title: Greeting
excerpt:
Dear citizens,
No matter whether you immigrated some time ago or very recently: I would like to welcome you to the Rems-Murr district!
Around 430,000 inhabitants live in the Rems-Murr district in a total of 31 towns and municipalities. Our district offers an attractive overall package of economically strong towns, communities with a high quality of life, picturesque nature and good infrastructure.
Together with all authorities, companies, associations and voluntarily committed citizens, we work every day to ensure that the entire district is an attractive place to live and do business. In a district of our size, orientation may not be easy at first glance. Moreover, there are numerous offers, opportunities, rights and obligations for all citizens in Germany.
With Integreat, we have therefore created a free digital platform for you that provides you with central information about our district and life in Germany in a compact and clear way. In the app you will find a lot of multilingual information on central information, but above all many offers on various topics such as health, work or education. The contents of the app are constantly updated. You are also welcome to make others aware of the app and share it with your friends and families.
We hope that Integreat will help you to quickly find your way around our district or to discover new offers and contact persons. I hope you enjoy getting to know, exploring, engaging and enriching our county.
Yours sincerely,

Dr. Richard SigelDistrict Administrator of the Rems-Murr District

title: Things to know about the Rems-Murr district
excerpt:
Numbers, data, facts
The Rems-Murr district is located in the Stuttgart region of Baden-Württemberg. The district takes its name from the rivers Rems and Murr.
With an area of 858 km² and a population of 426,635, the Rems-Murr-Kreis is one of the larger administrative districts.A total of 31 towns and municipalities belong to the Rems-Murr district. Among them are the six large district towns of Backnang, Fellbach, Schorndorf, Waiblingen, Weinstadt and Winnenden.
Economy
The Rems-Murr district is an attractive business location for both large companies and small and medium-sized enterprises. A special feature is its commercial and industrial structure. There are numerous large companies in the Rems-Murr district, such as Stihl (power saws), Bosch (household appliances) and Kärcher (household appliances). About 15 percent of the employees work in the mechanical engineering sector. This is a state record in Baden-Württemberg.

title: About Integreat
excerpt:
Integreat is a guide that supports you in your everyday life. You will findimportant addresses, contact persons as well as tips and tricks that can help you find yourway around.
This guide has several chapters. Each chapter deals with a different topic. Among other things, you will find information on doctors, schools, German courses or other institutions. There is also a chapter with ideas on what you can do in your free time. The information and leisure activities change. Your municipality updates them regularly. That's why it's very good if you check your mobile app often. You will always be informed about current activities and events. You can rely on the information in Integreat.
Download Integreat from your app store. You can also use this app offline if you don't have internet access. When you are back online, the app will update itself.
Sharing information
You can download and share important information, for example, as a PDF in the web app. In the mobile app, you can share interesting content directly, for example via WhatsApp, Facebook or email.
Latest news
With the Integreat smartphone app you can also receive push notifications. You can agree to receive them in the app's settings. Push notifications will send you important or last-minute information. 
Feedback
You can contribute to the development of the Integreat app in your municipality. You can give feedback using the smiley icons. This feedback ends up with the people who create the content. You can praise or criticise. If you have ideas or criticism, write down as many details as possible.
Read aloud function
The content of the Integreat app can also be read aloud. To do this, the read aloud function must be switched on in the settings of the smartphone. This works in all languages.
We very much hope that we can simplify your life in Germany with this app.

title: Entry from Ukraine and residence in Germany
excerpt:
Current information and entry requirements:
 Federal Foreign Office
 Federal Office for Migration and Refugees. 
 
Further information specifically for the Rems-Murr district can be found here. 
 
Can I enter Germany legally and stay there legally?
Foreigners normally require a residence permit - such as a visa or a residence authorisation - to enter and legally stay in Germany. Due to the special situation in Ukraine, an exception to this rule has been made: War refugees from Ukraine are temporarily exempt from the requirement of a residence permit in Germany. This exemption currently applies to first-time entries until 31 May 2023 for a period of 90 days and thus allows a stay without a residence permit until 29 August 2023 at the latest.
What happens after entry? Where can I register in Germany and where do I get accommodation and meals?
The procedure is divided into four consecutive steps:

First registration
Allocation to a place of residence (if you receive social benefits) 
Registration of the residential address at the destination 
Application for a residence permit.

Further information can be found here.
Can I work in Germany with a residence permit for temporary protection?
Yes, this is possible. However, gainful employment must first be authorised by the immigration  authority . When issuing the residence permit, the immigration authority will already enter in the residence title that gainful employment is permitted. This means that no further work permit from another authority is required.
Should Ukrainian nationals apply for asylum?
No, this is not necessary. The necessary protection is granted in a different, faster procedure. Ukrainian nationals are therefore advised not to apply for asylum. However, the right to apply for asylum at a later date remains unaffected.

Information portal of the German government
The Federal Ministry offers a digital information portal in German, English, Russian and Ukrainian. Here you will find all official information about residence and life in Germany.
 Germany4Ukraine

Embassy of Ukraine in Berlin +493028887128 Albrechtstraße 26, 10117 Berlin

title: Basic Law and Human Rights
excerpt:
The Basic Law
In every country there are rules that all people must abide by. The most important law for Germany is the Basic Law. It is a collection of 146 articles. Each article stands for a law, i.e. a rule. These rules determine how people live together in Germany. The basic rights protect the freedom of every individual. They are laid down in Articles 1 to 19 of the Basic Law (catalogue of basic rights).
 Here you can find the Basic Law in different languages.
Universal Declaration of Human Rights
Human rights are important rights that apply always and to all people around the world. Human rights are rights that every human being has by virtue of being human. They protect the dignity of every human being and are equally available to all without distinction of any kind, such as colour, sex, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, property, birth or other status. 
There are 30 rights. The most important are:

All people are of equal value.
Every person is allowed to have his or her own opinion.
The right to peace and security.
The rules for living together in Germany are derived from these basic rights.

The State Office for Political Education of North Rhine-Westphalia has published the brochure "Democracy for me" in which these rules are clearly presented. These rules, as well as examples of what is and is not allowed in Germany, are presented here under each keyword.

They protect the dignity of every human being and are equally available to all without distinction of any kind, such as colour, sex, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, property, birth or other status.

There are 30 rights. The most important are:

  • All people are of equal value.
  • Every person is allowed to have his or her own opinion.
  • The right to peace and security.
  • The rules for living together in Germany are derived from these basic rights.

The State Office for Political Education of North Rhine-Westphalia has published the brochure "Democracy for me" in which these rules are clearly presented. These rules, as well as examples of what is and is not allowed in Germany, are presented here under each keyword.

title: Rule of law
excerpt:
Germany is a democratic constitutional state. The Basic Law guarantees human dignity, freedom and justice. There are laws to ensure that human rights are respected.
Political decisions are made by representatives of the people. The people's representatives are elected by the Germans in free elections.
The laws apply equally to all people in Germany. The state must abide by the laws. All people living in Germany must also abide by German laws.
That means, for example:

If people think that other people or the public administration are doing them wrong, they can turn to a court. These courts are independent. This means: the government is not allowed to tell the courts how to decide.
State courts decide whether someone is punished. Punishments are, for example, fines, community service or prison. There is no death penalty in Germany.
The police have the task of ensuring that all people can live in freedom and safety.
The practice of religion must not violate laws. The laws always take precedence over religion.

This is not allowed in Germany, for example:

To incite hatred or violence.
To fight the democratic system and its values.
These offences can lead to a prison sentence.

After serving the sentence, non-German nationals can lose their right to stay under certain conditions and be deported.
content:
Germany is a democratic constitutional state. The Basic Law guarantees human dignity, freedom and justice. There are laws to ensure that human rights are respected.

Political decisions are made by representatives of the people. The people's representatives are elected by the Germans in free elections.

The laws apply equally to all people in Germany. The state must abide by the laws. All people living in Germany must also abide by German laws.

That means, for example:

  • If people think that other people or the public administration are doing them wrong, they can turn to a court. These courts are independent. This means: the government is not allowed to tell the courts how to decide.
  • State courts decide whether someone is punished. Punishments are, for example, fines, community service or prison. There is no death penalty in Germany.
  • The police have the task of ensuring that all people can live in freedom and safety.
  • The practice of religion must not violate laws. The laws always take precedence over religion.

This is not allowed in Germany, for example:

  • To incite hatred or violence.
  • To fight the democratic system and its values.
  • These offences can lead to a prison sentence.

After serving the sentence, non-German nationals can lose their right to stay under certain conditions and be deported.

title: Personal freedom
excerpt:
All adults are allowed to decide about themselves and their own lives. No matter whether man or woman, young or old, with or without disabilities, no matter what skin colour or religious affiliation.
All people are allowed to do what they want as long as they abide by the law and do not restrict others in their freedom.
That means, for example:

All people are allowed to decide what they want to wear. Women, for example, are allowed to decide whether they want to wear trousers, dresses, long or short skirts, tight or loose clothing or a headscarf. Men are allowed to decide, for example, whether to wear a suit and tie, T-shirt and jeans, turban, hat or beard.
All people are allowed to eat what they want and what they like. The decision whether to eat meat (including pork or beef) is made by people all by themselves. There are no universally valid or religiously based food regulations from the state.
The consumption of alcohol is permitted for adults. For children and adolescents, the consumption of alcohol is prohibited.
Every woman and every man may decide for themselves whether and whom they wish to marry. Every woman and every man may divorce.Unmarried couples may live together and have children.Members of different religions and beliefs may marry and have children.
Contraception is allowed for both sexes. A person's decision to use contraception must be respected.
Same-sex partnerships are accepted. Same-sex couples can marry. The rights of a civil partnership are similar to those of a marriage between a man and a woman.
Everyone decides for themselves how and where they want to live. For people in the asylum process, this right may be restricted until an asylum application is accepted.
Sexual acts between adults may only take place with mutual consent. Any sexual act with children is prohibited.
Private property is allowed for every man and woman in Germany. It is allowed to own a house or a plot of land. Many companies are privately owned.
Women and men have equal rights when it comes to inheritance.

Important:
One's own freedom ends where it infringes on the freedom or human dignity of others or violates laws.

title: Equal rights for men and women
excerpt:
Women and men have the same rights.Women and men have the same duties.This is reflected in the laws and in daily life.
This means, for example:

Girls and boys go to school together and receive the same lessons. They take part in sports classes together.
Women are allowed to study or learn a profession. In principle, all professions are open to women.
Women assume responsibility in society, for example as policewomen, doctors, teachers or in offices and authorities. Their instructions must be followed.
Women decide for themselves what work they want to do. They can dispose of the money they earn themselves.
Women do not have to ask their husbands, parents or other family members for permission to work, open a bank account or sign contracts.
Women are allowed to dress the way they want.
Women decide for themselves if, when and whom they want to marry.
Mothers are especially protected. They do not have to and are not allowed to work for six weeks before and eight weeks after giving birth. They may not be dismissed because of their maternity.
The tasks and roles in the family are not prescribed.
Women participate in public life. They attend cultural, political or sporting events, restaurants and bars.
Women can vote and be elected to political offices.
Women and men are equal in inheritance rights, daughters as well as sons.
Sexual touching, comments or solicitations are only allowed if all parties agree. A "stop" or "no" must be respected at all costs.

This is not allowed in Germany, for example:

Any form of violence towards women, even in marriage.
No one may be sexually harassed.
Rape, even within marriage, is punished.
No one may be forced to marry. Coercion to marry by force or threat is punished.

This is reflected in the laws and in daily life.

This means, for example:

  • Girls and boys go to school together and receive the same lessons. They take part in sports classes together.
  • Women are allowed to study or learn a profession. In principle, all professions are open to women.
  • Women assume responsibility in society, for example as policewomen, doctors, teachers or in offices and authorities. Their instructions must be followed.
  • Women decide for themselves what work they want to do. They can dispose of the money they earn themselves.

title: Children's rights
excerpt:
Children and young people have rights. These rights are laid down in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. It also applies in Germany to all children and young people under the age of 18. In addition, there are many laws in Germany that protect the life, health and rights of children in a special way. The protection of children always comes first.
This means, for example:

All children have the same rights. No matter where they live, where they come from, what colour their skin is, what their parents do, what language they speak, what religion they have, whether they are a boy or a girl, what culture they live in, whether they have a disability, whether they are rich or poor.
Children have the right to a name, a birth certificate and a nationality, and to a family. The state basically helps when children lack any of these things.
Children should be able to live with their parents unless this puts them in danger. Parents may and must care for their children, protect and promote their health and well-being.
Children who have fled have the right to special protection and help.
Children must be protected so that they can grow up well.
Children must and may go to school. There is compulsory schooling. Parents must support their children in attending school. School education is free in Germany.
Children are allowed to form their own opinions.
At the age of 14 at the latest, children are allowed to decide all by themselves whether they want to belong to a religion and which one.
Children should be able to develop well. Parents are responsible for this. If they need support, the state must help and, for example, provide food, clothing and a place to live.
Children whose parents are not married have the same rights as children who live with married parents.

 
This is not allowed in Germany, for example:

Children may not be neglected or abused.
Children may not be beaten or physically or emotionally abused in any way.
Children may not be used as labour until they are 13 years old. When they are older, they may only engage in very limited work. This must not affect their health and development.
Children must not be abducted or used as objects of trade.
It is forbidden to perform sexual acts on children.

Here you can find the rights of the child  in different languages.

Contact pointYou have a problem? If you have a conflict with your parents, the school or other people who do not respect your wishes and rights, the Child Protection Agency is there for you and will try to find a solution to the problem that suits you best. For example, you can call the number against sorrow  08001110333  or   116111 free of charge at any time and tell trained people about your worries completely anonymously.
Child Protection Association Rems-Murr District:
 www.kinderschutzbund-schorndorf-waiblingen.de
 Karlstraße 19, 73614 Schorndorf, Germany 0718188 77 17 info@kinderschutzbund-schorndorf.de

title: Freedom from violence/physical integrity
excerpt:
Everyone has the right to live without violence. This means that all people have the right to life and physical integrity. This is understood to meanboth the physical and mental health of a person. This also applies in the private sphere.
This means, for example:

Conflicts should be resolved without violence.
Anyone who needs help in case of danger or conflict can call the police.
All instructions of the police are to be followed.
Vigilante justice is not permitted. If one's rights have been violated, a state court decides.
The state must act non-violently. It may only use force in exceptional cases when all other means have been exhausted.
There is no death penalty or corporal punishment, torture is prohibited.

This is not permitted in Germany, for example:

To physically abuse, injure or kill another person. This also applies within the family, at school and on the street.
Participating in a brawl that results in people being killed or seriously physically injured.
Blood revenge and murder in the name of honour.
Violence against women and children always and everywhere.
Human trafficking, slavery and the coercion of prostitution.
The sewing up, circumcision or mutilation of female genitalia.

Sewing up, cutting or mutilating the female genitals is also called female genital mutilation or circumcision . In Germany, this is a punishable offence. 
 Information on domestic violence can be found here.
content:
Everyone has the right to live without violence. This means that all people have the right to life and physical integrity. This is understood to meanboth the physical and mental health of a person. This also applies in the private sphere.

This means, for example:

  • Conflicts should be resolved without violence.
  • Anyone who needs help in case of danger or conflict can call the police.
  • All instructions of the police are to be followed.
  • Vigilante justice is not permitted. If one's rights have been violated, a state court decides.
  • The state must act non-violently. It may only use force in exceptional cases when all other means have been exhausted.
  • There is no death penalty or corporal punishment, torture is prohibited.

This is not permitted in Germany, for example:

  • To physically abuse, injure or kill another person. This also applies within the family, at school and on the street.
  • Participating in a brawl that results in people being killed or seriously physically injured.
  • Blood revenge and murder in the name of honour.
  • Violence against women and children always and everywhere.
  • Human trafficking, slavery and the coercion of prostitution.
  • The sewing up, circumcision or mutilation of female genitalia.

Sewing up, cutting or mutilating the female genitals is also called female genital mutilation or circumcision . In Germany, this is a punishable offence.

Information on domestic violence can be found here.

title: Right to vote
excerpt:
People in Germany have the right to vote. They are allowed to vote for politicians. That is written in a law.
And these are the most important elections in Germany:
Landtag election
You elect politicians for the Landtag in your federal state.The Landtag decides things for the federal state.A new Landtag is always elected after 5 years.
Election to the Bundestag
You elect politicians for the Bundestag.The Bundestag decides things for the whole of Germany.A new Bundestag is always elected after 4 years.
European election
You elect politicians for the European Parliament.The European Parliament decides things for all countries in the European Union.A new European Parliament is always elected after 5 years.

In Germany there are 2 different electoral rights:
1. the active right to vote
You have a German passport. And you are 18 years or older. Then you have the active right to vote. This means that you can vote.
For example, in these elections:

Bundestag election
Landtag election
Local elections
Mayor election
Senior citizens' council election

2. the right to stand for election
You have a German passport. And you are 18 years or older. Then you have the right to stand for election. This means: You can be elected by other people.
You can then work as a politician. For example, you then work

For the German Bundestag
For the Landtag
For local government
For the Foreigners' Advisory Council


 You are an EU citizen. You may then vote in Germany in these elections:

Local election
European election
content:
People in Germany have the right to vote. They are allowed to vote for politicians. That is written in a law.

And these are the most important elections in Germany:

Landtag election

You elect politicians for the Landtag in your federal state.
The Landtag decides things for the federal state.
A new Landtag is always elected after 5 years.

Election to the Bundestag

You elect politicians for the Bundestag.
The Bundestag decides things for the whole of Germany.
A new Bundestag is always elected after 4 years.

European election

You elect politicians for the European Parliament.
The European Parliament decides things for all countries in the European Union.
A new European Parliament is always elected after 5 years.

In Germany there are 2 different electoral rights:

1. the active right to vote

You have a German passport. And you are 18 years or older. Then you have the active right to vote. This means that you can vote.

For example, in these elections:

  • Bundestag election
  • Landtag election
  • Local elections
  • Mayor election
  • Senior citizens' council election

2. the right to stand for election

You have a German passport. And you are 18 years or older. Then you have the right to stand for election. This means: You can be elected by other people.

You can then work as a politician. For example, you then work

  • For the German Bundestag
  • For the Landtag
  • For local government
  • For the Foreigners' Advisory Council

You are an EU citizen.
You may then vote in Germany in these elections:

  • Local election
  • European election

title: Religious freedom
excerpt:
Religion and faith are a private matter in Germany. The state does not dictate to anyone whether and in which god he or she should believe. State and religion are separate.
This means, for example:

All people are free to practise their religion and faith and to choose for themselves.
All people have the freedom not to be religious and to say so. Those who do not believe in God may also say so publicly.
Members of different religions and beliefs may marry each other.
Marriage only counts as a legally valid marriage if it is concluded before the registry office. Marriages concluded exclusively within the framework of a religion are not legally binding in Germany.

For example, it is not permitted in Germany:

To place religious rules or traditions above applicable laws, for example to be married to several women at the same time or to slaughter an animal without special permission.
Boys may only be circumcised if this does not endanger their well-being.

Many people in Germany today are committed to dialogue between religions. The goal is the peaceful coexistence of religious people, people of faith and people who do not belong to any religion. The state is obliged to maintain ideological neutrality. As long as the practice of a religion does not endanger democracy or the separation of state and religion, it is protected.
content:
Religion and faith are a private matter in Germany. The state does not dictate to anyone whether and in which god he or she should believe. State and religion are separate.

This means, for example:

  • All people are free to practise their religion and faith and to choose for themselves.
  • All people have the freedom not to be religious and to say so. Those who do not believe in God may also say so publicly.
  • Members of different religions and beliefs may marry each other.
  • Marriage only counts as a legally valid marriage if it is concluded before the registry office. Marriages concluded exclusively within the framework of a religion are not legally binding in Germany.

For example, it is not permitted in Germany:

  • To place religious rules or traditions above applicable laws, for example to be married to several women at the same time or to slaughter an animal without special permission.
  • Boys may only be circumcised if this does not endanger their well-being.

Many people in Germany today are committed to dialogue between religions. The goal is the peaceful coexistence of religious people, people of faith and people who do not belong to any religion. The state is obliged to maintain ideological neutrality. As long as the practice of a religion does not endanger democracy or the separation of state and religion, it is protected.

title: Social justice
excerpt:
The state must respect and protect human dignity. Therefore, it should ensure social justice in the best possible way. It takes legal, financial and material actions to do so. All people in Germany who earn money pay part of their wages to the state. The higher your income, the more you have to pay. The more you earn, the more taxes you pay. The state is supposed to spend this money on the welfare of the people living in Germany.
This means, for example:

Every person registered as living in Germany has the right to basic medical care. This includes medical treatment in the case of illness or accident.
All people who have a job that is subject to social insurance pay contributions to health insurance, long-term care insurance and pension insurance.
Every adult must make an effort to pay for their own living expenses. If a person is not able to do this, they can request support from the state.
The state ensures that taxes are used to reduce social inequality and help people in crisis (refugees, for example).
The state provides financial support to parents, for example through child benefits.

This is not allowedin Germany, for example:

Tax fraud, for example paying fewer taxes than required.
Receiving state benefits without being entitled to them.
content:
The state must respect and protect human dignity. Therefore, it should ensure social justice in the best possible way. It takes legal, financial and material actions to do so. All people in Germany who earn money pay part of their wages to the state. The higher your income, the more you have to pay. The more you earn, the more taxes you pay. The state is supposed to spend this money on the welfare of the people living in Germany.

This means, for example:

  • Every person registered as living in Germany has the right to basic medical care. This includes medical treatment in the case of illness or accident.
  • All people who have a job that is subject to social insurance pay contributions to health insurance, long-term care insurance and pension insurance.
  • Every adult must make an effort to pay for their own living expenses. If a person is not able to do this, they can request support from the state.
  • The state ensures that taxes are used to reduce social inequality and help people in crisis (refugees, for example).
  • The state provides financial support to parents, for example through child benefits.

This is not allowedin Germany, for example:

  • Tax fraud, for example paying fewer taxes than required.
  • Receiving state benefits without being entitled to them.

title: Freedom of expression
excerpt:
All people are allowed to form their own opinions, to express and disseminate them freely. People are also allowed to express these opinions publicly. All media are also free, all people can inform themselves there. Anyone who freely expresses his or her opinion must pay attention to the protection of personal honour or the personal dignity of other people.
That means, for example:

The government may be criticised.
Religion may be criticised.
Artistic works may provoke. No one may dictate to writers, musicians or visual artists how they should work.
Government and religions may also be the subject of satire and critical art.
Anyone who feels insulted or his or her personal honour or dignity violated can turn to the police or to a court.

 
This is not allowed in Germany, for example:

The use of anti-constitutional symbols and calls to overthrow democracy.
Insulting expressions of opinion that disparage other people.
Defamation or slander against other people.
Inciting hatred and violence.
content:
All people are allowed to form their own opinions, to express and disseminate them freely. People are also allowed to express these opinions publicly. All media are also free, all people can inform themselves there. Anyone who freely expresses his or her opinion must pay attention to the protection of personal honour or the personal dignity of other people.

That means, for example:

  • The government may be criticised.
  • Religion may be criticised.
  • Artistic works may provoke. No one may dictate to writers, musicians or visual artists how they should work.
  • Government and religions may also be the subject of satire and critical art.
  • Anyone who feels insulted or his or her personal honour or dignity violated can turn to the police or to a court.

This is not allowed in Germany, for example:

  • The use of anti-constitutional symbols and calls to overthrow democracy.
  • Insulting expressions of opinion that disparage other people.
  • Defamation or slander against other people.
  • Inciting hatred and violence.

title: Offers in Korb
excerpt:
Offers in Korb
Doctors, pharmacies and emergency call
https://www.korb.de/de/leben-wohnen/gesundheit-notruf/aerzte-apotheken

Education

School https://www.korb.de/de/leben-wohnen/bildung-betreuung/gemeinschaftsschule-korb


Childcare https://www.korb.de/de/leben-wohnen/bildung-betreuung/kinderbetreuung


Libraries https://www.korb.de/de/freizeit-kultur/bildung-wissen/buechereien


Adult education centre Unteres Remstal https://www.korb.de/de/freizeit-kultur/bildung-wissen/volkshochschule


Everyday life and leisure
Freundeskreis Asyl Korb e.V.
The Freundeskreis Asyl Korb e.V. supports refugees who are accommodated in Korb. We are happy to welcome new supporters to celebrate parties together, garden, learn the language, play the drums, do sports, support trainees, build sculptures, organise donations, go on excursions and enjoy culture. We have the areas: Meeting, Language and Needs. We would also like to set up an area to support refugees in everyday life (support in discussions with employers, landlords, daycare centres and schools). If this interests you and you would like to support our organisation, please write to
 freundeskreis-asyl-korb@web.de
German language training:
We regularly organise practical training courses in the German language. If you as a refugee are interested in language training or if you are interested in speaking German with refugees, please contact:
 Axelle Morfis  07151/37455
Clothing collection in the Eimer building
We regularly accept clothing and everyday items for refugees (usually on the 1st Saturday of the month). Please check the Korber newsletter for more information. 
Garden of encounter
The association organises a garden of encounter, which can be used by refugees and Korb citizens to plant vegetables but also to meet each other.
Women's meeting place (from December 2023)
A meeting place for women of all ages with and without a refugee or migrant background. The project enables women to socialise, experience activities together and take part in discussions and talks.
 Every Tuesday from 9:30 - 11:30 a.m.  St John's parish hall
 Tanja Mayer 015780637708 ( also WhatsApp)
Special offers:
05.12.2023 Creative time-out with Anita
12.12.2023 Star magic: making stars with paper
19.12.2023 Christmas party
30.01.2024 Soul food: homemade dips
 
Meeting place for refugees from Ukraine
Organiser: Württembergischer Christusbund 
Every Saturday from 14:30 to 17:00 
 Waiblinger Straße 14, 71404 Korb
 https://www.christusbund.de/korb/gruppen/ukraine/#deutsch
Café International 
Organiser: Freundeskreis Asyl Korb e.V.
We regularly organise a Café International with a cultural programme and drinks for everyone in Korb. This café is also largely organised by the parishes in Korb.
Information in the calendar of events:
 https://www.korb.de/de/freizeit-kultur/veranstaltungen/kalender
Calendar of events
 https://www.korb.de/de/freizeit-kultur/veranstaltungen/kalender

 https://www.korb.de/de/freizeit-kultur/vereine-organisationen
Youth centre
 https://www.korb.de/de/freizeit-kultur/kinder-jugendliche/jugendtreff

title: Offers in Schwaikheim
excerpt:
Ina e.V. Asylum Circle of Friends - Integration and tutoring
The circle of friends offers language meetings, accompanies asylum seekers and refugees on visits to the authorities, doctors or schools, organises sports and leisure activities, supports asylum seekers and refugees in their job search or in their school and company training and coordinates donations in kind. The Friends of Schwaikheim usually publishes weekly information in the Schwaikheim community newsletter, for example about events or the search for donations in kind.
 Opening hours: Monday - Friday: 2.30 p.m. - 5.30 p.m., Tuesdays: 9.00 a.m. - 10.30 a.m., Thursdays: 9.00 a.m. - 11.00 a.m.
INa e.V. Integration and tutoring Schwaikheim 07195978112 info@inaev.de www.inaev.com

Language meeting of the Freundeskreis Asyl
A non-binding German course takes place on Mondays and Thursdays. Volunteers meet refugees and migrants, material is available or can be organised.
Anyone who would like to get involved can simply drop in without obligation.
 Opening hours: Monday and Thursday: 6.00 pm - 7.30 pm
INa e.V. Integration and tutoring centre Schwaikheim 07195978112 info@inaev.de www.inaev.com

Café International
The "Café International" takes place every Friday from 4.00 p.m. to approx. 6.00 p.m. in the annexe of the INa-Haus.
This is an opportunity for informal meetings and socialising.
 Opening hours: Friday: 4.00 p.m. - 6.00 p.m.
INa e.V. Integration and tutoring centre Schwaikheim 07195978112 info@inaev.de  www.inaev.com

title: Immigration authorities in the district
excerpt:
The Aliens Department is responsible for measures relating to residence and passport law. For example:

Issuing or extending residence permits
Issuing a settlement permit
Issue or extend a residence permit
Applying for a work permit
Changing or cancelling residence requirements
Counselling on voluntary departure 
Issuing an employment permit
Solving problem situations (for example: passport lost or stolen)


Responsible for Alfdorf, Berglen, Großerlach, Kaisersbach, Kernen im Remstal, Korb, Leutenbach, Plüderhausen, Remshalden, Rudersberg, Schwaikheim, Spiegelberg, Sulbzbach an der Murr, Urbach, Winterbach:

title: Integration Officer
excerpt:
Municipal integration officers
The aim of the municipal integration officers is to promote the integration of people with a migration background and refugees in the district and to work towards their successful integration into society.
You can find the integration officers in your town / municipality here.

Integration officers of the district
Sandra Kreb and Stefan Saltikiotis are the district's integration officers. They are the contacts for all questions relating to integration at district level and are responsible for implementing measures from the integration plan.
The district integration officers liaise closely with the local integration officers in the towns and municipalities and are building up a district-wide integration network. 
 
If you are affected by racist discrimination , you can also contact the integration officers. They will be happy to help you and treat your concerns confidentially.

title: Rems-Murr job centre

The Rems-Murr Job Centre (SGB II) is responsible, among other things, for recognised refugees with a residence permit who are entitled to citizen's allowance and do not receive benefits under the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act. 
In addition to securing their livelihood, we support recognised refugees in their integration into the labour market through 

Fast transition to an integration course (learning German)

title: Office for Social Affairs and Participation
excerpt:
The Office for Social Affairs and Participation takes care of people who cannot work and therefore do not earn any money. These can be sick or old people , but also, for example, single women or men. These people can apply for so-called social assistance . The office checks whether the applicants cannot finance their lives with their own means. If this is not possible, the office pays aid to ensure people's subsistence level.  It covers the costs of living, rent and other expenses.
The Social Welfare Office is the point of contact for a wide range of financial assistance. But you can also find advice and help on various social situations here.

Contact
Rudolf LeonhardtHead of the Office for Social Affairs and Participation in the District Office
 071515011373

title: District Youth Welfare Office
excerpt:
Children's rights must be observed when bringing up children and young people. The district youth welfare office supports parents in bringing up children and young people. Anyone can contact the youth welfare office free of charge if they have problems. Even children and young people!
The Youth Welfare Office offers help in accordance with the Child Welfare Act and Youth Welfare Act (SGB VIII) or acts as an intermediary.
These services include in particular

Adoption
General social services
Care assistance
Integration assistance
Education of disabled and non-disabled children in kindergarten and school
Support for the family
Youth counselling
Assistance, foster care, guardianship
Advance maintenance payments
Economic youth welfare

 Parents and other legal guardians, as well as young people themselves, can turn to the Youth Welfare Office at the District Office in all matters relating to the upbringing and development of children and young people. You will find counselling and support in emergencies and conflict situations.

Contact
Rems-Murr district office Winnender Str. 30/1, Waiblingen kreisjugendamt@rems-murr-kreis.de 071515011286

title: Employment Agency
excerpt:
The Employment Agency (SGB III) is responsible for asylum seekers and persons with tolerated status who receive benefits under the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act. 
Job placementAre you looking for a job or do you want to do further vocational training? You can discuss these and many other questions with the job centre. The employment counsellors at all locations in the agency district will be happy to help and advise you.
Further information

Job placement
Advice on taking up employment
Advice on further vocational training
Information on looking for work and finding a job
Many of your questions can be clarified in a personal meeting, arrange your counselling appointment, also by telephone.

Careers counsellingCareers counselling supports you in your choice of studies and career, during your training and at the beginning of your working life. You can clarify important questions about your professional future in a personal counselling session.
Counselling is available for

School pupils
trainees
students and
university graduates.

In addition, anyone who is seeking vocational training for the first time or wants to reorient themselves professionally.
Careers counselling can help you, for example

find a suitable profession or degree programme
clarify questions about the content of an apprenticeship or degree programme
find a training place and apply for it
develop alternatives if your dream job doesn't work out
utilise funding opportunities
obtain information on the training market or labour market.

You can find out what else careers counselling can do for you in the information sheet on careers counselling services for teenagers and young adults.

content:
The Employment Agency (SGB III) is responsible for asylum seekers and persons with tolerated status who receive benefits under the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act.

Job placement
Are you looking for a job or do you want to do further vocational training? You can discuss these and many other questions with the job centre. The employment counsellors at all locations in the agency district will be happy to help and advise you.

Further information

  • Job placement
  • Advice on taking up employment
  • Advice on further vocational training
  • Information on looking for work and finding a job
  • Many of your questions can be clarified in a personal meeting, arrange your counselling appointment, also by telephone.

Careers counselling
Careers counselling supports you in your choice of studies and career, during your training and at the beginning of your working life. You can clarify important questions about your professional future in a personal counselling session.

Counselling is available for

  • School pupils
  • trainees
  • students and
  • university graduates.

In addition, anyone who is seeking vocational training for the first time or wants to reorient themselves professionally.

Careers counselling can help you, for example

  • find a suitable profession or degree programme
  • clarify questions about the content of an apprenticeship or degree programme
  • find a training place and apply for it
  • develop alternatives if your dream job doesn't work out
  • utilise funding opportunities
  • obtain information on the training market or labour market.

You can find out what else careers counselling can do for you in the information sheet on careers counselling services for teenagers and young adults.

title: Standesamt (Registry Office)
excerpt:
The registry office has several tasks. For example, when a child is born, the parents are obliged to report the birth of the child to the registry office in person for the registration ofthe birth. If you want to get married, the registry office is responsible for registering your marriage. 
The tasks at a glance

Certifying births and deaths
Marriages and life partnerships
Accepting applications to leave the Church
Name changes
Issue of documents(birth certificate, death certificate, marriage certificate)

 Contact the registry office in your municipality or town.
content:
The registry office has several tasks. For example, when a child is born, the parents are obliged to report the birth of the child to the registry office in person for the registration ofthe birth. If you want to get married, the registry office is responsible for registering your marriage.

The tasks at a glance

  • Certifying births and deaths
  • Marriages and life partnerships
  • Accepting applications to leave the Church
  • Name changes
  • Issue of documents(birth certificate, death certificate, marriage certificate)

Contact the registry office in your municipality or town.

title: Police
excerpt:
The police are there to protectus from danger. They also investigate and solve crimes. The police have nothing to do with the secret service or politicians. There is an emergency? Then you can reach the police at any time under 110. The call is free of charge. 
There are laws which govern what the police can and can’t do. For example, in order to search a house, they need a warrant from a judge. Unless there is great danger to a person in the home. 
When should I call the police?
You or another person are in danger? You have witnessed a crime?  Then call the police. Burglary, theft, arson and damage to property are also included. Sexual abuse, assault or threats are also the responsibility of the police. Also in the case of domestic violence you should call the police.
You can also call the police for a so-called administrative offence . For example, if someone does not comply with quiet times and plays loud music at night.
If you dial the emergency number 110, the police will be with you as soon as possible.

Also, if you notice political or religious radicalisation of young adults in your environment, you can report this to the police. However, you can also contact the counselling centre for radicalisation for this:
 09119434343 (available in several languages)

title: LGBTIQ* counselling centres
excerpt:
In Germany, people of different religions, genders, origins and political views live together peacefully and enjoy the same rights. The same applies to people of different sexual orientations or gender identities: lesbians, gays, bisexuals, transgender people, intersex people and queer people, or LGBTIQ for short, have the same rights in Germany as other people.
In addition to the two genders "male" and "female", Germany has recently introduced the third gender entry "diverse". Transgender people in Germany can have their gender entry and name changed.
Women in Germany are allowed to love and marry other women, men other men.
 Many LGBTIQ* people have fled to Germany because they were persecuted in their home country. If you have fled and are lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender or intersex, you can find support, social contacts and information from many LGBTIQ organisations in Germany. 
Lesbian and Gay Association in Germany (LSVD)Project "Queer Refugees Germany"
  www.queer-refugees.de  queer-refugees@lsvd.de
Counselling in the Rems Murr district  

Pro Familia in Waiblingen

 LGBTIQ* counselling (profamilia.de)

Rems Queer CircleOpen group for queer young people in the Rems-Murr district and surrounding areaEvery 1st Saturday of the month at 2 pm in Mühlstraße 3 in Backnang.

 www.instagram.com/rems_queer_kreis/  jugendgruppe.remsqueerkreis@gmail.com
Counselling in Stuttgart

The Regenbogen Refugium of Weissenburg e. V. offers meetings and networking opportunities for LGBTTIQ refugees and their supporters.Counselling for LGBTTIQ refugees takes place twice a month in cooperation with amnesty international Stuttgart.
The Turkish community in Baden-Württemberg (tgbw) offers "Specialist counselling for gender and cultural diversity in Stuttgart".  It is aimed specifically at LGBTIQ* people with an international history and/or experiences of racism.

In Germany, people of different religions, genders, origins and political views live together peacefully and enjoy the same rights. The same applies to people of different sexual orientations or gender identities: lesbians, gays, bisexuals, transgender people, intersex people and queer people, or LGBTIQ for short, have the same rights in Germany as other people.

In addition to the two genders "male" and "female", Germany has recently introduced the third gender entry "diverse". Transgender people in Germany can have their gender entry and name changed.

Women in Germany are allowed to love and marry other women, men other men.

Many LGBTIQ* people have fled to Germany because they were persecuted in their home country. If you have fled and are lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender or intersex, you can find support, social contacts and information from many LGBTIQ organisations in Germany.

title: Migration counselling for adult immigrants (aged 27 and over)
excerpt:
Migration counselling supports, accompanies and informs immigrants aged 27 and over with the aim of helping them to settle into their new environment. 
Who can contact the migration counselling service?

Newly arrived adult foreigners and their families who are permanently resident in Germany 
Newly arrived ethnic German repatriates and their families
Newly arrived EU citizens and their families
Migrants who have been living in Germany for some time and have migration-specific questions

The migration counselling service supports you 

in connection with residence and citizenship law
your entitlements under social law
family reunification of the nuclear family
in the search for a German and integration course
on childcare options for your children during your participation in an integration course
with information on the professional recognition procedure
Financial issues and entitlements under social law
on leisure and contact options


Migration counselling Backnang

Mrs Anastasia Deliaridou 071919115610 deliaridou.a@caritas-ludwigsburg-waiblingen-enz.de

an impediment

If the discrimination has happened at work, when looking for a flat, in education or in everyday life, the Anti-Discrimination Office is the right place foryou.

Any person affected by discrimination can contact the anti-discrimination office.

title: Forced marriage
content:
Every person may decide for himself or herself who and when he or she marries. 

A forced marriage is a violation of human rights and punishable in Germany. 

Are you afraid of being married against your will? 

You have been approached by a person who is at risk of forced marriage?

Seek help and support, the sooner the better.

title: Return counselling
excerpt:
Do you want to return to your home country before the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) has decided on your asylum application? You don't know how to get your passport back or you need financial help for your return journey? 
The return counselling service will advise you on options for voluntary departure to your home country. The counselling is open-ended. This means that you decide for yourself after the counselling whether you want to leave voluntarily or not.
The main target group are people in the Rems-Murr district who are considering voluntary departure and return to their home country. This applies in particular to

Foreign nationals without a right of residence (e.g. tolerated persons)
Asylum seekers in the ongoing procedure
Foreign nationals with only a temporary right of residence for humanitarian reasons
Foreign nationals who have a permanent right of residence


Contact

title: DoorOpener Project
excerpt:
Housing is scarce and hardly affordable any more. Even people with a regular income now have a hard time on the housing market. The TürÖffner project rents housing in the Rems Murr district and rents it out to a diverse range of people. These people differ in terms of their cultural and religious affiliation, gender, lifestyle, sexual identity, age, ideology, physical characteristics, social status, education and much more. Every person is unique in their own way. That is why the group of tenants includes

Single parents with their children
People who are at risk of homelessness
People with a migration background
Single people and families with a low income
People with disabilities

title: General information on the procedure
excerpt:
Are you registered in Germany and live in shared accommodation? What happens next?
Here you will find a series of multilingual explanatory videos on the subject of asylum processes on the following topics:

Procedure of the asylum process
How to prepare for the hearing
What is an asylum decision and how does the appeal procedure work?

The BAMF has compiled a lot of information for you here.  Here you will find a film that explains the procedure.
The next steps are explained here:
1. Personal application for asylum
You apply for asylum at the BundesAmt für Migration und Flüchtlinge (BAMF).Important: You can only submit your application in person, you cannot send this application by post.You will receive the appointment and the responsible BAMF office with your proof of arrival. If you did not get an appointment, ask your social worker.
2. First interview appointment (asylum application)
Go a few days before your 1. Appointment (asylum application, 1. Interview appointment) or your 2. Appointment (hearing, 2. Interview date) with your documents to your social workers in the accommodation.If you have your 1. Interview at the BAMF, please remember to bring enough food with you. There may be long waiting times.
As long as you are in the asylum procedure, you have a residence permit.
3. Personal hearing
The 2nd interview date is the hearing itself. The BAMF decides on your application for asylum. It will then send you a decision (Bescheid). Show the notice to your social worker. They will explain to you what was decided by the BAMF and what steps you can take.
content:
Are you registered in Germany and live in shared accommodation? What happens next?

Here you will find a series of multilingual explanatory videos on the subject of asylum processes on the following topics:

  • Procedure of the asylum process
  • How to prepare for the hearing
  • What is an asylum decision and how does the appeal procedure work?

The BAMF has compiled a lot of information for you here. Here you will find a film that explains the procedure.

The next steps are explained here:

1. Personal application for asylum

You apply for asylum at the BundesAmt für Migration und Flüchtlinge (BAMF).
Important: You can only submit your application in person, you cannot send this application by post.
You will receive the appointment and the responsible BAMF office with your proof of arrival. If you did not get an appointment, ask your social worker.

2. First interview appointment (asylum application)

Go a few days before your 1. Appointment (asylum application, 1. Interview appointment) or your 2. Appointment (hearing, 2. Interview date) with your documents to your social workers in the accommodation.
If you have your 1. Interview at the BAMF, please remember to bring enough food with you. There may be long waiting times.

As long as you are in the asylum procedure, you have a residence permit.

3. Personal hearing

The 2nd interview date is the hearing itself. The BAMF decides on your application for asylum. It will then send you a decision (Bescheid). Show the notice to your social worker. They will explain to you what was decided by the BAMF and what steps you can take.

title: Temporary Residence Permit (Aufenthaltsgestattung)
excerpt:
Duration: Limited in timeStatus: Asylum seekersBackground: Issued for the purpose of conducting an asylum procedure until the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) reaches a decision. This is NOT a residence permit!
The asylum seeker's identity document contains conditions relating to employment, housing situation and territorial restrictions.
The Agentur für Arbeit (Federal Employment Agency) is responsible for the placement in work.
If a work permit is necessary, it can be obtained from the “Ausländerbehörde” (Immigration Office) of your place of residence. To do this, you must fill in applications with the help of your employer. Your social worker will help you fill it out.
These are the applications:

Job description
Declaration on the employment relationship

If you do not work, you will receive benefits according to the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act.

The Agentur für Arbeit (Federal Employment Agency) is responsible for the placement in work.

If a work permit is necessary, it can be obtained from the “Ausländerbehörde” (Immigration Office) of your place of residence. To do this, you must fill in applications with the help of your employer. Your social worker will help you fill it out.

If you do not work, you will receive benefits according to the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act.

title: Benefits under the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act (AsylbLG)
excerpt:
You will receive benefits under the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act if you:

are a foreigner without a residence permit.
are a foreigner with authorisation to stay under the Asylum Act or a tolerated stay permit.
have no income or assets.
earn too little in your job and need support to cover your living expenses.

You will receive

a standard requirement (money for your daily needs for food, clothing, hygiene)
Accommodation costs (costs for rent or accommodation fees)
cover in the event of illness
Initial equipment for housing and newborns
Benefits for education and participation

If you need help or support, give us a call and arrange a counselling appointment.
Benefits
The Benefits for Refugees department is responsible for granting and paying benefits in accordance with the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act (AsylbLG), in particular to tolerated and authorised persons.
Benefits in accordance with the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act (AsylbLG) provide for subsistence if income and assets are insufficient.
Benefits centre of the district office
  Rötestraße 17, 71332 Waiblingen
Opening hours:

Closed on Mondays
Tuesday - Friday: 8.30 - 12 noon
Thursdays: 1.30 - 6 pm

 071515011172
Online application
 Here you will find the online application for benefits under the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act.
Further forms can be found here.
content:
You will receive benefits under the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act if you:

  • are a foreigner without a residence permit.
  • are a foreigner with authorisation to stay under the Asylum Act or a tolerated stay permit.
  • have no income or assets.
  • earn too little in your job and need support to cover your living expenses.

You will receive

  • a standard requirement (money for your daily needs for food, clothing, hygiene)
  • Accommodation costs (costs for rent or accommodation fees)
  • cover in the event of illness
  • Initial equipment for housing and newborns
  • Benefits for education and participation

If you need help or support, give us a call and arrange a counselling appointment.

Benefits

The Benefits for Refugees department is responsible for granting and paying benefits in accordance with the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act (AsylbLG), in particular to tolerated and authorised persons.

Benefits in accordance with the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act (AsylbLG) provide for subsistence if income and assets are insufficient.

title: Work permit
excerpt:
If you have a residence permit or proof of arrival, your access to the labour market is restricted. Self-employment is generally not permitted. To work as an employee, you must apply for a work permit at your foreigners authority before you start working.
Asylum seekers can get a work permit if they have already been in Germany for 3 months and no longer have to live in an initial reception centre. If you still have to live in an initial reception centre, you can get a work permit after 6 months if you have minor children. If you do not have minor children and are still living in an initial reception centre, you can get a work permit after 9 months .
Asylum seekers cannot get a work permit if their asylum application has been rejected because another EU country is responsible for it (Dublin procedure) or if they come from a "safe" country of origin and their asylum application filed after 31 August 2015 has been rejected. You can find out more about safe countries of origin in our chapter "Safe countries of origin".
Important: Your work permit is not valid in general, but for a very specific job. To do this, the future employer must fill in a form about the conditions of the job, and you yourself must fill in the "Application for permission to work".
Documents
 Certificate of employment and earnings (PDF file)(for employees; to be completed by the employer)
content:
If you have a residence permit or proof of arrival, your access to the labour market is restricted. Self-employment is generally not permitted. To work as an employee, you must apply for a work permit at your foreigners authority before you start working.

Asylum seekers can get a work permit if they have already been in Germany for 3 months and no longer have to live in an initial reception centre. If you still have to live in an initial reception centre, you can get a work permit after 6 months if you have minor children. If you do not have minor children and are still living in an initial reception centre, you can get a work permit after 9 months .

Asylum seekers cannot get a work permit if their asylum application has been rejected because another EU country is responsible for it (Dublin procedure) or if they come from a "safe" country of origin and their asylum application filed after 31 August 2015 has been rejected. You can find out more about safe countries of origin in our chapter "Safe countries of origin".

Important: Your work permit is not valid in general, but for a very specific job. To do this, the future employer must fill in a form about the conditions of the job, and you yourself must fill in the "Application for permission to work".

Documents

Certificate of employment and earnings (PDF file)(for employees; to be completed by the employer)

title: Residence requirement (Wohnsitzauflage)
excerpt:
Recognised refugees in Baden-Württemberg are generally given a "residence requirement" for a specific municipality.
Residence requirement means that refugees with a residence permit, residence permit, proof of arrival or toleration are obliged to live in a certain place.
The residence requirement only ceases to apply when you have your own income. 
Is it possible to move for a job?
The residence requirement can be lifted if you prove that you are living in a different place

start vocational training or a course of study
can take up an employment relationship subject to social security contributions
the probable permanent workplace is located at an unreasonable distance from the previous place of residence

Application for removal of the residency requirement is possible for both temporary and permanent employment. However, please note the following:

The employment must be expected to last longer than 3 months
The weekly working time must be at least 15 hours
The net income must be above the SGB II rate for standard requirements, accommodation and heating.

Modification of the residence requirement and deletion of the residence requirement:
You must submit the application for lifting or changing the residence requirement to the Aliens' Registration Office of your current place of residence.
The Immigration Office at the destination of the move must approve as well.
Important: Do not sign the tenancy agreement until the foreigners authority at your destination has approved the move.
You can find information on changing your place of residence through a redistribution application here.
content:
Recognised refugees in Baden-Württemberg are generally given a "residence requirement" for a specific municipality.

Residence requirement means that refugees with a residence permit, residence permit, proof of arrival or toleration are obliged to live in a certain place.

The residence requirement only ceases to apply when you have your own income.

Is it possible to move for a job?

The residence requirement can be lifted if you prove that you are living in a different place

  • start vocational training or a course of study
  • can take up an employment relationship subject to social security contributions
  • the probable permanent workplace is located at an unreasonable distance from the previous place of residence

Application for removal of the residency requirement is possible for both temporary and permanent employment. However, please note the following:

  • The employment must be expected to last longer than 3 months
  • The weekly working time must be at least 15 hours
  • The net income must be above the SGB II rate for standard requirements, accommodation and heating.

Modification of the residence requirement and deletion of the residence requirement:

You must submit the application for lifting or changing the residence requirement to the Aliens' Registration Office of your current place of residence.

The Immigration Office at the destination of the move must approve as well.

Important: Do not sign the tenancy agreement until the foreigners authority at your destination has approved the move.

You can find information on changing your place of residence through a redistribution application here.

title: Change of residence through redistribution application
excerpt:
Redistribution requestYou can apply for a change of residence with a reallocation application, which you can submit to your competent foreigners authority. The possibility of redistribution exists, for example, in the case of family reunification with a spouse or minor children. In addition, other humanitarian reasons or the prospect of work may be taken into account.
 Redistribution application (PDF file)(for asylum seekers in the current asylum procedure)

Redistribution request
You can apply for a change of residence with a reallocation application, which you can submit to your competent foreigners authority. The possibility of redistribution exists, for example, in the case of family reunification with a spouse or minor children. In addition, other humanitarian reasons or the prospect of work may be taken into account.

Redistribution application (PDF file)(for asylum seekers in the current asylum procedure)

title: Identity clarification
excerpt:
You entered Germany without a passport?
The authorities need to know who you are:

what is your name
when you were born and
which country you are from

This is called identity. To do this, you need evidence. The best proof is the passport from your home country. If you do not have a passport, you can alternatively present other identity documents as proof (example: Identity card, citizenship card, birth certificate, driving licence).
In Germany, all foreigners are subject to a passport obligation. Exceptions to the passport requirement may be permitted in justified individual cases.
If you do not have a passport, you are required to obtain one. Your cooperation in obtaining a passport is vital. This is because your cooperation in obtaining a passport or in clarifying your identity can be taken into account by the Aliens Department when it comes to decisions under aliens law.
Cooperation obligations
General duties to cooperate "The foreigner is personally obliged to cooperate in clarifying the facts of the case."  (§ 15 Asylum Act):
You are committed to

provide required information orally and, upon request, also in writing
Present and surrender your passport or passport replacement to the authorities
to present and leave all necessary documents with the authority (example: visas issued by other states, residence permits, airline tickets, driving licences, birth certificates, military passports, marriage certificates, testimonials)
if you do not have a valid passport or passport replacement, to cooperate in obtaining an identity document 
to present, hand over and temporarily surrender your passport, passport substitute or the substitute identity document at the request of the authority 

Important notes:

Hand over all identity documents to the Aliens' Registration Office or the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees. Have the authority make a copy of your documents and confirm the submission in writing.
If you do not have papers, contact parents or siblings in your home country and ask them to get the documents. Alternatively, you can hire a lawyer or other persons in your home country to obtain identity documents.
Write down all the steps of your involvement in the identity clarification process and collect evidence.
While the asylum procedure is still ongoing, you cannot be required by the German authorities to appear at your embassy.

Passport obligation in the asylum procedure
During the asylum procedure, the Aliens' Registration Office cannot require passports to be obtained, but passport obligations still apply, for example they are fulfilled by the possession of a substitute identity card.
 
 More information in several languages
content:
You entered Germany without a passport?

The authorities need to know who you are:

  • what is your name
  • when you were born and
  • which country you are from

This is called identity. To do this, you need evidence. The best proof is the passport from your home country. If you do not have a passport, you can alternatively present other identity documents as proof (example: Identity card, citizenship card, birth certificate, driving licence).

In Germany, all foreigners are subject to a passport obligation. Exceptions to the passport requirement may be permitted in justified individual cases.

If you do not have a passport, you are required to obtain one. Your cooperation in obtaining a passport is vital. This is because your cooperation in obtaining a passport or in clarifying your identity can be taken into account by the Aliens Department when it comes to decisions under aliens law.

Cooperation obligations

General duties to cooperate "The foreigner is personally obliged to cooperate in clarifying the facts of the case."  (§ 15 Asylum Act):

You are committed to

  • provide required information orally and, upon request, also in writing
  • Present and surrender your passport or passport replacement to the authorities
  • to present and leave all necessary documents with the authority (example: visas issued by other states, residence permits, airline tickets, driving licences, birth certificates, military passports, marriage certificates, testimonials)
  • if you do not have a valid passport or passport replacement, to cooperate in obtaining an identity document 
  • to present, hand over and temporarily surrender your passport, passport substitute or the substitute identity document at the request of the authority 

Important notes:

  • Hand over all identity documents to the Aliens' Registration Office or the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees. Have the authority make a copy of your documents and confirm the submission in writing.
  • If you do not have papers, contact parents or siblings in your home country and ask them to get the documents. Alternatively, you can hire a lawyer or other persons in your home country to obtain identity documents.
  • Write down all the steps of your involvement in the identity clarification process and collect evidence.
  • While the asylum procedure is still ongoing, you cannot be required by the German authorities to appear at your embassy.

Passport obligation in the asylum procedure

During the asylum procedure, the Aliens' Registration Office cannot require passports to be obtained, but passport obligations still apply, for example they are fulfilled by the possession of a substitute identity card.

 

More information in several languages

title: Decisions of the BAMF (Federal Office for Migration and Refugees)
excerpt:
The decision from the BAMF (Federal Office for Migration and Refugees)
Some time after your hearing (interview) at the BAMF you will receive your decision by post (yellow envelope). The decision states how your asylum procedure was decided. After receiving the decision, show it immediately to your social care provider. They will explain to you what was decided by the BAMF and what steps you can take.
Important! You have a period of 2 weeks to file a complaint against the decision. The deadline begins on the date printed on the yellow envelope.
There are the following decisions of the asylum procedure:
Right of asylum – Article 16a of the Basic Law (GG):

Residence permit for 3 years
Settlement permit possible after 3 years at the earliest (prerequisites are checked individually)
unlimited labour market access
Entitlement to family reunion

Granting asylum/refugee status § 3 German Asylum Law (AsylG):

Residence permit for 3 years (thereafter extension under certain circumstances)
Settlement permit possible after 3 years at the earliest (prerequisites are checked individually)
unlimited labour market access
Entitlement to family reunion

Granting subsidiary protection § 4 German Asylum Law (AsylG):

Residence permit for 1 year (2 more years for each extension)
Settlement permit possible after 5 years at the earliest (prerequisites are checked individually)
Employment permitted, self-employment only with permission from foreigners authority
Possibility of family reunification to be examined individually

Determination of a national ban on deportation § 60 (5) and (7) Residence Act (AufenthG):

Residence permit for 1 year (with extension for 1 further year each)
Settlement permit possible after 5 years at the earliest (prerequisites are checked individually)
Employment possible with permission from the foreigners authority
Family reunion not possible


An asylum application was rejected? There are two types of rejection:

The asylum application is rejected as inadmissiblebecause another country is responsible for processing the asylum application (Dublin procedure). This is the case if you have already applied for asylum in a different country or had your fingerprints taken there. Deportation to this country is threatened (example: Italy).
The asylum application is rejected (national procedure). Deportation to your country of origin will be imposed.

In these two cases, you are legally obliged to leave Germany and must leave again. As long as your deportation is not possible, you will be granted a " Duldung“ (toleration) under certain circumstances. A Duldung is not a residence title. The Regional Council is responsible for tolerated persons. They also oversee and carry out deportation.
What can I do if I do not want to be deported but no longer have any options to stay in Germany?
If you decide to leave voluntarily, you can receive financial support for your new start in your home country.
content:
The decision from the BAMF (Federal Office for Migration and Refugees)

Some time after your hearing (interview) at the BAMF you will receive your decision by post (yellow envelope). The decision states how your asylum procedure was decided. After receiving the decision, show it immediately to your social care provider. They will explain to you what was decided by the BAMF and what steps you can take.

Important! You have a period of 2 weeks to file a complaint against the decision. The deadline begins on the date printed on the yellow envelope.

There are the following decisions of the asylum procedure:

Right of asylum – Article 16a of the Basic Law (GG):

  • Residence permit for 3 years
  • Settlement permit possible after 3 years at the earliest (prerequisites are checked individually)
  • unlimited labour market access
  • Entitlement to family reunion

Granting asylum/refugee status § 3 German Asylum Law (AsylG):

  • Residence permit for 3 years (thereafter extension under certain circumstances)
  • Settlement permit possible after 3 years at the earliest (prerequisites are checked individually)
