Granting subsidiary protection § 4 German Asylum Law (AsylG):

  • Residence permit for 1 year (2 more years for each extension)
  • Settlement permit possible after 5 years at the earliest (prerequisites are checked individually)
  • Employment permitted, self-employment only with permission from foreigners authority
  • Possibility of family reunification to be examined individually

Determination of a national ban on deportation § 60 (5) and (7) Residence Act (AufenthG):

  • Residence permit for 1 year (with extension for 1 further year each)
  • Settlement permit possible after 5 years at the earliest (prerequisites are checked individually)
  • Employment possible with permission from the foreigners authority
  • Family reunion not possible

An asylum application was rejected? There are two types of rejection:

  1. The asylum application is rejected as inadmissiblebecause another country is responsible for processing the asylum application (Dublin procedure). This is the case if you have already applied for asylum in a different country or had your fingerprints taken there. Deportation to this country is threatened (example: Italy).
  2. The asylum application is rejected (national procedure). Deportation to your country of origin will be imposed.

In these two cases, you are legally obliged to leave Germany and must leave again. As long as your deportation is not possible, you will be granted a " Duldung“ (toleration) under certain circumstances. A Duldung is not a residence title. The Regional Council is responsible for tolerated persons. They also oversee and carry out deportation.

What can I do if I do not want to be deported but no longer have any options to stay in Germany?

If you decide to leave voluntarily, you can receive financial support for your new start in your home country.

title: Subsequent accommodation (Anschlussunterbringung)
excerpt:
You will be placed in follow-up accommodation if you have lived in a shared accommodation for more than two years or your asylum procedure has been legally concludedor you have received a residence permit. In the case of follow-up accommodation, you will move out of the shared accommodation and into accommodation in a city or municipality of the Rems-Murr district. from this point on, you can also move into your own flat   . 
If you are no longer in temporary accommodation but in follow-up accommodation or already live in your own flat in the district, the integration managementwill help you. The integration management can help you with questions about kindergarten, school, work, training, language courses, residence, family and with problems. You can find the contacts for this under cities and municipalities.
content:
You will be placed in follow-up accommodation if you have lived in a shared accommodation for more than two years or your asylum procedure has been legally concludedor you have received a residence permit. In the case of follow-up accommodation, you will move out of the shared accommodation and into accommodation in a city or municipality of the Rems-Murr district. from this point on, you can also move into your own flat   . 

If you are no longer in temporary accommodation but in follow-up accommodation or already live in your own flat in the district, the integration managementwill help you. The integration management can help you with questions about kindergarten, school, work, training, language courses, residence, family and with problems. You can find the contacts for this under cities and municipalities.

title: Residence permit
excerpt:
Here you will find an overview of the seven residence permits in Germany
Frequently asked questions are answered here by the Ministry of the Interior.
On the Baden-Württemberg service portal you will find further basic information, online applications, information on the procedure and information on the required documents and costs.
content:
Here you will find an overview of the seven residence permits in Germany

Frequently asked questions are answered here by the Ministry of the Interior.

On the Baden-Württemberg service portal you will find further basic information, online applications, information on the procedure and information on the required documents and costs.

title: Residence permit
excerpt:
The residence permit can be granted for various reasons, for example for humanitarian or family reasons or after a positive asylum decision.
Duration: Limited in time
The residence permit (Aufenthaltserlaubnis) grants temporary residence. It is always earmarked.
It forms the basis for legal residence and opens up the possibility of a subsequent permanent right of residence (settlement permit).Some residence permits allow unrestricted access to the labour market without a work permit from the “Bundesagentur für Arbeit” (Federal Employment Agency).
Other residence permits require the approval of the Federal Agency. Every residence permit states the extent to which work is permitted.
Here you will find the applications to apply for or extend a residence permit:
 Application for a residence permit / EU Blue Card (PDF file)
 Application for a residence permit for a child under 16 (PDF file)
  Application for extension of a residence permit / EU Blue Card (PDF file)
 Application for extension of a residence permit for a child under 16 (PDF file)
content:
The residence permit can be granted for various reasons, for example for humanitarian or family reasons or after a positive asylum decision.

Duration: Limited in time

The residence permit (Aufenthaltserlaubnis) grants temporary residence. It is always earmarked.

It forms the basis for legal residence and opens up the possibility of a subsequent permanent right of residence (settlement permit).
Some residence permits allow unrestricted access to the labour market without a work permit from the “Bundesagentur für Arbeit” (Federal Employment Agency).

Other residence permits require the approval of the Federal Agency. Every residence permit states the extent to which work is permitted.

Here you will find the applications to apply for or extend a residence permit:

Application for a residence permit / EU Blue Card (PDF file)

Application for a residence permit for a child under 16 (PDF file)

  Application for extension of a residence permit / EU Blue Card (PDF file)

Application for extension of a residence permit for a child under 16 (PDF file)

title: Probationary permit (Fiktionsbescheinigung)
excerpt:
Duration: Limited in time
A fictitious certificate is issued if a decision on an applied-for residence title cannot yet be made, for example because:

an ordered electronic residence title (eAT) cannot yet be issued before the expiry of the previous residence title,
Documents are missing or the alien's file is not available or
the outcome of criminal proceedings must be awaited.
content:
Duration: Limited in time

A fictitious certificate is issued if a decision on an applied-for residence title cannot yet be made, for example because:

  • an ordered electronic residence title (eAT) cannot yet be issued before the expiry of the previous residence title,
  • Documents are missing or the alien's file is not available or
  • the outcome of criminal proceedings must be awaited.

title: EU Blue Card
excerpt:
Duration: 

maximum of 4 years for permanent employment contracts
for fixed-term employment contracts: duration of the contract + 3 months

Group of persons: 
The Blue Card is only valid for:

Skilled workers with a German university degree
Recognised foreign university degree 
A comparable foreign university degree.

With the EU Blue Card, third-country nationals can obtain a residence permit in EU member states for the purpose of employment appropriate to their qualifications.
Prerequisites:

Concrete job offer that corresponds to the qualification
Professional licence (for regulated professions)
Annual gross salary of at least two thirds of the annual contribution assessment ceiling in the general pension insurance scheme
In certain occupational groups, the required salary limit applies (for example: for medical practitioners, specialists in engineering, natural sciences and mathematics as well as in IT). In such cases, the approval of the Federal Employment Agency is required.

After 33 months (A1 oral), holders of an EU Blue Card can obtain a settlement permit. If language skills are already at level B1, the settlement permit can be issued after just 21 months.
 Further information in several languages
content:
Duration:

  • maximum of 4 years for permanent employment contracts
  • for fixed-term employment contracts: duration of the contract + 3 months

Group of persons:

The Blue Card is only valid for:

  • Skilled workers with a German university degree
  • Recognised foreign university degree
  • A comparable foreign university degree.

With the EU Blue Card, third-country nationals can obtain a residence permit in EU member states for the purpose of employment appropriate to their qualifications.

Prerequisites:

  • Concrete job offer that corresponds to the qualification
  • Professional licence (for regulated professions)
  • Annual gross salary of at least two thirds of the annual contribution assessment ceiling in the general pension insurance scheme
  • In certain occupational groups, the required salary limit applies (for example: for medical practitioners, specialists in engineering, natural sciences and mathematics as well as in IT). In such cases, the approval of the Federal Employment Agency is required.

After 33 months (A1 oral), holders of an EU Blue Card can obtain a settlement permit. If language skills are already at level B1, the settlement permit can be issued after just 21 months.

Further information in several languages

title: ICT card
excerpt:
Duration: limited in time
Group of persons: For the purpose of intra-company secondment, the Residence Act offers third-country nationals the opportunity to work exclusively in a German branch of their company as part of the transfer.
However, this only applies to managers or specialists of the receiving branch or to trainees.
 You can find further information in several languages here.
content:
Duration: limited in time

Group of persons: For the purpose of intra-company secondment, the Residence Act offers third-country nationals the opportunity to work exclusively in a German branch of their company as part of the transfer.

However, this only applies to managers or specialists of the receiving branch or to trainees.

You can find further information in several languages here.

title: Mobile ICT card
excerpt:
Duration: limited in time
Group of persons: Third-country nationals who already hold a residence permit in accordance with the ICT Directive for an EU member state and are planning a longer stay (over 90 days) in Germany can apply for a separate residence permit, the Mobile ICT Card, for this purpose.
Only applies if the person is working as a manager, specialist or trainee.
content:
Duration: limited in time

Group of persons: Third-country nationals who already hold a residence permit in accordance with the ICT Directive for an EU member state and are planning a longer stay (over 90 days) in Germany can apply for a separate residence permit, the Mobile ICT Card, for this purpose.

Only applies if the person is working as a manager, specialist or trainee.

title: Permanent residence permit - EU
excerpt:
Duration: unlimited
Group of persons: Third-country nationals are entitled to a settlement permit if they have been in possession of a residence permit for five years and fulfil the other legal requirements for a  settlement permit .
content:
Duration: unlimited

Group of persons: Third-country nationals are entitled to a settlement permit if they have been in possession of a residence permit for five years and fulfil the other legal requirements for a settlement permit .

title: Settlement permit
excerpt:
Duration: unlimited, validity of the eAT (electronic residence permit) corresponds to the duration of the passport
Authorised for any gainful employment, including self-employment.
Requirements:

Third-country nationals who have resided in Germany for an uninterrupted period of five years with a residence permit
Securing their livelihood (securing their livelihood)
60 months of pension insurance contributions
Language skills, level B1, AE issued before 01.01.2005: only oral A1 skills required
Knowledge of the legal and social order (orientation course)
Sufficient living space (for each family member over the age of six, a living space of at least 12 m² must be demonstrated. For each family member between the ages of two and six, 10m² should be sufficient; children aged 0-2 are not included)
Secured livelihood: Your livelihood is secured if you can cover your living expenses and sufficient health insurance cover without recourse to public funds.

Special standard:
Settlement permit (§ 26 (3) AufenthG) for persons entitled to asylum and refugees under the Geneva Refugee Convention
The settlement permit is issued after three years if the following requirements are met:

The German language is "mastered" (C1)
The livelihood is largely secured (at least 75%)
The BAMF has not notified you in accordance with Section 73 (2a) of the Asylum Act that the conditions for revocation or withdrawal have been met
Basic knowledge of the legal and social order and living conditions in Germany (orientation course)
Sufficient living space (see above)

After 5 years, the settlement permit will be issued if the following requirements are met:

Sufficient knowledge of the German language (A2)
The livelihood is predominantly secured (at least 51%)
There are no requirements for revocation or cancellation of the asylum decision
Orientation course
Sufficient living space (see above)
content:
Duration: unlimited, validity of the eAT (electronic residence permit) corresponds to the duration of the passport

Authorised for any gainful employment, including self-employment.

Requirements:

  • Third-country nationals who have resided in Germany for an uninterrupted period of five years with a residence permit
  • Securing their livelihood (securing their livelihood)
  • 60 months of pension insurance contributions
  • Language skills, level B1, AE issued before 01.01.2005: only oral A1 skills required
  • Knowledge of the legal and social order (orientation course)
  • Sufficient living space (for each family member over the age of six, a living space of at least 12 m² must be demonstrated. For each family member between the ages of two and six, 10m² should be sufficient; children aged 0-2 are not included)
  • Secured livelihood: Your livelihood is secured if you can cover your living expenses and sufficient health insurance cover without recourse to public funds.

Special standard:

Settlement permit (§ 26 (3) AufenthG) for persons entitled to asylum and refugees under the Geneva Refugee Convention

The settlement permit is issued after three years if the following requirements are met:

  • The German language is "mastered" (C1)
  • The livelihood is largely secured (at least 75%)
  • The BAMF has not notified you in accordance with Section 73 (2a) of the Asylum Act that the conditions for revocation or withdrawal have been met
  • Basic knowledge of the legal and social order and living conditions in Germany (orientation course)
  • Sufficient living space (see above)

After 5 years, the settlement permit will be issued if the following requirements are met:

  • Sufficient knowledge of the German language (A2)
  • The livelihood is predominantly secured (at least 51%)
  • There are no requirements for revocation or cancellation of the asylum decision
  • Orientation course
  • Sufficient living space (see above)

title: Toleration (§60a)
excerpt:
Duration: Limited in timeStatus: ToleratedBackground: Negative asylum decision, obligation to leave the country
A "Duldung" is a temporary postponement of deportation and is not legal residence. This document is only granted if deportation is impossible for legal, practical, humanitarian or personal reasons at the moment.
A work permit is generally required. It is applied for at the Aliens' Registration Office  of your place of residence. Here, too, you have to fill in applications with the help of the employer. Your social worker will help you.
The Agentur für Arbeit (Federal Employment Agency) is responsible for the placement in work.
content:
Duration: Limited in time
Status: Tolerated
Background: Negative asylum decision, obligation to leave the country

A "Duldung" is a temporary postponement of deportation and is not legal residence. This document is only granted if deportation is impossible for legal, practical, humanitarian or personal reasons at the moment.

A work permit is generally required. It is applied for at the Aliens' Registration Office  of your place of residence. Here, too, you have to fill in applications with the help of the employer. Your social worker will help you.

The Agentur für Arbeit (Federal Employment Agency) is responsible for the placement in work.

title: Toleration for persons with unclear identity (§60b)
excerpt:
Duration: Limited in timeStatus: ToleratedBackground: Issued if deportation cannot be carried out due to identity deception and lack of cooperation in clarifying identity and obtaining a passport 
The following always applies:

Work ban and residence requirement
Benefit cuts
As a rule, compulsory residence (you are not allowed to leave a certain place)

Note:

Periods with this toleration are NOT counted as periods of stay for possible rights to stay/training/employment toleration
If the holder makes up for this participation, a "normal" toleration according to § 60a AufenthG is granted again

If you are thinking of returning to your home country, you can contact the return counselling service. 
ContactIf you have any questions about the Duldung, please contact the foreigners authorityresponsible for you.
content:
Duration: Limited in time
Status: Tolerated
Background: Issued if deportation cannot be carried out due to identity deception and lack of cooperation in clarifying identity and obtaining a passport 

The following always applies:

  • Work ban and residence requirement
  • Benefit cuts
  • As a rule, compulsory residence (you are not allowed to leave a certain place)

Note:

  • Periods with this toleration are NOT counted as periods of stay for possible rights to stay/training/employment toleration
  • If the holder makes up for this participation, a "normal" toleration according to § 60a AufenthG is granted again

If you are thinking of returning to your home country, you can contact the return counselling service.

Contact
If you have any questions about the Duldung, please contact the foreigners authorityresponsible for you.

title: Training toleration (§60c)
excerpt:
Duration: "Guaranteed" suspension of deportation for the duration of vocational trainingPerspective: The transition to a residence permit after successful completion of the training is possible, provided that the requirements are then met.
For whom is toleration of vocational training possible?

Tolerated persons (§ 60a AufenthG) who have already started training during the asylum procedure
Tolerated persons who want to start an apprenticeship: these persons must have been in possession of a toleration certificate according to § 60a for three months

In order to get a vocational training tolerance, you have to submit the training contract to the “Regierungspräsidium” (Regional Council). The application via the Foreigners' Registration Office is made with additional documents.
Requirements:

Qualified vocational training: Training in a state-recognised or comparably regulated training occupation
Standard training duration at least two years
In the case of training for assistants or helpers, qualified training in a so-called bottleneck occupation must be able to be followed up and a training place commitment must be available for this (e.g. geriatric care and nursing assistance)
The registration of the vocational training in the register of vocational training relationships is usually kept by the IHK or HWK.
clarified identity

The clarified identity may be waived if all reasonable and necessary steps to clarify the identity have been taken within the respective applicable time limit and the identity is/was still not clarified. The Regierungspräsidium decides whether the postponement of deportation due to vocational training (Ausbildungsduldung) is granted despite the unclear identity.
With an introductory qualification (EQ), you do not get a training permit (Ausbildungsduldung). But the EQ, i.e. a longer internship in a company, still offers advantages: Preparation for vocational training and the possibility of an accompanying language course!
Contact
If you have any questions, please contact the foreigners authorityresponsible for you.
content:
Duration: "Guaranteed" suspension of deportation for the duration of vocational training
Perspective: The transition to a residence permit after successful completion of the training is possible, provided that the requirements are then met.

For whom is toleration of vocational training possible?

  • Tolerated persons (§ 60a AufenthG) who have already started training during the asylum procedure
  • Tolerated persons who want to start an apprenticeship: these persons must have been in possession of a toleration certificate according to § 60a for three months

In order to get a vocational training tolerance, you have to submit the training contract to the “Regierungspräsidium” (Regional Council). The application via the Foreigners' Registration Office is made with additional documents.

Requirements:

  • Qualified vocational training: Training in a state-recognised or comparably regulated training occupation
  • Standard training duration at least two years
  • In the case of training for assistants or helpers, qualified training in a so-called bottleneck occupation must be able to be followed up and a training place commitment must be available for this (e.g. geriatric care and nursing assistance)
  • The registration of the vocational training in the register of vocational training relationships is usually kept by the IHK or HWK.
  • clarified identity

The clarified identity may be waived if all reasonable and necessary steps to clarify the identity have been taken within the respective applicable time limit and the identity is/was still not clarified. The Regierungspräsidium decides whether the postponement of deportation due to vocational training (Ausbildungsduldung) is granted despite the unclear identity.

With an introductory qualification (EQ), you do not get a training permit (Ausbildungsduldung). But the EQ, i.e. a longer internship in a company, still offers advantages: Preparation for vocational training and the possibility of an accompanying language course!

Contact

If you have any questions, please contact the foreigners authorityresponsible for you.

title: Employment toleration (§60d)
excerpt:
Duration: 30 months, currently limited until 31.12.2023Status: only applies to persons who entered the country before 01.08.2018; also applies to spouses or partners and unmarried minor children living in the familyPerspective: after 30 months, a residence permit can be issued in accordance with Section 25b (1) of the Residence Act, provided that the requirements are met.
Requirements:

12 months in possession of a toleration certificate (60a, NOT 60b!)
Employment subject to social insurance for at least 18 months and
regular weekly working hours of at least 35 hours for at least 18 months (at least 20 hours for single parents) andliving wage through employment for at least 12 months + Employment currently and still secured
German A2 oral
no conviction for intentional crime
no relations to extremist or terrorist organisations
no deportation order and no deportation order according to § 58a AufenthG
successful completion of the integration course of the applicant or the spouse, if one was obligatory
Proof of school attendance of minor children
clarified identity

Contact
If you have any questions, please contact the foreigners authorityresponsible for you.
content:
Duration: 30 months, currently limited until 31.12.2023
Status: only applies to persons who entered the country before 01.08.2018; also applies to spouses or partners and unmarried minor children living in the family
Perspective: after 30 months, a residence permit can be issued in accordance with Section 25b (1) of the Residence Act, provided that the requirements are met.

Requirements:

  • 12 months in possession of a toleration certificate (60a, NOT 60b!)
  • Employment subject to social insurance for at least 18 months and
  • regular weekly working hours of at least 35 hours for at least 18 months (at least 20 hours for single parents) and
    living wage through employment for at least 12 months + Employment currently and still secured
  • German A2 oral
  • no conviction for intentional crime
  • no relations to extremist or terrorist organisations
  • no deportation order and no deportation order according to § 58a AufenthG
  • successful completion of the integration course of the applicant or the spouse, if one was obligatory
  • Proof of school attendance of minor children
  • clarified identity

Contact

If you have any questions, please contact the foreigners authorityresponsible for you.

title: Opportunities Residence Act
excerpt:
Since 31 December 2022, the new opportunity residence law applies. Those who have been living in Germany on a tolerated basis for many years can now obtain a permanent right to stay more quickly.
The prerequisites for the new right of residence are:

Possession of a toleration
5 years without interruption with permit, residence permit or toleration in Germany as of 31.10.2022 (entry before 31.10.2017)
No offences
No false statements or deception about identity
Commitment to the free democratic basic order

Note: The opportunity stay is only granted for 18 months. It is not renewable. 
What happens afterwards:
The persons concerned receive a residence permit for 18 months. During this time, they are given the chance to fulfil the requirements for a permanent right to stay in Germany. This requires that they:

can predominantly secure their livelihood through gainful employment,
have proof of identity,
can demonstrate a good knowledge of the German language.

ContactIf you have any questions about the Opportunities Residence Act, please contact the foreigners authorityresponsible for you.
Further information from the Federal Government can be found here.
Handbook Germany
content:
Since 31 December 2022, the new opportunity residence law applies. Those who have been living in Germany on a tolerated basis for many years can now obtain a permanent right to stay more quickly.

The prerequisites for the new right of residence are:

  • Possession of a toleration
  • 5 years without interruption with permit, residence permit or toleration in Germany as of 31.10.2022 (entry before 31.10.2017)
  • No offences
  • No false statements or deception about identity
  • Commitment to the free democratic basic order

Note: The opportunity stay is only granted for 18 months. It is not renewable. 

What happens afterwards:

The persons concerned receive a residence permit for 18 months. During this time, they are given the chance to fulfil the requirements for a permanent right to stay in Germany. This requires that they:

  • can predominantly secure their livelihood through gainful employment,
  • have proof of identity,
  • can demonstrate a good knowledge of the German language.

Contact
If you have any questions about the Opportunities Residence Act, please contact the foreigners authorityresponsible for you.

Further information from the Federal Government can be found here.

Handbook Germany

title: Return Counselling
excerpt: If you want to return to your home country due to your rejected asylum procedure, you can find help here.
content: If you want to return to your home country due to your rejected asylum procedure, you can find help here.

title: A visa
excerpt:
Duration: Limited in time
Only for entry into Germany
Group of people: Nationals of a Member State of the European Union may enter Germany without a visa. Foreigners from other countries of origin almost all require a visa.
content:
Duration: Limited in time

Only for entry into Germany

Group of people: Nationals of a Member State of the European Union may enter Germany without a visa. Foreigners from other countries of origin almost all require a visa.

title: Reuniting Families
excerpt:
Do you and your family members not live in the same place or do you still have family members abroad?
Then, depending on the  residence status , there are different ways to reunite the family.
If you already have a residence permit for purposes other than humanitarian reasons or if you are German, you can find more information at the Baden-Württemberg service portal. 
Family reunion
If you live in Germany and already have a residence permit for humanitarian reasons, you may be able to bring direct family members (parents, children, spouse) from abroad. This is only possible if you have been granted refugee status by the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF; Bundesamt für Migration und Flüchtlinge).
To do this you must

file atimely report within 3 months of receiving your decision from the BAMF.
Your family members who are to join you in Germany must apply for a visa at the German mission abroad (e.g. embassy or consulate) in the respective country of their stay.

Where can I file a complaint within the time limit?
On the website of the German Foreign Office, the procedure for family reunification is explained to you and you can also directly file the timely application. You can also find information on the page of the Integration Commissioner. 
You can also get more information on family reunification at the responsible Bureau for Foreigners (Ausländerbehörde).
You can also get support for family reunification at the migration counselling centre of Caritas in the Rems-Murr district:
 Migration counselling for adult immigrants 
Contact details for migration counselling can be found here. 
Family reunion
If you come to Germany as an asylum seeker, you will be assigned to a specific district in Germany (for example, the Rems-Murr district). As a general rule, you must live there at least until the end of your asylum procedure.
Moving to be with family or for a job
However, under certain circumstances, you can change the location. For example, if immediate family members (children, spouse, domestic partner, or parents) reside in other counties. In order to be able to move in with your family, you must submit a  application for reallocation to the competent foreigners authority. If this application is approved, you may move.
If you already have a residence permit (Aufenthaltserlaubnis) and you get a condition of fixed abode (Wohnsitzauflage), you must look for an apartment within the specified location.
If you want to move to another place, you must also submita redistribution application or an application for cancellation of the residence requirement to the responsible foreigners authority. This is possible, for example, because of a relationship or a job. 
The application must be approved by the receiving immigration authority of the county or municipality to which you wish to move.
content:
Do you and your family members not live in the same place or do you still have family members abroad?

Then, depending on the  residence status , there are different ways to reunite the family.

If you already have a residence permit for purposes other than humanitarian reasons or if you are German, you can find more information at the Baden-Württemberg service portal.

Family reunion

If you live in Germany and already have a residence permit for humanitarian reasons, you may be able to bring direct family members (parents, children, spouse) from abroad. This is only possible if you have been granted refugee status by the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF; Bundesamt für Migration und Flüchtlinge).

To do this you must

  1. file atimely report within 3 months of receiving your decision from the BAMF.
  2. Your family members who are to join you in Germany must apply for a visa at the German mission abroad (e.g. embassy or consulate) in the respective country of their stay.

Where can I file a complaint within the time limit?

On the website of the German Foreign Office, the procedure for family reunification is explained to you and you can also directly file the timely application. You can also find information on the page of the Integration Commissioner.

You can also get more information on family reunification at the responsible Bureau for Foreigners (Ausländerbehörde).

You can also get support for family reunification at the migration counselling centre of Caritas in the Rems-Murr district:

Migration counselling for adult immigrants 

Contact details for migration counselling can be found here. 

Family reunion

If you come to Germany as an asylum seeker, you will be assigned to a specific district in Germany (for example, the Rems-Murr district). As a general rule, you must live there at least until the end of your asylum procedure.

Moving to be with family or for a job

However, under certain circumstances, you can change the location. For example, if immediate family members (children, spouse, domestic partner, or parents) reside in other counties. In order to be able to move in with your family, you must submit a  application for reallocation to the competent foreigners authority. If this application is approved, you may move.

If you already have a residence permit (Aufenthaltserlaubnis) and you get a condition of fixed abode (Wohnsitzauflage), you must look for an apartment within the specified location.

If you want to move to another place, you must also submita redistribution application or an application for cancellation of the residence requirement to the responsible foreigners authority. This is possible, for example, because of a relationship or a job.

The application must be approved by the receiving immigration authority of the county or municipality to which you wish to move.

title: EU migrants and ethnic repatriates
excerpt:
EU migrants
If you are a citizen of a member state of the EU, you can in principle enter Germany legally and live and work there (Freedom of Movement Act).You must then register at the Residents' Registration Office responsible for you (locally in the municipality/city hall). You will need a valid identity card or a valid passport from your country of origin.
Note: If you do not work, you may not be entitled to social benefits in Germany for the first 5 years of your stay. Here it is important that you make an appointment for counselling with the Job Centre  .
You can find more information here.
A brochure of the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) in German, English and other languages can be found here.

Late repatriates
After you have received your entry form in your country of origin, you may enter Germany.There, you will be assigned to a district by the Federal Office of Administration in Friedland (for example, the Rems-Murr district) and accommodated by it if you cannot find a private flat.
You can find more information here.
You can find a Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) brochure in German and Russian here.

You can find more information here.

A brochure of the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) in German, English and other languages can be found here.

Late repatriates

After you have received your entry form in your country of origin, you may enter Germany.

title: Naturalisation
excerpt:
If you live permanently in Germany, you can apply for naturalisation under certain conditions.You must submit a request for this. From your 16th birthday You can make this application yourself on your birthday. For children and youth under 16, the parents must submit the application.
You can obtain application forms from the competent naturalisation authorities. In the Rems-Murr district, the naturalisation authority of the district is responsible for naturalisation applications. You can also find all important information and forms here.

title: What are the language levels?
excerpt:
The levels
The basic levels are:
A: Elementary language skillsB: Independent language skillsC: Competent language skills
These three levels are further subdivided into two levels each. A detailed description of the knowledge behind each level can be found in the following table:
Level:
A1Can understand and use familiar everyday expressions and very basic phrases. This includes, for example, the question and answer regarding the place of residence.
A2The person is able to understand sentences and frequently used expressions related to the essential aspects of everyday life. This includes, for example, the description of your own job or training.
B1The person understands the most important contents when using a clear standard language when dealing with familiar matters at work, school or leisure. This enables the person to express themselves in a simple and coherent way about familiar topics and personal areas of interest, for example, about what goals the person is pursuing.
B2The person is able to understand the most important contents of complex texts and also understands technical discussions in his/her own special field, for example, in vocational school. The person is able to communicate so spontaneously and fluently that a conversation with native speakers is easily possible without much effort on either side.
C1The person understands a wide range of demanding, longer texts and can also perceive implicit meanings that are not expressed openly. In addition, the person is able to speak spontaneously and fluently - for example at work - and to express himself or herself on complex topics.
C2The person can understand practically everything he or she reads and hears without effort. They can express themselves spontaneously, very fluently and precisely.
Further information at: europaeischer-referenzrahmen.de
content:
The levels

The basic levels are:

A: Elementary language skills
B: Independent language skills
C: Competent language skills

These three levels are further subdivided into two levels each. A detailed description of the knowledge behind each level can be found in the following table:

Level:

A1
Can understand and use familiar everyday expressions and very basic phrases. This includes, for example, the question and answer regarding the place of residence.

A2
The person is able to understand sentences and frequently used expressions related to the essential aspects of everyday life. This includes, for example, the description of your own job or training.

B1
The person understands the most important contents when using a clear standard language when dealing with familiar matters at work, school or leisure. This enables the person to express themselves in a simple and coherent way about familiar topics and personal areas of interest, for example, about what goals the person is pursuing.

B2
The person is able to understand the most important contents of complex texts and also understands technical discussions in his/her own special field, for example, in vocational school. The person is able to communicate so spontaneously and fluently that a conversation with native speakers is easily possible without much effort on either side.

C1
The person understands a wide range of demanding, longer texts and can also perceive implicit meanings that are not expressed openly. In addition, the person is able to speak spontaneously and fluently - for example at work - and to express himself or herself on complex topics.

C2
The person can understand practically everything he or she reads and hears without effort. They can express themselves spontaneously, very fluently and precisely.

Further information at: europaeischer-referenzrahmen.de

title: Integration Courses
excerpt:
The integration course consists of a language course and an orientation course. In the language course you will learn German up to language level B1 in 600 teaching units.  In the subsequent orientation course, you will gain insights into the culture, politics and social customs in Germany. There are also special forms of the integration course, which in some instances include more or fewer teaching units. The integration course with literacy and the subsequent orientation course, for example, comprise 1000 teaching units.
Who is the language course for?

Foreigners with a permanent residence permit. You received your residence permit more than one year ago or have held it for more than 18 months (worker, family reunification, humanitarian reasons, long-term resident).
Late repatriates
Asylum seekers with a residence permit according to §55 par.
Foreigners with a tolerated stay in accordance with § 60 a para. 2 sentence 3 AufenthG.
Foreigners with a training permit pursuant to § 60c para. 1 or an employment permit pursuant to § 60d para. 1 AufenthG
Foreigners with a residence permit according to §24 or § 25 Para. 5 AufenthG.
Foreigners with a residence permit according to §25b (§ 104c AufenthG - "right of residence of opportunity")
EU citizens 
German nationals who do not yet speak sufficient German or who are particularly in need of integration.

What types of language courses are available?
There are different forms of integration course. Which ones are available can be found here.

General integration course
Literacy courses
Integration course for secondary learners
Youth integration course
Women's integration course
Parent integration course
Intensive course
Integration course for people with disabilities

What does the language course cost?
Integration courses are free of chargefor refugees and asylum seekers . The course is also free of charge for other people in the target group who receive social benefits. These persons need an application for this.
Further forms on costs and participation (e.g. application for travel allowance) are available here.
When and where do the language courses take place?
There are full-time courses and part-time courses. In principle, the integration course is offered full-time.  If you are working, it is possible to attend the course in the afternoon or evening.
You can find local counselling centres and integration courses here.
You can find integration course providers here.
How can I register?Here you can find the application forms.
The application for the integration course for asylum seekers, tolerated persons and foreigners with a residence permit according to §24 and § 25 Abs. 5 AufenthG can be found here.
Send the completed applications to the competent regional office of the BAMF. 
If you need assistance with the application, contact the social care or integration manager, the migration counselling centre or the youth migration service. You can find more information here.

title: Vocational Language Courses (DeuFöV)
excerpt:
Job-related German courses help to further improve one's German skills, for example after having already attended an integration course. You can attend the so-called DeuFöV courses while you are working, undergoing training or a vocational qualification measure or as preparation for starting a career in Germany.
The basic structure of the professional language courses is the basic course. A basic distinction is made between three types: B1 to B2, B2 to C1 and C1 to C2. The modules each comprise 300 teaching units.
However, there are also special modules that only require speaking level A2 or B1. Additional special modules are specifically adapted to specific occupational groups.
Who can participate?You must meet the following requirements to participate in the professional language course:

They have a migration background and a need for further language training. This is the case with immigrants from third countries, EU citizens and Germans with a migration background.
You have already completed an integration course and/or already speak German at A1, A2, B1, B2 or C1 level according to the Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR) for languages. In order to attend courses with a target language level below B2, prior attendance of an integration course with a passed and failed German test for immigrants is required.
You must be registered as a job seeker and/or usually receive benefits according to SGB II ("Hartz IV") or SGB III (unemployment benefit).
You are looking for a training position or are already in training.
You are currently going through the recognition procedure for your vocational qualification or training certificate. 

Participation as an employeeIf you are already in employment, you can take part in the professional language course. The prerequisite is that you do not yet have sufficient language skills to master your future everyday working life.
Cost of participationParticipation in the professional language course is generally free of charge. If your taxable annual income is over €20,000, you pay a cost contribution of €2.42 per teaching unit (50 per cent of the cost reimbursement rate). This is a total of 1,452 € for a course with 600 teaching units. The payment of the cost contribution can also be made by the employer.
Upon successful completion of the examination, a refund of 50 per cent of the cost contribution can be applied for.
EligibilityAs a rule, the employment agencies and job centresdecide on eligibility. Contact your counsellor here. They will also know which language schools offer courses and whether special courses are possible for you.
If you are already working or in a training relationship or in the recognition procedure and do not receive benefits under SGB II or SGB III, you can apply directly to the BAMF for entitlement to participate.
Here you can search for relevant courses in the Rems-Murr district.

title: VwV German Language Courses
excerpt:
For people who are not allowed to take part in the integration course, the state of Baden-Württemberg has set up a special programme with the VwV Deutsch. The courses build on the respective language level and lead to the next higher language level (for example from A1 to A2). Each course usually consists of 300 lessons and lasts about 4-5 months. The special courses, such as literacy courses, take a little longer.
Costs
The course is free of charge for participants. Travel costs can be covered by the District Office on a pro-rata basis if required.

title: Voluntary language courses
excerpt:
In addition to the official German courses, there are many opportunities to practise German in most municipalities.The groups are led by volunteers. These are usually people whose mother tongue is German. Sometimes they are teachers who are no longer working. These groups are often open to anyone, regardless of their residence status.
You can find an overview of the voluntary language programmes in the Rems-Murr district here.

The groups are led by volunteers. These are usually people whose mother tongue is German. Sometimes they are teachers who are no longer working. These groups are often open to anyone, regardless of their residence status.

You can find an overview of the voluntary language programmes in the Rems-Murr district here.

title: Learn German independently
excerpt:
You can, of course, also learn German independently – without attending a course or in addition to a course. Your Support Network can support your learning.  Librariesare an important place to learn German independently. Learning in the library and using the WLAN and internet PCs are free of charge.
 
Online services
There are also free offers on the internet to learn German:
The Goethe Institut has a free online offer with exercises for German at work. The exercises are specially adapted to certain job categories.
The radio station Deutsche Welle offers online language exercises that work with video contributions and series. They are adapted for language levels A1 to C and offer an entertaining complement to other German courses.
VHS- Lernportal
For immigrants who want to learn the German language quickly and without bureaucratic hurdles, the German Adult Education Association (DVV) has now put a free learning offer online. The learning portal is available at vhs-lernportal.de and can be run on all common end devices.

title: Certified interpreters
excerpt:
You will need an interpreter for many visits to the authorities, such as the Aliens' Registration Office, the Social Welfare Office and the Education Office, but also for visits to the doctor, parents' evenings at school or kindergarten. 
If you need an interpreter, go to your social care or integration management. If possible, they will arrange for a suitable interpreter to accompany you to your appointment. All requests will be treated in the strictest confidence. Please note that interpreters do not offer professional or legal advice or legal representation.
Translation of documentsOfficial documents such as certificates, marriage or birth certificates may only be transmitted in Germany by state-certified translators. These translations can be costly. It is best to check carefully beforehand whether you really need a certified translation.
Here you will find a selection of certified interpreters:
All languages:

title: Adult education centres
excerpt:
The adult education centre is an institution for adult education and further education. The courses offered by adult education centres consist of courses of various durations, usually between 1 and 15 weeks. As a rule, it is open to anyone aged 16 and over. There are courses that are tailored to the needs of working people.
There are the following locations in the Rems-Murr district :

title: Other Training and Education Programmes
excerpt:
Basic education
There are many people living in Germany who are not or not fully literate.  They lack important basic skills in reading, writing and arithmetic. It is therefore difficult for you to participate in everyday life.
That is why the Volkshochschule unteres Remstal offers certain courses on this topic.
 Basic education

EasyUni
The inclusive offer of "EasyUni" is aimed at everyone. People with and without disabilities can learn and be creative together here.  Complex topicsare explained here in simple language.
  Offers

title: Childcare from 0-6 years (until joining school)
excerpt:
You can have your child cared for in a day care centre or in day care facility. As a rule, your child can be looked after from 6 months of age. Your child can stay at the day care centre until he or she starts school. This is usually at the age of 6.
You can find more information on this page.
content:
You can have your child cared for in a day care centre or in day care facility. As a rule, your child can be looked after from 6 months of age. Your child can stay at the day care centre until he or she starts school. This is usually at the age of 6.

You can find more information on this page.

title: Day care centre/kindergarten
excerpt:
What is a day care centre?
Before your child goes to school, they can attend a day care centre. There are carers there who look after your child and support their development. They are like teachers at school.
Day care centre is a collective term for various forms of childcare. It is often just called a "day care centre ". If your child is 1-3 years old, the daycare centre is called a "crèche". The crèche is often integrated into a daycare centre. If your child is 3-6 years old (until they start school), the daycare centre is called a " kindergarten". The kindergarten is also called "Kiga" or "Kindi".
From the age of 1, your child has the right to attend a day-care centre or day-care facility.
Attending a day care centre/kindergarten/crèche is voluntary and costs money.
Here you can find a multilingual video about daycare centres.
Why is a day care centre good for my child?
At the daycare centre, your child can play with other children, make friends and learn lots of new things. They will also learn the German language here. At the day care centre, children learn while they play.
The day care centre is a very important preparation for school.In the penultimate year and shortly before your child starts school, there is a school enrolment examination.
Here you can find videos about the day care centre in different languages.
How can I enrol my child in the daycare centre?
Ask at the town hall in your municipality how you can enrol your child.
The social counselling/integration manager in the shared accommodation or the migration counselling and youth migration service can also help you to register your child at the kindergarten.
Unfortunately, there are not enough places in all day care centres. It is therefore best to enrol your child several months to a year in advance and have it placed on the waiting list.
When is the daycare centre open?
There are different opening hours.
In day care centres, you can normally have your child looked after from the morning until late in the afternoon. However, there are also kindergartens that are only open until midday (approx. 12:00 or 14:00).
You bring your child to the daycare centre in the morning and pick it up again at lunchtime or in the evening. This depends on how long you have booked. There are fixed times for this. You have to stick to them. This is very important for the children. This allows the carers to support the children undisturbed.Find out more directly from the daycare centre.

Child day care centre
The Child Day Care Centre is the point of contact for families and parents for all questions regarding child day care.
Rems-Murr district office Backnang Kindertagesbetreuung@rems-murr-kreis.de 071918954192 Further information

title: Child day care
excerpt:
What is childminding?
Childminding is the care of children by childminders.
If required, children from 0 to 14 years of age can be looked after by a childminder. The children are looked after in the childminder's home, in their own home or in other rooms. The care takes place in small groups. Day care is a family-like form of childcare. It is mainly used by children under the age of 3. Your child can receive individualised support here.
The childcare hours are agreed flexibly between parents and childminders. It can also supplement childcare in a day care centre.
From the age of 1, your child has the right to attend a daycare centre or childminder.Attending a day care centre/kindergarten/crèche/day care is voluntary and costs money.
How do I find a place with a childminder?
Verein für Kinder- und Jugendhilfe Backnang e.V.responsible for Allmersbach im Tal, Auenwald, Aspach, Backnang, Burgstetten, Großerlach, Kirchberg/M., Murrhardt, Oppenweiler, Sulzbach/M., Spiegelberg and Weissach im Tal

title: Important information for parents
excerpt:
Settling in 
After you have found a place in a day care centre, your child will be "settled in". This is how it works: Mother or father goes to the day care centre together with the child for a while. Together they get to know the teachers, the rooms, the other children and the daily routine.  This way, your child can get used to the new place and you as parents can get used to it as well. That's why it's called "settling in". This is very important in Germany and is something that all parents and children do. The acclimatisationprocess can take two or more weeks.
 Familiarisation video
Parents' meetings 
Normally, two parent meetings take place in one kindergarten year. This applies to all parents and all children. In these conversations, you will be told what the child has learned, what he/she is particularly good at and where he/she should develop further . An interpreter can also come to these appointments so that can everyone understands each other well. Sometimes there are also important issues to discuss outside the regular schedule. You, as parents, can also ask for a meeting if something is bothering you at the day care centre, or if you have something important to say about your child. Then the educators will arrange an appointment with you.
Parents' evening
All parents are invited to a parents' evening. You can exchange ideas with other parents and the educators and get a lot of information. It is good if you take advantage of these meetings. The dates for the parents' evenings are posted in the day-care centre, in the parents' letter or are communicated verbally.
Measles vaccination
Here you can find information about the measles vaccination.

title: Childcare costs
excerpt:
Attending a day care centre or day care facility costs money. You can find out the costs directly from the town hall or the specific facility. Families with several children often receive discounts.
If you do not have a job and receive benefits from the “Landratsamt” (District Office – asylum seeker benefits), the Job Centre or the “Agentur für Arbeit” (Federal Employment Agency), you can get assistance with the costs. To do this, you must submit an application to the YouthWelfareOffice at the District Office(Wirtschaftliche Jugendhilfe).
Click here for the applications and contact details
Often, the day care centre also offers a lunch together. There are also vouchers for this. You must submit an application for Education and participation, or BuT for short at the district administration office
Here you can access the applications of BuT
content:

To do this, you must submit an application to the YouthWelfareOffice at the District Office(Wirtschaftliche Jugendhilfe).

Click here for the applications and contact details

Often, the day care centre also offers a lunch together. There are also vouchers for this. You must submit an application for Education and participation, or BuT for short at the district administration office

title: Compulsory schooling
excerpt:
Compulsory schooling
In Germany, attending school is compulsory. This means that in Germany, all children from the ages of 6 up to (and including) 18 must attend school. The parents or guardians of the children have the duty to ensure that the children attend school.
Compulsory education includes:

participation in classes
participation in the compulsory events of the school
compliance with the school rules

You will be fined for unexcused absence. In the worst case, the police will also visit you. In addition, the “Jugendamt” (Youth Welfare Office) can then also be called in.
 Are you new to Germany?
Your child can go to school from the first day. If you have already been in Germany for 6 months, your child must go to school. School attendance is compulsory after 6 months.
content:
Compulsory schooling

In Germany, attending school is compulsory. This means that in Germany, all children from the ages of 6 up to (and including) 18 must attend school. The parents or guardians of the children have the duty to ensure that the children attend school.

Compulsory education includes:

  • participation in classes
  • participation in the compulsory events of the school
  • compliance with the school rules

You will be fined for unexcused absence. In the worst case, the police will also visit you. In addition, the “Jugendamt” (Youth Welfare Office) can then also be called in.

 Are you new to Germany?

Your child can go to school from the first day. If you have already been in Germany for 6 months, your child must go to school. School attendance is compulsory after 6 months.

title: How do I register my child in a school?
excerpt:
Are you new to Germany?
Your child may go to a school. After 6 months in Germany at the latest, you must register your child at a school.  School attendance is compulsory.
Ask at the city hall which school your child can go to. There are special classes to learn German. You can find more information here.
Have you been in Germany for a while? Your child already attends a day care centre or a primary school?
There are specific days for registration.
You will need the following documents:

Your identity card, birth certificate or proof of arrival
Registration certificate
all documents concerning your child (identity card/passport, birth certificate, school reports, medical certificates, ...)

Please bring your child to school for registration.
School enrolment dates and registration dates at primary schools in Baden-Württemberg:

Baden-Württemberg reference date: End of June. (Your child must be 6 years old by that day)
School enrolment: Beginning of March until end of April
School enrollment: September

You can find information about school enrolment (primary school) here.
Enrolment and registration dates for other schools (secondary schools) in Baden-Württemberg:

Registration dates take place in March.  Check with the school several weeks or months before this date.
Note: For vocational schools, there are other times when you can register. Check with the school early.

You do not know which school your child should go to?
Ask your socialcounselling/integration manager, youth migration counselling or migration counselling.
You can also obtain information at the “Rathaus” (town hall) or directly at the schools in your place of residence.
content:
Are you new to Germany?

Your child may go to a school. After 6 months in Germany at the latest, you must register your child at a school. School attendance is compulsory.

Ask at the city hall which school your child can go to. There are special classes to learn German. You can find more information here.

Have you been in Germany for a while? Your child already attends a day care centre or a primary school?

There are specific days for registration.

You will need the following documents:

  • Your identity card, birth certificate or proof of arrival
  • Registration certificate
  • all documents concerning your child (identity card/passport, birth certificate, school reports, medical certificates, ...)

Please bring your child to school for registration.

School enrolment dates and registration dates at primary schools in Baden-Württemberg:

  • Baden-Württemberg reference date: End of June. (Your child must be 6 years old by that day)
  • School enrolment: Beginning of March until end of April
  • School enrollment: September

You can find information about school enrolment (primary school) here.

Enrolment and registration dates for other schools (secondary schools) in Baden-Württemberg:

  • Registration dates take place in March. Check with the school several weeks or months before this date.
  • Note: For vocational schools, there are other times when you can register. Check with the school early.

You do not know which school your child should go to?

Ask your socialcounselling/integration manager, youth migration counselling or migration counselling.

You can also obtain information at the “Rathaus” (town hall) or directly at the schools in your place of residence.

title: Where can my child be looked after before and after school?
excerpt:
“Verlässliche Grundschule” (a primary school that provides care directly before and after morning lessons)
At the Reliable Primary School, the children are looked after directly before and after lessons. Children can be looked after for up to six hours in the morning. This also includes lessons and breaks. For example, the care can be from 7 AM to 1 PM. However, the Reliable Primary School ends at 2 pm at the latest.
The Reliable Primary School takes place in the school or in rooms next to the school. Most of the time, educators/teachers look after the children during this time. There are often also different activities, for example sports or creative activities.
 If you want your child to attend the Reliable Primary School, you must registerhim or her.The Reliable Primary School costs money.
 Ask at the school or the town hall if there is a Reliable Primary School. Ask there for further information (costs, registration).
Flexible afternoon care
 Flexible after-school care is available at some schools.These are offers in the afternoon. These offers take place at the schools. Flexible afternoon care starts at 12 noon at the earliest and ends at 5:30 PM at the latest.
 If your child is to participate in afternoon care, you must register them.Flexible afternoon care costs money.
 Ask at the school or the town hall if there is Flexible Afternoon Care. Ask there for further information (costs, registration).
Homework supervision
After school, many schools offer homework supervision. During homework period the students are looked after and supervised. The person in charge helps with questions.
 You may have to pay for homework support. Ask the school if there is homework support.
Hort
In the after-school care centre , children are looked after by educators after school. It is also known as a school nursery or a day nursery. In the after-school care centre, children can have lunch, do their homework and play with other children. They can get help with homework from teachers.The after-school care is for children of the primary school (1st Year until 4th Year). Sometimes older children can also visit the after-school care centre.
 You have to register with an after-school care centre.The after-school care costs money. The costs can be covered completely or partly by the “Jugendamt” (Youth Welfare Office), if you are unable to pay it.To do this, you must submit an application to the Youth Welfare Office. 
 Ask at the school or at  town hall if there is an after-school care centre in your municipality.
Holiday care
In some municipalities there is holiday care. Your children will be looked after there during the school holidays.In some municipalities, holiday care is also called " Stadtranderholung".During the holiday care there are many different offers for the children (games, sports, creative activities).
 If you want your child to take part in the holiday care, you must register them.Holiday care costs money.Important: Holiday care does not normally take place over the whole school holidays.
 Ask at the town hall if there is any holiday care. Ask there for further information (costs, registration, time period).
content:
“Verlässliche Grundschule” (a primary school that provides care directly before and after morning lessons)

At the Reliable Primary School, the children are looked after directly before and after lessons. Children can be looked after for up to six hours in the morning. This also includes lessons and breaks. For example, the care can be from 7 AM to 1 PM. However, the Reliable Primary School ends at 2 pm at the latest.

The Reliable Primary School takes place in the school or in rooms next to the school. Most of the time, educators/teachers look after the children during this time. There are often also different activities, for example sports or creative activities.

If you want your child to attend the Reliable Primary School, you must registerhim or her.
The Reliable Primary School costs money.

Ask at the school or the town hall if there is a Reliable Primary School. Ask there for further information (costs, registration).

Flexible afternoon care

Flexible after-school care is available at some schools.
These are offers in the afternoon. These offers take place at the schools. Flexible afternoon care starts at 12 noon at the earliest and ends at 5:30 PM at the latest.

If your child is to participate in afternoon care, you must register them.
Flexible afternoon care costs money.

Ask at the school or the town hall if there is Flexible Afternoon Care. Ask there for further information (costs, registration).

Homework supervision

After school, many schools offer homework supervision. During homework period the students are looked after and supervised. The person in charge helps with questions.

You may have to pay for homework support.
Ask the school if there is homework support.

Hort

In the after-school care centre , children are looked after by educators after school. It is also known as a school nursery or a day nursery. In the after-school care centre, children can have lunch, do their homework and play with other children. They can get help with homework from teachers.
The after-school care is for children of the primary school (1st Year until 4th Year). Sometimes older children can also visit the after-school care centre.

You have to register with an after-school care centre.
The after-school care costs money. The costs can be covered completely or partly by the “Jugendamt” (Youth Welfare Office), if you are unable to pay it.
To do this, you must submit an application to the Youth Welfare Office.

Ask at the school or at  town hall if there is an after-school care centre in your municipality.

Holiday care

In some municipalities there is holiday care. Your children will be looked after there during the school holidays.
In some municipalities, holiday care is also called " Stadtranderholung".
During the holiday care there are many different offers for the children (games, sports, creative activities).

If you want your child to take part in the holiday care, you must register them.
Holiday care costs money.
Important: Holiday care does not normally take place over the whole school holidays.

Ask at the town hall if there is any holiday care. Ask there for further information (costs, registration, time period).

title: What do I have to do when my child is sick?
excerpt:
If your child is ill or cannot go to school for other important reasons, you must report him or her as sick at school. Please call the school before the start of the lesson .
Most schools also expect a written note excusing the child. This is a letter from the parents. The written excuse must often be received by the school within three days.
If your child is ill for a longer period of time , he/she needs a doctor's certificate . The certificate must also be handed in at school. It is best to ask the secretary's office what the school needs.
If your child does not come to school without a telephone or written excuse or a medical certificate, the school must look for your child. If necessary, the school will even search for your child with the help of the police. You may then have to pay a fine.
content:
If your child is ill or cannot go to school for other important reasons, you must report him or her as sick at school. Please call the school before the start of the lesson .

Most schools also expect a written note excusing the child. This is a letter from the parents. The written excuse must often be received by the school within three days.

If your child is ill for a longer period of time , he/she needs a doctor's certificate . The certificate must also be handed in at school. It is best to ask the secretary's office what the school needs.

If your child does not come to school without a telephone or written excuse or a medical certificate, the school must look for your child. If necessary, the school will even search for your child with the help of the police. You may then have to pay a fine.

title: How much does school cost?
excerpt:
General and administrative expenses
Attendance at a state school is free of charge.
Ticket
If your child needs a ticket to school, you can buy a  JugendTicketBW.  With this season ticket, pupils can travel inexpensively by bus and train in the entire VVS area and even in the whole of Baden-Württemberg.The ticket costs €30.42 per month.If the school is more than 3 km away from your place of residence and you are entitled as per the BuT, the ticket can be paid for in part.You must then submit a BuT application .
School trips, school materials, lunch
This also costs money. You have to pay a part of it yourself.If you are entitled as per the BuT, the costs can be paid in part.You must submit a BuT application .
Ask your integration manager, social counsellor, youth migration counsellor or migration counsellor for help if you want to apply for a BuT.
content:
General and administrative expenses

Attendance at a state school is free of charge.

Ticket

If your child needs a ticket to school, you can buy a  JugendTicketBW. With this season ticket, pupils can travel inexpensively by bus and train in the entire VVS area and even in the whole of Baden-Württemberg.
The ticket costs €30.42 per month.
If the school is more than 3 km away from your place of residence and you are entitled as per the BuT, the ticket can be paid for in part.
You must then submit a BuT application .

School trips, school materials, lunch

This also costs money. You have to pay a part of it yourself.
If you are entitled as per the BuT, the costs can be paid in part.
You must submit a BuT application .

Ask your integration manager, social counsellor, youth migration counsellor or migration counsellor for help if you want to apply for a BuT.

title: Education and Participation Package (BuT; Bildungs- und Teilhabepaket)
excerpt:
If you receive Social Security benefits, you may receive financial assistance for your child. This support is called the Education and Participation Pact, or BuTfor short.
With the education and participation package, children, adolescents and young adults on low incomes are given the opportunity to take advantage of offers such as tutoring, music school, sports, lunch at daycare centres and schools or class excursions .
Who can apply for BuT?
All children, teenagers and young adults,

whose families receive a citizen's allowance or social assistance, or
whose families receive housing benefit or
for whom child supplement is received or
who receive asylum seeker benefits

Where to apply for the benefits?
 Rems-Murr District Job Centre

Benefit recipients who receive the citizen's income according to SGB II

Office for Social Affairs and Participation at the Rems-Murr District Office

Beneficiaries who receive housing benefit, social assistance, child supplement or asylum seeker benefits

District Office Rems-Murr-Kreis 071515011453 bildungspaket@rems-murr-kreis.de
content:
If you receive Social Security benefits, you may receive financial assistance for your child. This support is called the Education and Participation Pact, or BuTfor short.

With the education and participation package, children, adolescents and young adults on low incomes are given the opportunity to take advantage of offers such as tutoring, music school, sports, lunch at daycare centres and schools or class excursions .

Who can apply for BuT?

All children, teenagers and young adults,

  • whose families receive a citizen's allowance or social assistance, or
  • whose families receive housing benefit or

title: Important information for parents
content:
Parents' evening 

All parents are invited to a parents' evening. You can communicate with other parents and the teacher and get a lot of information. It is good if you take advantage of these meetings. The dates will be communicated in a letter to parents. It is important to read the letters to parents.

Parents' Council 

There is a Parents' Council in every class. This is elected by all parents during a parents' evening. The tasks and rights of the Parents' Council are regulated by law. The Parents' Council deals with problems that other parents tell them. The Parents' Council represents the other parents before the school.

School social work

There are school social workers in many schools. These can support children and young people at school. School social workers advise and help with school and private problems, annoyances or other worries. The service is voluntary and the school social workers work in confidence. This means that they must not tell anyone about the problems.
Otherwise, there are also guidance counsellors or liaison teachers. Check with your school.

Tutoring 

If you have difficulties in some subjects at school and need additional support, you can register for tutoring. The tutoring is carried out by a tutor and takes place outside the classroom. The tutoring usually takes place in small groups or by way of individual supervision. You can repeat content here or get extra tasks to practice.

Tutoring costs money. If you are Entitled to BuT the costs for tutoring can be paid under certain conditions (confirmation from the school that your child urgently needs tutoring).
You have to fill out a BuT application.

If you need help finding tutoring, ask your integration manager, social counselling, youth migration coun selling or migration counselling.

title: Is your child between 6 and 10 years old?
excerpt:
Grundschule (primary school) 
Age: from 6 years (deadline - your child will be 6 years old by 30.06.)Requirement: Primary school abilityAt the end of the daycare center there is the elementary school entrance examination. A doctor examines your child. He will check to see if your child is ready for school or needs special support.Duration: 4 years (1st Year until 4th Year)Thereafter: Transfer to a secondary schoolIn the 4th grade, parents receive a recommendation from the teachers. It states which secondary school your child should go to.Miscellaneous: The primary school is near/within the district of your place of residence. In primary school, your child learns to read, write and calculate.
Primary school support class 
Some children are not ready for primary schoolat the age of 6. As a rule, however, they can no longer stay in the kindergarten.However, they can then attend a primary school support class.
The primary school support class is also at the primary school.In the primary school support class, children receive special support. They are encouraged in their development.
The goal of the primary school support class is that the child is ready for grade 1. Class is.

content:
Grundschule (primary school) 

Age: from 6 years (deadline - your child will be 6 years old by 30.06.)
Requirement: Primary school ability
At the end of the daycare center there is the elementary school entrance examination. A doctor examines your child. He will check to see if your child is ready for school or needs special support.
Duration: 4 years (1st Year until 4th Year)
Thereafter: Transfer to a secondary school
In the 4th grade, parents receive a recommendation from the teachers. It states which secondary school your child should go to.
Miscellaneous: The primary school is near/within the district of your place of residence. In primary school, your child learns to read, write and calculate.

Primary school support class

Some children are not ready for primary schoolat the age of 6. As a rule, however, they can no longer stay in the kindergarten.
However, they can then attend a primary school support class.

The primary school support class is also at the primary school.
In the primary school support class, children receive special support. They are encouraged in their development.

The goal of the primary school support class is that the child is ready for grade 1. Class is.

Talk to the kindergarten, primary school and paediatrician if your child is not ready for school at the age of 6.

excerpt:
Then your child will attend a secondary school.
At the end of the 4. At the end of the first grade, the teachers make a recommendation as to which secondary school your child should attend.
