content:
Then your child will attend a secondary school.

At the end of the 4. At the end of the first grade, the teachers make a recommendation as to which secondary school your child should attend.

When one attends and graduates from a secondary school, one receives a certificate/achievement certificate. With a certificate, you can prove what you have learned. You need it, for example, for applications when looking for a job or apprenticeship or for transferring to another school.

Gemeinschaftsschule
Age: from 10 years
Duration: between 5 and 9 years (5. Grade 9 to 9. Class or up to 10. Class or 13. Year)
Requirement: Attending a primary school or preparatory class (VKL)
Certificate: “Hauptschulabschluss”, “Mittlere Reife” or “Abitur”
Focus: Lessons at different levels and individual support
Thereafter: Vocational training in the event of attaining a “Hauptschulabschluss” and “Mittlere Reife”, studies in the event of attaining “Abitur”

Secondary school 

Age: from 10 years
Duration: 5 years (5. Grade 9 to 9. Year)
Requirement: Attendance of a primary school or preparatory class (VKL)
Certificate: “Hauptschulabschluss” - general school leaving certificate
Focus: prepares for an apprenticeship or work, one learns theoretical and practical knowledge
Thereafter: Vocational training, “Realschule” (standard secondary school) or “Berufliche Schule” (vocational school)

Werkrealschule

Age: from 10 years
Duration: between 5 years (5. Grade 9 to 9. Grade) and 6 years (5. Class to 10. Year)
Requirement: Attendance of a primary school or preparatory class (VKL)
Certificate: either “Hauptschulabschluss” or “Mittlere Reife”
Focus: preparing for working life, promoting practical talent, aptitudes and performance
Thereafter: Vocational training, “Berufliche Schule” (vocational school) and “Gymnasium” (grammar school)

Realschule 

Age: From 10 years
Duration: 6 years (5. Class to 10. Year)
Requirement: Attendance of a primary school or preparatory class (VKL)
Certificate: Standard secondary school leaving certificate
Focus: vocational education and extended general education, preparation for vocational training and work
Thereafter: Vocational training, “Berufliche Schule” (vocational school) or “Gymnasium” (grammar school)

Gymnasium (grammar school) 

Age: from 10 years
Duration: between 8 and 9 years (5. Grade 12 to 12 or 13 Year)
Requirement: Attendance of a primary school or preparatory class (VKL)
Certificate: “Allgemeine Hochschulreife (Abitur)” – general university entrance qualification and the highest school leaving certificate in Germany
Focus: in-depth general education, special and in-depth subjects and courses, independent learning
Thereafter: Vocational training, study at a university or college

title: Graduate from senior school
excerpt:
In principle, senior school-leaving qualifications can also be obtained at a later date. For example, after obtaining the “mittlerer Bildungsabschluss” (“Mittlere Reife”) described above, the student could also obtain an Abitur at a grammar school. This is also possible, for example, at vocational schools, various vocational colleges or the evening school.
Even if you do not have a school-leaving certificate, you can obtain one at a later stage. Or you have a foreign school leaving certificate that is not recognised in Germany. Even then, you can obtain your school leaving certificate via a second educational path.
Here you can find more information.

title: General information about studying
excerpt:
Different types of universities
There are different types of universitiesin Germany:
Universitäten = universities (more academically focused)Pädagogische Hochschulen = Teacher training colleges (for social subjects)Hochschulen für Angewandte Wissenschaften = Universities of Applied Sciences (practice-oriented)Dual universities: very practice-oriented, you work and studyArt schools, film schools and music colleges: for artistic subjects
There are public and private universities. Private universities are not necessarily better than public ones – however, students usually have to pay high tuition fees at private universities.
Study programmes
There are also many different courses of study. An overview is available here.
Further information
You can find detailed information about studying in Germany here:

Different types of universities

There are different types of universitiesin Germany:

Universitäten = universities (more academically focused)

There are public and private universities. Private universities are not necessarily better than public ones – however, students usually have to pay high tuition fees at private universities.

title: What do I need in order to study?
excerpt:
If you want to study in Germany, you will need the following:
University entrance qualification
This is a school-leaving qualification that qualifies for university study, for example the Abitur or the higher education entrance qualification.If you did not complete your school-leaving certificate in Germany, you must check whether you can study in Germany from abroad with this school-leaving certificate. You can find further information here or here.
German language skills
Many courses of study (Bachelor, State Examination, Diploma) are in German. Therefore, you usually need certain language certificates at B2/C1 level (European reference framework). Some degree programmes (especially Master's and Doctorate) are also in English.
You can find an overview of international study programmes here.
content:
If you want to study in Germany, you will need the following:

University entrance qualification

This is a school-leaving qualification that qualifies for university study, for example the Abitur or the higher education entrance qualification.
If you did not complete your school-leaving certificate in Germany, you must check whether you can study in Germany from abroad with this school-leaving certificate. You can find further information here or here.

German language skills

Many courses of study (Bachelor, State Examination, Diploma) are in German. Therefore, you usually need certain language certificates at B2/C1 level (European reference framework). Some degree programmes (especially Master's and Doctorate) are also in English.

You can find an overview of international study programmes here.

title: How much does it cost to study?
excerpt:
At state universities, you may have to pay tuition fees.
You come from an EU/EEA country or have completed school with the German university entrance qualification (Abitur) ?Then you do not have to pay tuition fees.
You do not come from an EU/EEA country and do not have a German university entrance qualification (Abitur)?Then you have to pay € 1500 tuition fees each semester.
Under certain conditions, you can be exempted from paying tuition fees. To do this, you must submit an application. Here you can find more information.
You have flown your home country?You can be exempted from tuition fees. To do this, you must submit an application. Here you can find more information.
Attention: If you want to study at a private university, you usually have to pay higher fees.
content:
At state universities, you may have to pay tuition fees.

You come from an EU/EEA country or have completed school with the German university entrance qualification (Abitur) ?
Then you do not have to pay tuition fees.

You do not come from an EU/EEA country and do not have a German university entrance qualification (Abitur)?
Then you have to pay € 1500 tuition fees each semester.

Under certain conditions, you can be exempted from paying tuition fees. To do this, you must submit an application. Here you can find more information.

You have flown your home country?
You can be exempted from tuition fees. To do this, you must submit an application. Here you can find more information.

Attention: If you want to study at a private university, you usually have to pay higher fees.

title: How can I finance my studies?
excerpt:
Federal Training Assistance Act (BAföG)
BAföG means Bundesausbildungsförderungsgesetz (Federal Training Assistance Act) and is a financial support. You can apply for this if you are studying in Germany. BAföG is money from the state. You get it into your account every month. Half of the amount is free money. As soon as you have a job and earn money after your studies, you have to pay back the other half of the money. You can then pay back the money in small instalments.
BAföG can be applied for by people who live and study in Germany.
Even if you do not have a German passport, you can apply for BAföG.
You can get more information here.
You can also call the BAföG hotline free of charge: 0800-2236341 Monday - Friday from 8 a.m. - 8 p.m
The application for BAföG must be submitted in writing to the relevant student union. Make sure that your application is submitted early. This is because it takes several months to process the applications. You can find the application forms here.
Grants 
There are many grants you can apply for. And not just in the first semester, but throughout your studies. Here  you can get an overview. These schemes are sometimes very different from each other. In some cases, value is placed on social commitment or attention is paid to political orientation, course of study, grades or personal circumstances.
Working student 
Many courses of study offer the opportunity to work as a student trainee in a company. There you can gain your first experiences in the field you have studied and earn money on the side. The companies mostly offer contracts on a 10-20 hours/week basis. If you perform well, there is a chance of being taken on after graduation. Get information from companies in your area. The concept of the working student is widespread.
Student assistant 
As a student assistant, you can usually work at a university for a maximum of 20 hours a week. In doing so, you will complete tasks that will help, for example, a lecturer, a chair or an organisation of the university. The prerequisite is enrolment at a university as a student. These positions are advertised at the universities.
Side job and holiday job 
Many students have a side job to finance their studies. There are different types of side jobs. If you receive a state subsidy, find out how much you can earn in addition. State support is, for example, BAföG or a scholarship.
Many students work in a so-called mini-job. You earn a maximum of 450 € per month. But you don't pay taxes and social security contributions.
Some also work in holiday jobs during the semester breaks. If you earn more than 520 € per month in a holiday job, you should note the following: if you do not work for longer than 3 months or a total of 70 working days, the job is also social security-free.
 Education loan
The education loan is a low-interest loan from the state-owned Kreditanstalt für Wiederaufbau (KfW). It is specifically aimed at students who are in the final phase of their studies . Unlike normal bank loans, you do not need collateral such as your own income. The income of parents or a spouse is also irrelevant.
Here you will find further information on the subject of educational loans.
content:
Federal Training Assistance Act (BAföG)

BAföG means Bundesausbildungsförderungsgesetz (Federal Training Assistance Act) and is a financial support. You can apply for this if you are studying in Germany. BAföG is money from the state. You get it into your account every month. Half of the amount is free money. As soon as you have a job and earn money after your studies, you have to pay back the other half of the money. You can then pay back the money in small instalments.

BAföG can be applied for by people who live and study in Germany.

Even if you do not have a German passport, you can apply for BAföG.

You can get more information here.

You can also call the BAföG hotline free of charge:
0800-2236341
 Monday - Friday from 8 a.m. - 8 p.m

The application for BAföG must be submitted in writing to the relevant student union. Make sure that your application is submitted early. This is because it takes several months to process the applications. You can find the application forms here.

Grants 

There are many grants you can apply for. And not just in the first semester, but throughout your studies. Here  you can get an overview. These schemes are sometimes very different from each other. In some cases, value is placed on social commitment or attention is paid to political orientation, course of study, grades or personal circumstances.

Working student 

Many courses of study offer the opportunity to work as a student trainee in a company. There you can gain your first experiences in the field you have studied and earn money on the side. The companies mostly offer contracts on a 10-20 hours/week basis. If you perform well, there is a chance of being taken on after graduation. Get information from companies in your area. The concept of the working student is widespread.

Student assistant 

As a student assistant, you can usually work at a university for a maximum of 20 hours a week. In doing so, you will complete tasks that will help, for example, a lecturer, a chair or an organisation of the university. The prerequisite is enrolment at a university as a student. These positions are advertised at the universities.

Side job and holiday job 

Many students have a side job to finance their studies. There are different types of side jobs. If you receive a state subsidy, find out how much you can earn in addition. State support is, for example, BAföG or a scholarship.

Many students work in a so-called mini-job. You earn a maximum of 450 € per month. But you don't pay taxes and social security contributions.

Some also work in holiday jobs during the semester breaks. If you earn more than 520 € per month in a holiday job, you should note the following: if you do not work for longer than 3 months or a total of 70 working days, the job is also social security-free.

 Education loan

The education loan is a low-interest loan from the state-owned Kreditanstalt für Wiederaufbau (KfW). It is specifically aimed at students who are in the final phase of their studies . Unlike normal bank loans, you do not need collateral such as your own income. The income of parents or a spouse is also irrelevant.

Here you will find further information on the subject of educational loans.

title: May I work with a residence permit?
excerpt:
Permission to work as an asylum seeker with a residence permit depends on this,

whether you live in an initial reception centre or have already been placed outside the initial reception centre
how many months you have already been in Germany.

They still live in the initial reception centre
No employment permit can be issued during thefirst nine months after the asylum application is filed. During this time, your identity document will contain the sentence: "Gainful employment not permitted".
After the ninth month from the date of application for asylum, there is an entitlement to the issuance of an employment permit. Your identity document says "Gainful employment only permitted with the permission of the foreigners authority." You must complete and sign the job description and declaration of employment and hand it in to the Aliens' Registration Office.
You no longer live in the initial reception centre
If you are in Germany for less than 3 months, you are not allowed to work.
If you have been in Germany for 4-9 months or longer, you can apply for an employment permit at the Aliens' Registration Office (see above). The decision is taken at the discretion of the relevant authority.
From the 10. Month you can apply for an employment permit. This is then no longer a discretionary decision, because you are entitled to it.
A general employment permit applies from4 years in Germany.  You then have full access to the labour market. This means The approval of the “Bundesagentur für Arbeit” (Federal Employment Agency) is no longer necessary. But this must be applied for at the “Ausländerbehörde” (Immigration Office). It will then be noted in your residence permit.
If you have any further questions, please contact your social services or integration management.
content:
Permission to work as an asylum seeker with a residence permit depends on this,

  • whether you live in an initial reception centre or have already been placed outside the initial reception centre
  • how many months you have already been in Germany.

They still live in the initial reception centre

No employment permit can be issued during thefirst nine months after the asylum application is filed. During this time, your identity document will contain the sentence: "Gainful employment not permitted".

After the ninth month from the date of application for asylum, there is an entitlement to the issuance of an employment permit. Your identity document says "Gainful employment only permitted with the permission of the foreigners authority." You must complete and sign the job description and declaration of employment and hand it in to the Aliens' Registration Office.

You no longer live in the initial reception centre

If you are in Germany for less than 3 months, you are not allowed to work.

If you have been in Germany for 4-9 months or longer, you can apply for an employment permit at the Aliens' Registration Office (see above). The decision is taken at the discretion of the relevant authority.

From the 10. Month you can apply for an employment permit. This is then no longer a discretionary decision, because you are entitled to it.

A general employment permit applies from4 years in Germany. You then have full access to the labour market. This means The approval of the “Bundesagentur für Arbeit” (Federal Employment Agency) is no longer necessary. But this must be applied for at the “Ausländerbehörde” (Immigration Office). It will then be noted in your residence permit.

If you have any further questions, please contact your social services or integration management.

title: Can I work if I come from a safe country of origin?
excerpt:
Besides the EU member states, Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Ghana, Kosovo, Macedonia, Montenegro, Senegal and Serbiaare currently considered safe countries of origin.
Permission to work as an asylum seeker from a safe country of origin is dependent on

whether you have a residence permit or a tolerated status
whether you live in an initial reception centre or have already been placed outside the initial reception centre
when you filed your asylum application.

You are still living in the initial reception centre and have a temporary residence permit or a toleration permit and filed your asylum application after 31.08.2015?
Then you may not work.
You are still living in the initial reception centre and have a Duldung and filed your asylum application before 31.08.2015?
Then you can apply for an employment permit at the “Ausländerbehörde” (Immigration Office). You must complete and sign the job description and the declaration of employment for it and hand it in to the Aliens' Registration Office.
You are no longer living in the initial reception centre and have a residence permit and filed your asylum application after 31.08.2015?
Then you may not work.
You are no longer living in the initial reception centre and have a residence permit and submitted your asylum application before 31.08.2015?
Then you can apply for an employment permit at the “Ausländerbehörde” (Immigration Office).
You are no longer living in the initial reception centre and have a Duldung and have applied for asylum after 31.08.2015?
Then you may not work.
You are no longer living in the initial reception centre and have a toleration permit and filed an asylum application before 31 August 2015?
Then you can apply for an employment permit at the Foreigners' Registration Office.
content:
Besides the EU member states, Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Ghana, Kosovo, Macedonia, Montenegro, Senegal and Serbiaare currently considered safe countries of origin.

Permission to work as an asylum seeker from a safe country of origin is dependent on

  • whether you have a residence permit or a tolerated status
  • whether you live in an initial reception centre or have already been placed outside the initial reception centre
  • when you filed your asylum application.

You are still living in the initial reception centre and have a temporary residence permit or a toleration permit and filed your asylum application after 31.08.2015?

Then you may not work.

You are still living in the initial reception centre and have a Duldung and filed your asylum application before 31.08.2015?

Then you can apply for an employment permit at the “Ausländerbehörde” (Immigration Office). You must complete and sign the job description and the declaration of employment for it and hand it in to the Aliens' Registration Office.

You are no longer living in the initial reception centre and have a residence permit and filed your asylum application after 31.08.2015?

Then you may not work.

You are no longer living in the initial reception centre and have a residence permit and submitted your asylum application before 31.08.2015?

Then you can apply for an employment permit at the “Ausländerbehörde” (Immigration Office).

You are no longer living in the initial reception centre and have a Duldung and have applied for asylum after 31.08.2015?

Then you may not work.

You are no longer living in the initial reception centre and have a toleration permit and filed an asylum application before 31 August 2015?

Then you can apply for an employment permit at the Foreigners' Registration Office.

title: May I work with a tolerated status?
excerpt:
Permission to work with a Duldung depends on this,

whether you live in an initial reception centre or have already been placed outside the initial reception centre
how many months you have already been in Germany.

They still live in the initial reception centreIf you are in possession of a “Duldung” (toleration) for 0-6 months, then you are not allowed to work.
If you have held the Duldung according to §60a for at least 6 months , then gainful employment is only permitted with the approval of the Aliens' Registration Office. You will find this notice on your identity document as a secondary provision.
An employment permit can be issued to you. You must complete and sign the job description and the declaration of employment and hand it in to the Aliens' Registration Office. The approval of the “Bundesagentur für Arbeit” (Federal Employment Agency) is requested by the “Ausländerbehörde” (Immigration Office). In doing so, it checks the working conditions (for example, minimum wage, scope of work).
They no longer live in the initial reception centreIf you are in Germany for 0-3 months, you are not allowed to work.
If you have already been in Germany for 4 months, you can apply for an employment permit at the Aliens' Registration Office. Your identity document says "Gainful employment only permitted with the permission of the foreigners authority." This means that you must complete and sign the job description and declaration of employment and hand it in to the Aliens' Registration Office. The approval of the “Bundesagentur für Arbeit” (Federal Employment Agency) is requested by the “Ausländerbehörde” (Immigration Office). In doing so, it checks the working conditions (for example, minimum wage, scope of work). The granting of the employment permit is at the discretion of the foreigners authority.
If you have already been in Germany for 4 years, a general employment permit applies. You then have full access to the labour market. This means The approval of the “Bundesagentur für Arbeit” (Federal Employment Agency) is no longer necessary.
In principle, you do not need a work permit for school education.
Persons with a Duldung according to §60a AufenthG
There is a ban on working if:

They come from a "safe" country of origin and filed their asylum application after 31 August 2015 or entered the country after this cut-off date.
They entered Germany with the motive of receiving asylum seekers' benefits.
Deportation is not possible for a reason for which the applicant is responsible and which is the cause of the impossibility of deportation.

Persons with a temporary residence permit §60b AufenthG
Toleration for persons "with unclear identity
For these persons, gainful employment is not allowed (work ban).
This toleration is granted to persons who have not fulfilledtheirobligations to cooperate .
Obtaining passports and clarifying identityIt is very important that you cooperate in obtaining your passport and clarifying your identity. Otherwise, the Aliens' Registration Office or the Regional Council can issue you with a general ban on working under aliens' law.If you have such a work ban, you cannot apply to the Aliens' Registration Office for admission to employment/training or continuation of existing employment.
If you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to contact your social services or the responsible integration management.
content:
Permission to work with a Duldung depends on this,

  • whether you live in an initial reception centre or have already been placed outside the initial reception centre
  • how many months you have already been in Germany.

They still live in the initial reception centre
If you are in possession of a “Duldung” (toleration) for 0-6 months, then you are not allowed to work.

If you have held the Duldung according to §60a for at least 6 months , then gainful employment is only permitted with the approval of the Aliens' Registration Office. You will find this notice on your identity document as a secondary provision.

An employment permit can be issued to you. You must complete and sign the job description and the declaration of employment and hand it in to the Aliens' Registration Office. The approval of the “Bundesagentur für Arbeit” (Federal Employment Agency) is requested by the “Ausländerbehörde” (Immigration Office). In doing so, it checks the working conditions (for example, minimum wage, scope of work).

They no longer live in the initial reception centre
If you are in Germany for 0-3 months, you are not allowed to work.

If you have already been in Germany for 4 months, you can apply for an employment permit at the Aliens' Registration Office. Your identity document says "Gainful employment only permitted with the permission of the foreigners authority." This means that you must complete and sign the job description and declaration of employment and hand it in to the Aliens' Registration Office. The approval of the “Bundesagentur für Arbeit” (Federal Employment Agency) is requested by the “Ausländerbehörde” (Immigration Office). In doing so, it checks the working conditions (for example, minimum wage, scope of work). The granting of the employment permit is at the discretion of the foreigners authority.

If you have already been in Germany for 4 years, a general employment permit applies. You then have full access to the labour market. This means The approval of the “Bundesagentur für Arbeit” (Federal Employment Agency) is no longer necessary.

In principle, you do not need a work permit for school education.

Persons with a Duldung according to §60a AufenthG

There is a ban on working if:

  • They come from a "safe" country of origin and filed their asylum application after 31 August 2015 or entered the country after this cut-off date.
  • They entered Germany with the motive of receiving asylum seekers' benefits.
  • Deportation is not possible for a reason for which the applicant is responsible and which is the cause of the impossibility of deportation.

Persons with a temporary residence permit §60b AufenthG

Toleration for persons "with unclear identity

For these persons, gainful employment is not allowed (work ban).

This toleration is granted to persons who have not fulfilledtheirobligations to cooperate .

Obtaining passports and clarifying identity
It is very important that you cooperate in obtaining your passport and clarifying your identity. Otherwise, the Aliens' Registration Office or the Regional Council can issue you with a general ban on working under aliens' law.
If you have such a work ban, you cannot apply to the Aliens' Registration Office for admission to employment/training or continuation of existing employment.

If you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to contact your social services or the responsible integration management.

title: May I work as a person who has flown their home country and who has a residence permit?
excerpt:
As a recognised refugee, as a refugee with subsidiary protection and with a ban on deportation, you will be issued a residence permit.  With the residence permit, you may immediately take up any kind of work or start an apprenticeship. In such cases, the companies do not have to observe any special conditions.In your residence permit or on the “Zusatzblatt” (supplementary sheet), you will find as an ancillary provision “Erwerbstätigkeit gestattet” (“Gainful employment permitted”).
With the electronic residence title (eAT) you can take up self-employment, but you need the approval of the “Ausländerbehörde” (Immigration Office).
If you need more information, please contact your social services or your integration management.
content:
As a recognised refugee, as a refugee with subsidiary protection and with a ban on deportation, you will be issued a residence permit. With the residence permit, you may immediately take up any kind of work or start an apprenticeship. In such cases, the companies do not have to observe any special conditions.
In your residence permit or on the “Zusatzblatt” (supplementary sheet), you will find as an ancillary provision “Erwerbstätigkeit gestattet” (“Gainful employment permitted”).

With the electronic residence title (eAT) you can take up self-employment, but you need the approval of the “Ausländerbehörde” (Immigration Office).

If you need more information, please contact your social services or your integration management.

title: Recognition of foreign qualifications
excerpt: Qualifications play an important role in Germany for school, studies or work. With qualification certificates you can prove what you have already learned and achieved. Qualifications are an important prerequisite for a place at a school, university or job.This means that if you have already acquired qualifications at school, in an apprenticeship or in a course of study abroad, you can have these recognised. There will be a review to check what you are qualified to do in Germany based on your qualifications. Your qualifications are “transposed” so to speak.
content:
Qualifications play an important role in Germany for school, studies or work. With qualification certificates you can prove what you have already learned and achieved. Qualifications are an important prerequisite for a place at a school, university or job.
This means that if you have already acquired qualifications at school, in an apprenticeship or in a course of study abroad, you can have these recognised. There will be a review to check what you are qualified to do in Germany based on your qualifications. Your qualifications are “transposed” so to speak.

title: Foreign school-leaving certificate
excerpt:
The recognition of a foreign school-leaving certificate is particularly useful if you want to start an apprenticeship . However, if you also want to start a course of study university studies , you have to have your school leaving certificate recognised.
The Stuttgart Regional Council (Regierungspräsidium Stuttgart) examines foreign school-leaving qualifications (for example, Hauptschulabschluss, Mittlere Reife, Fachhochschulreife/Hochschulreife).
You can contact the “Zeugnisanerkennungsstellen” (Certificate Recognition Offices) for Baden-Württemberg and have your qualifications reviewed.
content:
The recognition of a foreign school-leaving certificate is particularly useful if you want to start an apprenticeship . However, if you also want to start a course of study university studies , you have to have your school leaving certificate recognised.

The Stuttgart Regional Council (Regierungspräsidium Stuttgart) examines foreign school-leaving qualifications (for example, Hauptschulabschluss, Mittlere Reife, Fachhochschulreife/Hochschulreife).

You can contact the “Zeugnisanerkennungsstellen” (Certificate Recognition Offices) for Baden-Württemberg and have your qualifications reviewed.

title: Foreign degree
excerpt:
You can have it checked whether your degree is recognised in Germany.
Note that there is a difference in recognition between regulated and non-regulated professions.
Regulated professions
You may only work in regulated professions if a certain qualification is available. These are, for example

Medical professions
Legal professions
The teaching profession at state schools
Professions in the public sector

This means that in these professions you may only work with a state recognition of the professional qualification (for example, vocational qualification or university degree).In the Anerkennungs-Finder you can search for the competent recognition body for regulated professions. You will also receive information on how to proceed.
Non-regulated professions
In non-regulated professions, you may work without the state recognition of professional qualifications. However, it is recommended to apply for a certificate evaluation.The Central Office for Foreign Education (ZAB) in Bonn is responsible for the assessment of certificates for non-regulated academic professions.
Further information
Here you will find further information on the recognition of your university degree from abroad.
content:
You can have it checked whether your degree is recognised in Germany.

Note that there is a difference in recognition between regulated and non-regulated professions.

Regulated professions

You may only work in regulated professions if a certain qualification is available. These are, for example

  • Medical professions
  • Legal professions
  • The teaching profession at state schools
  • Professions in the public sector

This means that in these professions you may only work with a state recognition of the professional qualification (for example, vocational qualification or university degree).
In the Anerkennungs-Finder you can search for the competent recognition body for regulated professions. You will also receive information on how to proceed.

Non-regulated professions

In non-regulated professions, you may work without the state recognition of professional qualifications. However, it is recommended to apply for a certificate evaluation.
The Central Office for Foreign Education (ZAB) in Bonn is responsible for the assessment of certificates for non-regulated academic professions.

Further information

Here you will find further information on the recognition of your university degree from abroad.

title: Foreign vocational training qualification
excerpt:
If you have completed vocational training abroad, you can check whether this training is recognised in Germany. As a rule, the respective chamber (Chamber of Crafts, Chamber of Industry and Chamber of Commerce) is responsible for this. Chambers are points of contact for various training courses.
In the Recognition-Finder you can search for the competent recognition office. You will also receive information on how to proceed.Please note that the “Regierungspräsidium” (Regional Council) Stuttgart is responsible for the recognition of vocational training for educators and child carers.
content:
If you have completed vocational training abroad, you can check whether this training is recognised in Germany. As a rule, the respective chamber (Chamber of Crafts, Chamber of Industry and Chamber of Commerce) is responsible for this. Chambers are points of contact for various training courses.

In the Recognition-Finder you can search for the competent recognition office. You will also receive information on how to proceed.
Please note that the “Regierungspräsidium” (Regional Council) Stuttgart is responsible for the recognition of vocational training for educators and child carers.

title: Career planning in the Rems-Murr district
excerpt:
Training preparation dual (AVdual)
The AVdual support at the schools in the Rems-Murr district supports AVdual pupils to improve their chances on the training market and labour market.
Tasks:

Counselling and support in planning career paths and educational pathways.
Help with preparing application documents and preparing for job interviews
Support in preparing and carrying out a work placement
mediator between school, company and parents

The AVdual mentors have their office at the vocational schools. This means they are always in contact with the class teachers or school social work. Here you can find an overview of the AVdual training programme in the Rems-Murr district.

Vocational guidance
Vocational guidance supports you in your choice of study and career, during training and at the beginning of your working life. In a personal counselling interview you can clarify all important questions about your professional future.
Counselling is available to

Pupils
Trainees
students and
graduates of universities and colleges.

In addition, anyone who is seeking vocational training for the first time or who wants to reorientate themselves professionally.
 08004555500
 Request a counselling appointment

Youth Vocational Assistance
To ensure that every young person has a chance of finding an apprenticeship place and a job, the Youth Vocational Assistance Service offers counselling, support and orientation.
Vocational guidance Diakonie

Youth Migration Service Schorndorf

title: Vocational preparation and training preparation
excerpt:
VABO - Pre-qualification for a job without German language skills
At the schools, young people initially receive intensive language support in so-called VABO classes (pre-qualification year for work/occupation with a focus on acquiring German language skills at vocational schools) and are prepared for the transition to training and work.
Age: younger than 19Duration: 1 year full-time (repetition possible)Prerequisite: little or no knowledge of GermanFocus: Acquisition of the German languageCertificate: A2 or B1Connection: Change to AVdual, start a helper training programme, employment agency measures, a Voluntary Social Year (FSJ), Voluntary Ecological Year (FÖJ) or looking for a job.
From now on, pupils should use the following link to register for the VABO programme: 
 VABO registration 
AVdual - dual training preparation programme
Age: possible from 15/16 years - up to approx. 25Duration: 1 year full-time (repetition possible)Prerequisite: at least language level A2Focus: Vocational orientation, many internshipsCertificate: Secondary school leaving certificateFollow-up: Start an apprenticeship, 1-year vocational school or 2-year vocational school, employment agency measures, FSJ, FÖJ or looking for a job
You can find more detailed information about AVdual here.
BEJ - vocational entry year
Age: possible from 15/16 yearsDuration: 1 year full-timePrerequisite: Secondary school leaving certificate and/or still required to attend vocational schoolFocus: Vocational preparation and improvement of training skillsCertificate: none or improvement of the lower secondary school leaving certificateFollow-up: Start an apprenticeship, 1-year vocational school or 2-year vocational school, employment agency measures, FSJ, FÖJ or looking for a job
Pre-vocational training programme
A pre-vocational training programme (BvB) helps you if you are having problems finding an apprenticeship or have broken off an apprenticeship. With a BvB, you can make good use of the time until your (next) apprenticeship and make progress on your way into working life.
Further information can be found here.

You can find an overview of the preparatory classes in the Rems-Murr district here:
AVdual accompaniments in the Rems-Murr district
VABO support in the Rems-Murr district
content:
VABO - Pre-qualification for a job without German language skills

At the schools, young people initially receive intensive language support in so-called VABO classes (pre-qualification year for work/occupation with a focus on acquiring German language skills at vocational schools) and are prepared for the transition to training and work.

Age: younger than 19
Duration: 1 year full-time (repetition possible)
Prerequisite: little or no knowledge of German
Focus: Acquisition of the German language
Certificate: A2 or B1
Connection: Change to AVdual, start a helper training programme, employment agency measures, a Voluntary Social Year (FSJ), Voluntary Ecological Year (FÖJ) or looking for a job.


From now on, pupils should use the following link to register for the VABO programme:

VABO registration

Prerequisite: at least language level A2
Focus: Vocational orientation, many internships
Certificate: Secondary school leaving certificate
Follow-up: Start an apprenticeship, 1-year vocational school or 2-year vocational school, employment agency measures, FSJ, FÖJ or looking for a job

You can find more detailed information about AVdual here.


BEJ - vocational entry year

Age: possible from 15/16 years
Duration: 1 year full-time
Prerequisite: Secondary school leaving certificate and/or still required to attend vocational school
Focus: Vocational preparation and improvement of training skills
Certificate: none or improvement of the lower secondary school leaving certificate
Follow-up: Start an apprenticeship, 1-year vocational school or 2-year vocational school, employment agency measures, FSJ, FÖJ or looking for a job


Pre-vocational training programme

A pre-vocational training programme (BvB) helps you if you are having problems finding an apprenticeship or have broken off an apprenticeship. With a BvB, you can make good use of the time until your (next) apprenticeship and make progress on your way into working life.

title: EQ - Introductory Qualification
excerpt:
The EQ (Einstiegsqualifizierung) is a paid internship subject to social insurance with a duration of between six and a maximum of 12 months. It serves as preparation for an apprenticeship. Further information is available here.
Young people can contact the career counsellors at the Waiblingen Employment Agency on 08004555500, or by e-mail at waiblingen.Berufsberatung@arbeitsagentur.de.
content:
The EQ (Einstiegsqualifizierung) is a paid internship subject to social insurance with a duration of between six and a maximum of 12 months. It serves as preparation for an apprenticeship. Further information is available here.

Young people can contact the career counsellors at the Waiblingen Employment Agency on 08004555500, or by e-mail at waiblingen.Berufsberatung@arbeitsagentur.de.

title: Why do an apprenticeship?
excerpt:
In Germany, it is a great advantage if you have a vocational qualification before you go to work. With a vocational qualification, you earn more money on average over the course of your life, become unemployed less often and have fixed-term contracts less often than if you were looking for work without a vocational qualification.

In principle, training can begin at any time. The regular start of training is 1 August or 1 September each year. In some professions, it is also possible to start on 1 February or 1 March. If the start of training differs from this, the respective vocational school should be consulted.
The duration of the vocational training depends on the type of job. It usually lasts 3 years. At the end of the training period you take a final exam. If you pass the exam, you can work in this profession. There is no age limit to start vocational training.
You can also do part-time vocational training. A part-time vocational training programme lasts the same length of time as a normal, full-time one – but less time is spent at the company each day or week.
Successfully completed vocational training opens up many options on the labour market to you. You can also take up a course of study after completing your training.
An Internship is useful to get an insight into a profession. You can find out whether you like the profession. You can also improve your German language skills.
Whether you are allowed to do an apprenticeship depends on your residence status. 
There are around 400 apprenticeship occupationsin Germany. If you are interested in vocational training, you can find further information and contact persons at  Training in Germany (dual and full-school).
As a teenager and young adult, you have to go to vocational school . This is true if you are undergoing vocational training, but also in other cases. The vocational schools in the Rems-Murr district also offer various educational and counselling services to prepare you for vocational training or for starting a career. The youth vocational assistance or AVdual counsellors can advise you on this. Outside of the vocational schools, the HWK, the IHK and the employment promotion companies also provide support when starting a career and in the first few months of training.
content:
In Germany, it is a great advantage if you have a vocational qualification before you go to work. With a vocational qualification, you earn more money on average over the course of your life, become unemployed less often and have fixed-term contracts less often than if you were looking for work without a vocational qualification.

In principle, training can begin at any time. The regular start of training is 1 August or 1 September each year. In some professions, it is also possible to start on 1 February or 1 March. If the start of training differs from this, the respective vocational school should be consulted.

The duration of the vocational training depends on the type of job. It usually lasts 3 years. At the end of the training period you take a final exam. If you pass the exam, you can work in this profession. There is no age limit to start vocational training.

You can also do part-time vocational training. A part-time vocational training programme lasts the same length of time as a normal, full-time one – but less time is spent at the company each day or week.

Successfully completed vocational training opens up many options on the labour market to you. You can also take up a course of study after completing your training.

An Internship is useful to get an insight into a profession. You can find out whether you like the profession. You can also improve your German language skills.

Whether you are allowed to do an apprenticeship depends on your residence status. 

There are around 400 apprenticeship occupationsin Germany. If you are interested in vocational training, you can find further information and contact persons at  Training in Germany (dual and full-school).

As a teenager and young adult, you have to go to vocational school . This is true if you are undergoing vocational training, but also in other cases. The vocational schools in the Rems-Murr district also offer various educational and counselling services to prepare you for vocational training or for starting a career. The youth vocational assistance or AVdual counsellors can advise you on this. Outside of the vocational schools, the HWK, the IHK and the employment promotion companies also provide support when starting a career and in the first few months of training.

title: Dual training
excerpt:
A special feature in Germany is the dual training system. Dual training takes place about one third of the time in vocational school and about two thirds in a training company.  In this way you get to know theory and practice at the same time and earn money in a company during your training.
If you want to apply for an apprenticeship, German language skills are very important (at least B1). This is because German is spoken in companies and vocational schools and technical colleges. The tests will also be held in German.
In a short film by the network Unternehmen integrieren Flüchtlinge (Companies Integrate Refugees), vocational training is presented in different languages.
content:
A special feature in Germany is the dual training system. Dual training takes place about one third of the time in vocational school and about two thirds in a training company. In this way you get to know theory and practice at the same time and earn money in a company during your training.

If you want to apply for an apprenticeship, German language skills are very important (at least B1). This is because German is spoken in companies and vocational schools and technical colleges. The tests will also be held in German.

In a short film by the network Unternehmen integrieren Flüchtlinge (Companies Integrate Refugees), vocational training is presented in different languages.

title: Full-time school-based training
excerpt: In Germany, however, not only is there the option for dual training, but there is also full-time school-based training at a vocational school (Berufsfachschule). This type of training provides a completed vocational training in theory and practice outside of the dual training system (without an apprenticeship at a company). It usually lasts two to three and a half years. The course is full-time and includes general subjects in addition to the professional subjects. Vocational schools vary greatly in terms of their training courses, admission requirements, duration of training and further education opportunities. Please enquire at the respective school in each individual case.
content: In Germany, however, not only is there the option for dual training, but there is also full-time school-based training at a vocational school (Berufsfachschule). This type of training provides a completed vocational training in theory and practice outside of the dual training system (without an apprenticeship at a company). It usually lasts two to three and a half years. The course is full-time and includes general subjects in addition to the professional subjects. Vocational schools vary greatly in terms of their training courses, admission requirements, duration of training and further education opportunities. Please enquire at the respective school in each individual case.

title: Employment Agency or Job Centre?

The Employment Agency (SGB III) is responsible for asylum seekers and persons with toleration who receive benefits under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act. 
Job placement service
You are looking for a job or want to further your professional development? You can discuss these and many other questions with the employment agency. The employment agencies at all locations in the agency district are happy to help you with advice and support.
Further information

Job placement
Consultations that focus on starting work
Advice on all aspects of continuing vocational training
Information on job search and finding a job
Many of your questions can be clarified in a personal conversation, arrange your consultation appointment, also by telephone.

Career guidance
Career guidance supports you in your choice of study and career, during training and at the beginning of your working life. In a personal consultation, you can clarify important questions about your professional future.
The following persons can be advised

schoolchildren
Apprentices
students and
Graduates of the universities.

In addition, all those who are seeking vocational training for the first time or want to reorient themselves professionally.
Career guidance can help you, for example,

to find a suitable profession or a suitable study programme
to clarify questions about the contents of an apprenticeship or study programme
to find a training place and to apply accordingly
to develop alternatives, if the desired occupation does not work
to use funding opportunities
Receive information on the training market or labour market.

title: What does unemployment mean?
excerpt:
You are unemployed if you do not earn money to live on. This is also called unemployment. Since Germany is a welfare state, it helps people who cannot or can only partially secure their own livelihood.
However: Basically, everyone should be able to earn their own living through work.
content:
You are unemployed if you do not earn money to live on. This is also called unemployment. Since Germany is a welfare state, it helps people who cannot or can only partially secure their own livelihood.

However: Basically, everyone should be able to earn their own living through work.

title: Unemployment benefit
excerpt:
You will receiveunemployment benefit if you lose your job. You must have worked in Germany for at least 12 months in the last 30 months. There are other conditions under certain circumstances.
The Federal Employment Agency will decide whether you receive unemployment benefit.
1. register as a jobseeker
You have been made redundant, you have given notice or your temporary employment contract is coming to an end. The Employment Agency will support you in your search for new employment. They will also work with you to determine whether you are entitled to financial support.
It is important that you register as a jobseeker immediately. Register as a jobseeker at least 3 months before the end of your employment relationship. If you only find out later, register as a jobseeker no later than 3 days later.
You can do this in various ways:
On site at your local employment agencyby telephone at  0800/4555500 (toll-free)online at https://www.arbeitsagentur.de/
2. register as unemployed in person
You must register as unemployed in person at your local employment agency on your first day without work at the latest. This is the prerequisite for receiving unemployment benefit.
3. complete the application for unemployment benefit
Apply for unemployment benefit online. Alternatively, you can obtain an application form from your local employment agency to submit the application in writing.
You can obtain further informationhere.
content:
You will receiveunemployment benefit if you lose your job. You must have worked in Germany for at least 12 months in the last 30 months. There are other conditions under certain circumstances.

The Federal Employment Agency will decide whether you receive unemployment benefit.

1. register as a jobseeker

You have been made redundant, you have given notice or your temporary employment contract is coming to an end. The Employment Agency will support you in your search for new employment. They will also work with you to determine whether you are entitled to financial support.

It is important that you register as a jobseeker immediately. Register as a jobseeker at least 3 months before the end of your employment relationship. If you only find out later, register as a jobseeker no later than 3 days later.

You can do this in various ways:

On site at your local employment agency
by telephone at 0800/4555500 (toll-free)
online at https://www.arbeitsagentur.de/


2. register as unemployed in person

You must register as unemployed in person at your local employment agency on your first day without work at the latest. This is the prerequisite for receiving unemployment benefit.

3. complete the application for unemployment benefit

Apply for unemployment benefit online. Alternatively, you can obtain an application form from your local employment agency to submit the application in writing.

You can obtain further informationhere.

title: Citizen's income
excerpt:
You are entitled to citizen's allowance from the Job Centre if you meet certain conditions.
You can receive citizen's allowance if you are able to work and entitled to benefits and therefore fulfil at least the following conditions:

You are at least 15 years old and you have not yet reached the age limit for your pension.
You live in Germany and have your centre of life here.
You can work at least 3 hours a day.
You or members of your benefit community are in need of assistance.

In need of assistance means that the income of your benefit community is below the minimum subsistence level and you are unable to cover your living expenses from your own resources.
Able to work means that no illness or disability prevents you from taking up work.
Anyone who is not able to work can also receive citizen's allowance if they live in a community of need with a person who is able to work and entitled to benefits.
You will receive

a standard rate
Housing and heating costs
Health insurance and nursing care insurance
Initial equipment for housing and clothing
Integration into the labour market.

Register with the job centre. 
You can apply for citizen's allowance onlinehere.
Please note: Benefits under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act are subordinate to all other financial support and your own income.
content:
You are entitled to citizen's allowance from the Job Centre if you meet certain conditions.

You can receive citizen's allowance if you are able to work and entitled to benefits and therefore fulfil at least the following conditions:

  • You are at least 15 years old and you have not yet reached the age limit for your pension.
  • You live in Germany and have your centre of life here.
  • You can work at least 3 hours a day.
  • You or members of your benefit community are in need of assistance.

In need of assistance means that the income of your benefit community is below the minimum subsistence level and you are unable to cover your living expenses from your own resources.

Able to work means that no illness or disability prevents you from taking up work.

Anyone who is not able to work can also receive citizen's allowance if they live in a community of need with a person who is able to work and entitled to benefits.

You will receive

  • a standard rate
  • Housing and heating costs
  • Health insurance and nursing care insurance
  • Initial equipment for housing and clothing
  • Integration into the labour market.

Register with the job centre.

You can apply for citizen's allowance onlinehere.

Please note: Benefits under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act are subordinate to all other financial support and your own income.

title: Assisted training flexible (AsAflex)
content:
With the AsAflex, young people are supported in finding a training place and on the way to successfully completing their training - flexibly and completely adapted to individual needs. Trainees and training companies receive continuous socio-educational support from specialists. The trainees receive preparatory offers and assistance tailored to them, while the companies are supported, for example, in organisational issues or in the search for suitable trainees. 

Who is AsAflex aimed at? 
To young people who want to do a dual apprenticeship or are currently preparing for an apprenticeship in an introductory qualification.

Entry can begin in all apprenticeship years. Whenever there is a need for support.

More info here: 

Assisted Training (AsA) | Federal Employment Agency (arbeitsagentur.de)

title: Funding opportunities through the Employment Agency
excerpt:
Vocational training allowance (BAB)
Is the money you earn during your training not enough? Then you can ask the Employment Agency or the Job Centre whether you can get financial help. This supportive funding is called Berufsausbildungsbeihilfe (BAB).
You can find more information on the vocational training allowancehere.
Prospects for young refugees
Have you fled your home country and would like to start training in Germany? Find out about special offers at the Employment Agency.
If you are younger than 25, the measure "Perspectives for Young Refugees (PerjuF)" will help you to find your way on the German training market. Following this measure, you should be able to start a suitable apprenticeship.
During the first 2 weeks, your language skills will be tested. It will also be determined how much support you need. After that, you will find out whether you like working with wood or metal, for example, or whether you are suitable for the field of home economics.
As a rule, participation lasts 6 to 8 months.
The placement specialists at your employment agency or the integration specialists at the job centre will be happy to help you with any questions you may have.
Vocational guidance in working life (BBiE)
Whether you want to take on more responsibility in your job, update or expand your professional knowledge or reorient yourself professionally: The Employment Agency's Vocational Guidance in Working Life (BBiE) supports you in every phase of your professional life.
We will advise you comprehensively and individually every step of the way - from initial orientation to the selection of a suitable, subsidised continuing education programme to the search for a new job.
Appointment
Monday to Friday from 8 a.m. - 6 p.m: 08004555500
 
Here you can find more information from the Federal Employment Agency.

title: mira - Right at work
excerpt:
Doyou have any questions or problems with your work on: 

Employment contract (mini-job, part-time or full-time)
Wage / salary (unpaid working hours)
Working hours / holiday / termination
Insurance, for example, in the event of illness and occupational accident
Job centre or social welfare office?

Then Mira will be happy to advise and support you on your rights!
Counselling is free of charge and confidential and takes place in German and English - in person, by telephone and online.
It is important to Mira that work and training take place under fair conditions and with respect for workers' rights.
They want to enable people from third countries to integrate fairly into the labour market. To this end, Mira informs you about your labour rights and accompanies and supports you in asserting your rights and claims.
The counselling centre mira- mit Recht bei der Arbeit in Stuttgart is a project that aims to counteract the exploitation of third-country nationals and refugees in the labour market.
