title: Work exploitation
excerpt:
Labour exploitation is when labour is exploited under unfair conditions or without the consent of the people concerned.
Slavery and forced labour are prohibited in Germany!Human trafficking for the purpose of labour exploitation or forced sex work is prohibited in Germany!
Other forms of work exploitation are also criminal offences:

Refusing to pay wages despite work being carried out
Longer periods of work than was contractually agreed for the same salary (circumventing the minimum wage)
Refusing to pay additional wages that are due to the worker such as payment in the event of illness or paid holiday

For more information, please contact the following counselling centre.
content:
Labour exploitation is when labour is exploited under unfair conditions or without the consent of the people concerned.

Slavery and forced labour are prohibited in Germany!
Human trafficking for the purpose of labour exploitation or forced sex work is prohibited in Germany!

Other forms of work exploitation are also criminal offences:

  • Refusing to pay wages despite work being carried out
  • Longer periods of work than was contractually agreed for the same salary (circumventing the minimum wage)
  • Refusing to pay additional wages that are due to the worker such as payment in the event of illness or paid holiday

For more information, please contact the following counselling centre.

title: Accident at work
excerpt:
If you have an accident during working hours or on the way to or from work, it is an occupational accident.
In this case, you are insured through the company by an accident insurance .
If you go to the doctor or hospital you must tell them that it’s an accident at work. The treatment is then not paid for by the health insurance company, but by the employer's accident insurance. You can find out the name of the accident insurance company from your employer.
If you have an accident at work and

are unfit for work for more than one day or
require medical treatment for longer or
become ill again at a later date 

you must consult a so-called transit doctor. 
You can find transit doctors on the website of the German Social Accident Insurance (Deutsche Gesetzliche Unfallversicherung)
content:
If you have an accident during working hours or on the way to or from work, it is an occupational accident.

In this case, you are insured through the company by an accident insurance .

If you go to the doctor or hospital you must tell them that it’s an accident at work. The treatment is then not paid for by the health insurance company, but by the employer's accident insurance. You can find out the name of the accident insurance company from your employer.

If you have an accident at work and

  • are unfit for work for more than one day or
  • require medical treatment for longer or
  • become ill again at a later date 

you must consult a so-called transit doctor.

You can find transit doctors on the website of the German Social Accident Insurance (Deutsche Gesetzliche Unfallversicherung)

title: Employment contract
excerpt:
Anyone who starts a job gets an employment contract. The employment contract regulates the most important conditions of an employment relationship such as:

Working hours
Holiday
The amount of salary and
Periods of notice

Both sides - workers and employers - must abide by these agreements.
As the contract becomes legally valid with your signature, you should only sign it when you fully understand the content.
If you later discover that you have signed a contract with which you do not agree after all, you can have the clauses reviewed. A lawyer can help you with this, for example. You can get further support here.
Note:

An employment contract can also be established verbally or tacitly by conclusive conduct!
If you have worked, your employer has to pay you for it, even if there is no written employment contract (yet in place)!

Types of contracts
Permanent job contract (Unbefristeter Arbeitsvertrag)There is usually a probationary period of three or six months. During this period, both the employer and the employee may terminate an employment relationship at short notice within two weeks. At the end of the probationary period, a permanent employment relationship begins with longer protection against dismissal. Working hours are usually up to 40 hours a week.
Fixed-term employment contract (Befristeter Arbeitsvertrag)The employment ends at the agreed time, without the need for notice of resignation.
content:
Anyone who starts a job gets an employment contract. The employment contract regulates the most important conditions of an employment relationship such as:

  • Working hours
  • Holiday
  • The amount of salary and
  • Periods of notice

Both sides - workers and employers - must abide by these agreements.

As the contract becomes legally valid with your signature, you should only sign it when you fully understand the content.

If you later discover that you have signed a contract with which you do not agree after all, you can have the clauses reviewed. A lawyer can help you with this, for example. You can get further support here.

Note:

  • An employment contract can also be established verbally or tacitly by conclusive conduct!
  • If you have worked, your employer has to pay you for it, even if there is no written employment contract (yet in place)!

Types of contracts

Permanent job contract (Unbefristeter Arbeitsvertrag)
There is usually a probationary period of three or six months. During this period, both the employer and the employee may terminate an employment relationship at short notice within two weeks. At the end of the probationary period, a permanent employment relationship begins with longer protection against dismissal. Working hours are usually up to 40 hours a week.

Fixed-term employment contract (Befristeter Arbeitsvertrag)
The employment ends at the agreed time, without the need for notice of resignation.

title: Working times
excerpt:
According to the Working Hours Act, you are not allowed to work more than 8 hours a day.
In exceptional cases, the working time may be extended up to 10 hours if an average of 8 hours per day has not been exceeded within 6 months.
You are entitled to breaks:

From 6 hours upwards, you must take a break of at least 30 minutes.
From 9 hours upwards, you are entitled to a break of at least 45 minutes.
content:
According to the Working Hours Act, you are not allowed to work more than 8 hours a day.

In exceptional cases, the working time may be extended up to 10 hours if an average of 8 hours per day has not been exceeded within 6 months.

You are entitled to breaks:

  • From 6 hours upwards, you must take a break of at least 30 minutes.
  • From 9 hours upwards, you are entitled to a break of at least 45 minutes.

title: Salary statement
excerpt:
If you are employed as a worker, you will receive a pay slip or wage slipafter the first month of work. Some employers will still issue you with a monthly statement after that, others only if something is different in that month than usual (for example, Christmas bonus, increase in insurance contributions).
These details must be shown in the salary statement or payslip:

Name and address of employer
Name, address, date of birth of the employee
Employer's insurance number
Date of beginning the employment
Tax class and tax identification number (Steueridentifikationsnummer)
Accounting period
Gross salary (salary without deductions – gross tax amount and gross social security amount)
Type and amount of surcharges or bonuses
Type and amount of deductionsNet amount (after all deductions)

The net amount is usually the amount you receive. Exception: If there were advance payments, or loans from the company or salary seizure (if you have debts), further amounts will be removed from the net amount.
content:
If you are employed as a worker, you will receive a pay slip or wage slipafter the first month of work. Some employers will still issue you with a monthly statement after that, others only if something is different in that month than usual (for example, Christmas bonus, increase in insurance contributions).

These details must be shown in the salary statement or payslip:

  • Name and address of employer
  • Name, address, date of birth of the employee
  • Employer's insurance number
  • Date of beginning the employment
  • Tax class and tax identification number (Steueridentifikationsnummer)
  • Accounting period
  • Gross salary (salary without deductions – gross tax amount and gross social security amount)
  • Type and amount of surcharges or bonuses
  • Type and amount of deductionsNet amount (after all deductions)

The net amount is usually the amount you receive. Exception: If there were advance payments, or loans from the company or salary seizure (if you have debts), further amounts will be removed from the net amount.

title: Illness
excerpt:
If you are working, doing an internship or attending a German course and are sick, you must call them and report sick. As a rule, your doctor must certify that you are not able to work (certificate of incapacity to work) 
Ask your employer or language course provider when you have to submit a certificate of incapacity to work.
In case of illness, you will be paid for 6 weeks.
From the 7th class You will receive sickness benefit from the health insurance fund for the first week, which is 70%.
Note: Illness is not a form of protection against dismissal!
content:
If you are working, doing an internship or attending a German course and are sick, you must call them and report sick. As a rule, your doctor must certify that you are not able to work (certificate of incapacity to work) 

Ask your employer or language course provider when you have to submit a certificate of incapacity to work.

In case of illness, you will be paid for 6 weeks.

From the 7th class You will receive sickness benefit from the health insurance fund for the first week, which is 70%.

Note: Illness is not a form of protection against dismissal!

title: Handing in your notice
excerpt:
If you want to resign as an employee, you must send the notice in writing, preferably by post, to your employer.
If you have been dismissed by your employer and want to do something about it, you only have 3 weeks. You must file a complaint with the help of a lawyer and/or at the “Rechtsantragsstelle” (Legal Application Office) at the “Arbeitsgericht” (Labour Court).
 The notice period for employers is normally 4 weeks to the end of a month.
The period for employees depends on the duration of the employment relationship.
For example, 5 years --> 2 months' notice
Probationary period up to a maximum of 6 months --> 2 weeks notice period
content:
If you want to resign as an employee, you must send the notice in writing, preferably by post, to your employer.

If you have been dismissed by your employer and want to do something about it, you only have 3 weeks. You must file a complaint with the help of a lawyer and/or at the “Rechtsantragsstelle” (Legal Application Office) at the “Arbeitsgericht” (Labour Court).

The notice period for employers is normally 4 weeks to the end of a month.

The period for employees depends on the duration of the employment relationship.

For example, 5 years --> 2 months' notice

Probationary period up to a maximum of 6 months --> 2 weeks notice period

title: Minimum wage
excerpt:
Germany has a statutory minimum wage. The amount is increased regularly. Since 1 October 2022, the minimum wage has been €12.43.  
The minimum wage may not be reduced by working longer hours than contractually agreed without corresponding wage compensation.
The minimum wage does not apply to:

Young people under the age of 18 without completed vocational training
Apprentices
Long-term unemployed persons during the first six months of their employment after the end of unemployment
Trainees in certain types of internship (school or study-related internship or
Internships for professional orientation up to three months)
Voluntary activities
Self-employed

 You can find more information here.
content:
Germany has a statutory minimum wage. The amount is increased regularly. Since 1 October 2022, the minimum wage has been €12.43.  

The minimum wage may not be reduced by working longer hours than contractually agreed without corresponding wage compensation.

The minimum wage does not apply to:

  • Young people under the age of 18 without completed vocational training
  • Apprentices
  • Long-term unemployed persons during the first six months of their employment after the end of unemployment
  • Trainees in certain types of internship (school or study-related internship or
  • Internships for professional orientation up to three months)
  • Voluntary activities
  • Self-employed


You can find more information here.

title: Minijob
excerpt:
The maximum earnings per month are € 520 and are tax-free.  No contributions have to be paid by the employee to the statutory health insurance and unemployment insurance . You can also be exempted from the obligation to pay pension insurance upon application.
With a mini-job, you acquire only very small entitlements to a later old-age pension. You must arrange your own health insurance, so it is best to seek advice from a statutory health insurance company.
Here you can find more information on this topic.
content:
The maximum earnings per month are € 520 and are tax-free. No contributions have to be paid by the employee to the statutory health insurance and unemployment insurance . You can also be exempted from the obligation to pay pension insurance upon application.

With a mini-job, you acquire only very small entitlements to a later old-age pension. You must arrange your own health insurance, so it is best to seek advice from a statutory health insurance company.

Here you can find more information on this topic.

title: Taxes and social security payments
excerpt:
Every employee in Germany pays a part of his or her wage as taxes and social security contributions. Self-employed persons must also pay taxes.
Income tax
Income tax is a contribution to financing federal, state and local government spending. With the money from taxes, streets and schools are built or social benefits are financed, for example.

If you have an employer (i.e. are “angestellt”), you will receive the net sum of your salary from your employer – in other words, your taxes have already been deducted.
If you are self-employed, you are responsible for your own income tax

Tax ID numberAll working persons receive a “Tax ID number” when they start work. The tax ID is a 11-digit number and is used for income tax. It is valid for the whole of your life. Children born in Germany receive a letter with their personal tax ID within three months after the birth; this is required to apply for child benefit (Kindergeld) for example.
If you work in Germany, you will need the number again and again, for example, for your employer. If you do not know the number, you can ask for it personally at the Meldebehörde (registration office) or in writing from the Bundesamt für Steuern (federal tax office).
Tax returnIn the annual tax return, you can claim various expenses from the Tax Office to reduce the amount of tax you pay. You can receive refunds or you may have to pay additional payments to the Tax Office. Many people are obliged to complete a tax return; it is best to ask the Finanzamt (tax office) if this applies to you.
If you need help with your tax return, you should contact your local taxpayer’s advice centre. If you have further questions, the tax office can also help you.
Social security paymentsSocial security contributions are the contributions to social insurance that employees have to deduct from their gross monthly wage in addition to taxes - this is legally obligatory and is automatically calculated by the employer. Part of social insurance is also paid by the employer.
The social security payments finance the German social insurance system. If people can't find work, or are no longer able to work, their key living costs will still be covered. Ultimately, social contributions serve the personal security of each and every individual - for example, if you become unemployed and have previously paid into unemployment insurance for a certain period of time, you are entitled to unemployment benefit I. Likewise, with your monthly contribution to pension insurance, you acquire a right to receive a state pension in old age.
The contributions to social insurance are made up of payments towards:

Pension insurance
Unemployment insurance
Health Insurance
Long-term care insurance

The amount depends on your individual income. The contributions are automatically deducted from your gross salary.
There are exceptions for foreign workers, for example if they are sent by a foreign company to Germany, work in several countries or are self-employed or affected by other exemptions.
To receive a permanent residence, it’s a requirement that you have paid contributions for at least 60 months into pension insurance. This also applies to self-employed people. There are also exemptions here.
‘Sozialversicherungsnummer’ (social security number)Deutsche Rentenversicherung (the German state pension insurance company) automatically sends you your social security number the first time you take up employment in Germany.
If you lose this number you can request to have it sent to you again:
Telephone number of the Deutsche Rentenversicherung:
  080010004800 (free of charge from the German fixed network)
Additional information: German Pension Insurance
content:
Every employee in Germany pays a part of his or her wage as taxes and social security contributions. Self-employed persons must also pay taxes.

Income tax

Income tax is a contribution to financing federal, state and local government spending. With the money from taxes, streets and schools are built or social benefits are financed, for example.

  • If you have an employer (i.e. are “angestellt”), you will receive the net sum of your salary from your employer – in other words, your taxes have already been deducted.
  • If you are self-employed, you are responsible for your own income tax

Tax ID number
All working persons receive a “Tax ID number” when they start work. The tax ID is a 11-digit number and is used for income tax. It is valid for the whole of your life. Children born in Germany receive a letter with their personal tax ID within three months after the birth; this is required to apply for child benefit (Kindergeld) for example.

If you work in Germany, you will need the number again and again, for example, for your employer. If you do not know the number, you can ask for it personally at the Meldebehörde (registration office) or in writing from the Bundesamt für Steuern (federal tax office).

Tax return
In the annual tax return, you can claim various expenses from the Tax Office to reduce the amount of tax you pay. You can receive refunds or you may have to pay additional payments to the Tax Office. Many people are obliged to complete a tax return; it is best to ask the Finanzamt (tax office) if this applies to you.

If you need help with your tax return, you should contact your local taxpayer’s advice centre. If you have further questions, the tax office can also help you.

Social security payments
Social security contributions are the contributions to social insurance that employees have to deduct from their gross monthly wage in addition to taxes - this is legally obligatory and is automatically calculated by the employer. Part of social insurance is also paid by the employer.

The social security payments finance the German social insurance system. If people can't find work, or are no longer able to work, their key living costs will still be covered. Ultimately, social contributions serve the personal security of each and every individual - for example, if you become unemployed and have previously paid into unemployment insurance for a certain period of time, you are entitled to unemployment benefit I. Likewise, with your monthly contribution to pension insurance, you acquire a right to receive a state pension in old age.

The contributions to social insurance are made up of payments towards:

  • Pension insurance
  • Unemployment insurance
  • Health Insurance
  • Long-term care insurance

The amount depends on your individual income. The contributions are automatically deducted from your gross salary.

There are exceptions for foreign workers, for example if they are sent by a foreign company to Germany, work in several countries or are self-employed or affected by other exemptions.

To receive a permanent residence, it’s a requirement that you have paid contributions for at least 60 months into pension insurance. This also applies to self-employed people. There are also exemptions here.

‘Sozialversicherungsnummer’ (social security number)
Deutsche Rentenversicherung (the German state pension insurance company) automatically sends you your social security number the first time you take up employment in Germany.

If you lose this number you can request to have it sent to you again:

Telephone number of the Deutsche Rentenversicherung:

  080010004800 (free of charge from the German fixed network)

Additional information: German Pension Insurance

title: Self-employment
excerpt:
Do you want to start your own business or work freelance?
You have to consider many things:

The market situation
Legal questions
Administrative guidelines
Financing

Note: If you are only permitted to stay in Germany temporarily, you first need to get permission from the Immigration Office to start a business.
The portal Wir-gründen-in-Deutschland offers helpful information on the topic of starting a business in Germany. The website is offered in 14 languages (Arabic, Bosnian, Chinese, Dari, German, English, French, Polish, Russian, Spanish, Tigrinya, Turkish, Ukrainian, Vietnamese).
Addresses of regional and nationwide advice centres specifically for founders with a migration background can be found on the business start-up portal under "Advice and addresses".
The specialist unit Migrant Economy of the IQ Network also provides information and support to people from abroad in setting up their own business.
For more information, see the online guide for refugees with tips in German and Arabic.
Please enquire at the competent foreigners authority.
content:
Do you want to start your own business or work freelance?

You have to consider many things:

  • The market situation
  • Legal questions
  • Administrative guidelines
  • Financing

Note: If you are only permitted to stay in Germany temporarily, you first need to get permission from the Immigration Office to start a business.

The portal Wir-gründen-in-Deutschland offers helpful information on the topic of starting a business in Germany. The website is offered in 14 languages (Arabic, Bosnian, Chinese, Dari, German, English, French, Polish, Russian, Spanish, Tigrinya, Turkish, Ukrainian, Vietnamese).

Addresses of regional and nationwide advice centres specifically for founders with a migration background can be found on the business start-up portal under "Advice and addresses".

The specialist unit Migrant Economy of the IQ Network also provides information and support to people from abroad in setting up their own business.

For more information, see the online guide for refugees with tips in German and Arabic.

Please enquire at the competent foreigners authority.

title: Overtime
excerpt:
You may only be required to work overtime if it is stipulated in your contract.
Overtime must also be paid.
Instead of a payment, there is also time off in lieu. This must be stipulated in the contract or you as an employee must agree to it.
Important: Always document your working hours daily! So you can always prove how much overtime you have worked.
content:
You may only be required to work overtime if it is stipulated in your contract.

Overtime must also be paid.

Instead of a payment, there is also time off in lieu. This must be stipulated in the contract or you as an employee must agree to it.

Important: Always document your working hours daily! So you can always prove how much overtime you have worked.

title: Holiday
excerpt:
You have at least 24 working days of holiday per year. Working days are from Monday to Saturday. If you work less than 6 days a week, your holiday must be reduced.
In other words:
5-day week: 20 days holiday
4-day week: 16 days holiday
3-day week: 12 days holiday
content:
You have at least 24 working days of holiday per year. Working days are from Monday to Saturday. If you work less than 6 days a week, your holiday must be reduced.

In other words:

5-day week: 20 days holiday

4-day week: 16 days holiday

3-day week: 12 days holiday

title: General information on the health system
General practitioner, paediatrician and specialist
excerpt:
General practitioner 
In every town in Germany, there are doctors who work in a practice rather than a clinic - these are called GPs. If you have health concerns or questions, you first go to a family doctor. To avoid having to wait too long, it is important to make an appointment in advance.
You can choose your own family doctor. As a rule, you do not change your family doctor. There are GPs in almost every town. They set their own opening hours.
GPs carry out important examinations and are your first point of contact in the event of illness.Visit your family doctor if you

are acutely ill (e.g. flu or a cold)
are chronically ill (e.g. diabetes or rheumatism)
are in pain
would like to be vaccinated
are pregnant

GPs decide on the medication you need and whether a specialist examination is necessary. Your GP can also give you a sick note if you are unable to work.
If necessary, your GP will refer you to a specialist who can carry out specialised examinations.
 You can search for a family doctor or a specialist in your area here.  You can also find the foreign-language healthcare services available in the Rems-Murr district  here .
If you cannot find a doctor who speaks your language, you will need to organise an interpreter. Sometimes the costs for professional interpreters can be covered. 
Paediatrician
Children are usually examined by paediatricians. Regular check-ups and vaccinations at the paediatrician are important for the health of every child. The prescribed check-ups are called "U examinations" and are always free of charge and at a specific time.
When registering at a day care centre, proof of complete screening examinations may be requested.
If your child is ill and cannot go to school, the paediatrician can issue a certificate.
Important! Your child must be vaccinated against measles when attending a day care centre or school.
Specialist doctor
If you need a specialised doctor, your family doctor will refer you to a specialist. They can carry out specialised examinations.

Women's health
It is important that women are regularly examined by a gynaecologist. This allows diseases to be recognised in good time. This is called a check-up. You can also discuss the topic of contraception there.
Further information on this topic:
Video │ Good to know - Visit to the gynaecologist │ Media centre of GWA St.Pauli e.V.German ⋅  Arabic ⋅ English ⋅  Farsi ⋅ Turkish

Men's health
The urologist and urologist are responsible, among other things, for diseases of the male reproductive organs and for preventive examinations.
You can find more information about men's healthhere.

Dental health
If you have a toothache, go to a dentist. Regular check-ups at the dentist are important for your dental health.
You can find more information on dental healthhere.
content:
General practitioner

In every town in Germany, there are doctors who work in a practice rather than a clinic - these are called GPs. If you have health concerns or questions, you first go to a family doctor. To avoid having to wait too long, it is important to make an appointment in advance.

You can choose your own family doctor. As a rule, you do not change your family doctor. There are GPs in almost every town. They set their own opening hours.

GPs carry out important examinations and are your first point of contact in the event of illness.
Visit your family doctor if you

  • are acutely ill (e.g. flu or a cold)
  • are chronically ill (e.g. diabetes or rheumatism)
  • are in pain
  • would like to be vaccinated
  • are pregnant

GPs decide on the medication you need and whether a specialist examination is necessary.
Your GP can also give you a sick note if you are unable to work.

If necessary, your GP will refer you to a specialist who can carry out specialised examinations.

You can search for a family doctor or a specialist in your area here.
You can also find the foreign-language healthcare services available in the Rems-Murr district here .

If you cannot find a doctor who speaks your language, you will need to organise an interpreter. Sometimes the costs for professional interpreters can be covered.

Paediatrician

Children are usually examined by paediatricians. Regular check-ups and vaccinations at the paediatrician are important for the health of every child. The prescribed check-ups are called "U examinations" and are always free of charge and at a specific time.

When registering at a day care centre, proof of complete screening examinations may be requested.

If your child is ill and cannot go to school, the paediatrician can issue a certificate.

Important! Your child must be vaccinated against measles when attending a day care centre or school.

Specialist doctor

If you need a specialised doctor, your family doctor will refer you to a specialist. They can carry out specialised examinations.

Women's health

It is important that women are regularly examined by a gynaecologist. This allows diseases to be recognised in good time. This is called a check-up. You can also discuss the topic of contraception there.

Further information on this topic:

Video │ Good to know - Visit to the gynaecologist │ Media centre of GWA St.Pauli e.V.
German ⋅ Arabic ⋅ English ⋅ Farsi ⋅ Turkish

Men's health

The urologist and urologist are responsible, among other things, for diseases of the male reproductive organs and for preventive examinations.

You can find more information about men's healthhere.

Dental health

If you have a toothache, go to a dentist. Regular check-ups at the dentist are important for your dental health.

You can find more information on dental healthhere.

title: Health insurance and health insurance
excerpt:
In Germany, insurance is compulsory. This means you have to be a member of a health insurance fund to see a doctor.As soon as you have a residence title , you must register with a regular health insurance fund. You can choose and change the health insurance company yourself.You will receive an insurance card from the health insurance company and are thus entitled to the same services as all residents in Germany. Always take the insurance card with you to your appointments with the doctors.Here you will find an overview of the health insurance funds in Germany.
The basic medical care provided by the health insurance company includes:

Services to prevent and alleviate diseases
Services during pregnancy
Services for the detection of diseases
Services for the treatment of diseases


Costs
If you go to see a doctor, please present your health insurance card. With this, most examinations are free of charge foryou.You must pay for certain preventive medical checkups yourself.For therapies (for example, physiotherapy) and aids (for example, bandages) you have to pay a contribution yourself.People who have limited funds can be exempted from this. Please ask your health insurance company about this.
The costs of dental treatment are paid by the health insurance. If a tooth needs to be renewed or replaced, you will have to pay for part of it yourself.
The costs of hospital treatment are also paid by the health insurance company. However, you have to pay a daily hospital allowance of € 10 for each dayspent in hospital. People who have limited funds can be exempted from this.
content:
In Germany, insurance is compulsory. This means you have to be a member of a health insurance fund to see a doctor.
As soon as you have a residence title , you must register with a regular health insurance fund. You can choose and change the health insurance company yourself.
You will receive an insurance card from the health insurance company and are thus entitled to the same services as all residents in Germany. Always take the insurance card with you to your appointments with the doctors.
Here you will find an overview of the health insurance funds in Germany.

The basic medical care provided by the health insurance company includes:

  • Services to prevent and alleviate diseases
  • Services during pregnancy
  • Services for the detection of diseases
  • Services for the treatment of diseases

Costs

If you go to see a doctor, please present your health insurance card. With this, most examinations are free of charge foryou.
You must pay for certain preventive medical checkups yourself.
For therapies (for example, physiotherapy) and aids (for example, bandages) you have to pay a contribution yourself.
People who have limited funds can be exempted from this. Please ask your health insurance company about this.

The costs of dental treatment are paid by the health insurance. If a tooth needs to be renewed or replaced, you will have to pay for part of it yourself.

The costs of hospital treatment are also paid by the health insurance company. However, you have to pay a daily hospital allowance of € 10 for each dayspent in hospital. People who have limited funds can be exempted from this.

title: Treatment certificate for asylum seekers
excerpt:
Persons in the ongoing asylum procedure need a health insurance voucher or a dental treatment voucherfor medical treatment. This is always valid for 3 months. You can obtain the respective treatment voucher from the benefits officer of the asylum seeker benefits department at the Rems-Murr District Office.
If you are going to see a doctor, please show the treatment certificate.
You are entitled to:

Services to prevent and alleviate illness and pain
Services during pregnancy
Services for the detection of diseases
Services for the treatment of diseases

If you have a residence permit , you must register with a health insurance fund.
content:
Persons in the ongoing asylum procedure need a health insurance voucher or a dental treatment voucherfor medical treatment. This is always valid for 3 months. You can obtain the respective treatment voucher from the benefits officer of the asylum seeker benefits department at the Rems-Murr District Office.

If you are going to see a doctor, please show the treatment certificate.

You are entitled to:

  • Services to prevent and alleviate illness and pain
  • Services during pregnancy
  • Services for the detection of diseases
  • Services for the treatment of diseases

If you have a residence permit , you must register with a health insurance fund.

title: Pharmacy and medicines
excerpt:
Pharmacies (Apotheken)
In Germany, you canonly get medicinesin pharmacies. In other shops or in the doctor's office you will not get any medicine.
Every pharmacy can be recognised from the outside by the red A. 
Pharmacies are openfrom Monday to Saturday. The opening times vary according to each chemist. If you urgently need medication outside normal opening hours, you will find a sign at every chemist with the name and address of the chemist which is open for emergencies.
 

 Search for pharmacies near you
 Search pharmacy emergency service 
 
Medication
There are prescription and over-the-counter drugs.
You can only getprescription medicines if a doctor issues a prescription. Prescription drugs are, for example, drugs for high blood pressure or diabetes and all antibiotics for bacterial infections.
You can getover-the-counter medicines at the pharmacy without a prescription. So you don't have to see a doctor beforehand. Over-the-counter drugs are, for example, drugs for colds and many drugs for pain.
Recipe colours:

Pink: This is the colour of the prescription sheet for people with statutory health insurance. Such a prescription is valid for 28 days.
Green: On these prescription sheets, doctors recommend over-the-counter medicines. Such a prescription is valid indefinitely.
Blue:  This is the prescription sheet for privately insured persons. Such a prescription is valid for three months in most cases.
Yellow: Narcotics are prescribed on these prescriptions, for example strong painkillers.  Such a prescription is valid for 7 days.
Cost of medicinesStatutory health insurance: Drugs (pink prescription) are partly paid by health insurance companies. You have to pay a co-payment of at least 5 € yourself. You do not have to pay this for children up to 18 years of age. Medicines that do not require a prescription (for example, cough syrup) must be paid for by yourself (green or blue prescription).
Health care for asylum seekers: Even with a prescription, not all medicines are free. Therefore, check with your doctor.

Blue:  This is the prescription sheet for privately insured persons. Such a prescription is valid for three months in most cases.

title: Protection provided by vaccination
excerpt:
Many diseases are caused by bacteria or viruses. Vaccinations are a good measure to protect yourself. If many people are vaccinated against a certain disease, further spread is prevented.
In Germany, there are recommendations on when which vaccinations should be given. Several vaccinations are necessary against some diseases. The recommended vaccinations are paid for by the health insurance companies. If you have a vaccination document, you should show it when you visit your doctor. Then they can decide which vaccinations are required. If you do not have one, your doctor will issue you with a "vaccination card".  Keep this document in a safe place. You should take it with you to every doctor's appointment.
Get your children vaccinated too. This will protect you and your family from diseases such as measles, rubella, polio, tetanus, whooping cough or influenza.
Here you will find multilingual information on which vaccinations are recommended by the Standing Committee on Vaccination (STIKO).

Measles vaccination
Important! Your child must be vaccinated against measles when attending a day care centre or school.
The measles protection law in Germany states that all children over the age of one must have two measles vaccinations when they enter kindergarten, day care or school.
Persons born after 1970 who live in communal facilities for asylum seekers and refugees must also provide proof of appropriate vaccination protection no later than four weeks after moving into the communal accommodation.
 Here you will find information in several languages.

title: Life threatening emergency
excerpt:
Police:  110
Fire brigade:  112
Ambulance, emergency doctor:  112
Important! Only for life-threatening emergencies and accidents  
 The emergency numbers of the mobile phones always work, even with a prepaid card without credit/money.
Important information for an emergency call:

Who is calling (your name)?
Where did the incident occur (address)?
What happened?
How many people are injured or sick?
What kind of diseases or injuries are present?
Wait for questions!

Stay calm. Speak slowly and clearly so that you can be understood better. Do not end the conversation. The emergency call centre will end the call when it has all important information.
Also, always get other people around you involved if you need help. Never put yourself in harm’s way. If you are able, always provide first aid, or call someone who can.
Life-threatening emergencies are, for example:

severe shortness of breath
unconsciousness
heavily bleeding wounds
heart troubles
suspected stroke
symptoms of paralysis
complications during pregnancy
poisonings
Severe pain

Important! Don't forget your ID card / proof of arrival when you go to the hospital! If you are already registered with a health insurance company, bring your insurance card with you.
 As an asylum seeker, you may also go to hospital without a treatment certificate in the event of an emergency. At the hospital you have to show that you are an asylum seeker with your proof of arrival.
content:
Police: 110

Fire brigade: 112

Ambulance, emergency doctor: 112


Important! Only for life-threatening emergencies and accidents  

The emergency numbers of the mobile phones always work, even with a prepaid card without credit/money.

Important information for an emergency call:

  • Who is calling (your name)?
  • Where did the incident occur (address)?
  • What happened?
  • How many people are injured or sick?
  • What kind of diseases or injuries are present?
  • Wait for questions!

Stay calm. Speak slowly and clearly so that you can be understood better. Do not end the conversation. The emergency call centre will end the call when it has all important information.

Also, always get other people around you involved if you need help. Never put yourself in harm’s way. If you are able, always provide first aid, or call someone who can.

Life-threatening emergencies are, for example:

  • severe shortness of breath
  • unconsciousness
  • heavily bleeding wounds
  • heart troubles
  • suspected stroke
  • symptoms of paralysis
  • complications during pregnancy
  • poisonings
  • Severe pain

Important! Don't forget your ID card / proof of arrival when you go to the hospital! If you are already registered with a health insurance company, bring your insurance card with you.

As an asylum seeker, you may also go to hospital without a treatment certificate in the event of an emergency. At the hospital you have to show that you are an asylum seeker with your proof of arrival.

In such cases, contact your family doctor or specialist.
If you need a doctor in the evening, at night or at the weekend, but it is not an emergency, call the medical on-call service.  If you cannot come to the practice, a doctor will drive to your home.

title: What do I do in an emergency?
excerpt:
If you need help very quickly in an emergency situation, the emergency numbers will help you.
You can also call the telephone pastoral care service (“Telefon-Seelsorge”). There you will be advised directly on the phone: 08001110111 and  08001110222The call is free and you can always call. You do not have to say your name and you will not be asked for it.
For children and young people, there is the number for those struggling with worries or concerns: 116111
What can you do in the event of an acute mental health crisis?
 Anyone can have a mental health crisis - no matter how old they are, how they live or where they come from. You can have a crisis because something very bad has happened to you (for example, someone has died, you are in great danger war...). You can also have a crisis if you have been experiencing bad things for a long time or are seriously mentally ill (for example, have depression or anxiety disorders).
 In an emergency, call 112.
If you have a crisis or think you want to die, you can also always go to a hospital - day and night and at weekends.
For the Rems-Murr district
Centre for Mental Health Winnenden
Winnenden Castle HospitalSchloßstraße 50, 71364 Winnenden 071959000 info@zfp-winnenden.de
The following offers are available here:

Outpatient offers
Partial inpatient offers
Inpatient offers

You can find more information here.

title: Addictive disorders
excerpt:
Addiction is an illness!
An addiction is a dependency on substances (e.g. alcohol, drugs, nicotine, medication) or behaviour (e.g. gambling addiction, shopping addiction). Addiction can affect anyone. Seeking help has nothing to do with personal failure.
When you are addicted, you think almost exclusively about the addictive substance. You can no longer control your own consumption. Relationships and work performance often deteriorate as a result.
What help is available?
Professional support
You can get professional support from specialists in addiction counselling centres.
There are the following counselling centres in the district:
Addiction counselling Kreisdiakonieverband:
 Waiblingen, Schorndorf, Welzheim and Fellbach - there is also an online counselling service Addiction counselling (kdv-rmk.de)
Caritas addiction counselling
 Backnang - there is also online counselling Addiction counselling (caritas-ludwigsburg-waiblingen-enz.de)
Addiction counselling Jobcenter
 Waiblingen job centre Addiction counselling - Rems-Murr job centre (jobcenter-rems-murr.de)
Young people
There is also a special addiction counselling service for young people under 28
 Waiblingen, Backnang, Schorndorf HORIZONT - youth and drug help centre in the Rems-Murr district (drogenhilfe-horizont.de)
Addiction officer of the district
 Backnang Addiction officer: Rems-Murr district
Self-help groups 
Those affected strengthen each other in self-help groups. The groups work anonymously in some cases and help all those affected in difficult situations.
General information on self-help groups in the Rems-Murr district can be found here.
Counselling for refugees and migrants affected by addiction
Information material and multilingual brochures on the subject of addiction can be found here.
Important information
The counselling centres are free of charge. The counselling sessions are confidential and the information discussed will not be passed on to the police. If you wish, the counselling is anonymous.

title: HIV/AIDS and sexually transmitted infections
excerpt:
HIV is the abbreviation for a virus. If you get very sick from the virus, it means: AIDS. Sexually transmitted infections are diseases that are transmitted during sex.
On these websites you will find information in several languages on the topic of HIV and AIDS:
 HIV and AIDS | Zanzu
 Materials | AIDS-Hilfe Potsdam e.V. - We promote health. (aidshilfe-potsdam.de)
Counselling on HIV / AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases at the Rems-Murr District Health Office
The AIDS counselling centres of the health offices provide advice on AIDS/HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases such as hepatitis B, C, syphilis, gonorrhoea or chlamydia.
 Counselling is confidential, free of charge and anonymous. The public health department is bound by professional secrecy.
The Rems-Murr district health office also offers a free and anonymous HIV antibody test.
Consultations take place in Waiblingen and Backnang.
All contact details and further information can be found here.

title: Care support point
excerpt:
At the care support point, people in need of care as well as their families receive free information on the topic of care.
They deal with many questions:

How do I get a care degree?
How can care be organised at home?
Where can I get relief?
What additional or relieving help is available in my area?
What can I do about forgetfulness and dementia?
Can I cope with the physical and mental strain of caring for my relative?of caring for my relative?
What financial support can I get?

Tasks

The care support point offers free and individual counselling to all those seeking advice and help on all questions prior to and in the context of care.
The care support point offers guidance and decision-making aids on all aspects of care.
The care support point is subject to professional secrecy and data protection is our highest priority.
Counselling can take place by telephone, in person and in the environment of the person in need of care.

title: Self-help groups
excerpt:
What are self-help groups?
Self-help groups are self-organised groups of people who have the same problem or illness and want to do something together to get better.
What happens in a self-help group?

The participants exchange ideas and information. Examples: How do other sufferers deal with the illness or problem in certain situations in everyday life? What information is available on certain illnesses or problems?
The participants support and help each other.

Self-help groups are no substitute for medicine or therapy. But they are a very good and important addition. What is said in the self-help groups is confidential. Everything is voluntary, nobody is forced.
Which groups are there?
Here you can find out more about the self-help groups in the Rems-Murr district.
Self-help contact centre district office
The task of the advice centre is to support self-help in the Rems-Murr district in a variety of ways. Further information and contact details can be found here.
 selbsthilfe@rems-murr-kreis.de

title: Counselling for people in prostitution
excerpt:
The Prostitute Protection Act (ProstSchG; Prostituiertenschutzgesetz) has been in force in Germany since July 1, 2017. This law is intended to better regulate the protection of prostitutes.
This law regulates, among other things, that all prostitutes must register with the health office before they start working. For this you need certain information and documents. For example, you need proof of health consultation according to § 10 ProstSchG. This takes place in the health office of the district administration.
You can make an appointment for a consultation here:District Office Rems-Murr-KreisGesundheitsamt (Health Department) p-beratung@rems-murr-kreis.de
 Health Department website
Further information on the Prostitution Protection Act in Baden-Württemberg can be found in different languages at www.bleibsafe.info.

title: Counselling regarding female genital mutilation
excerpt:
In Germany, female genital mutilation (FGM)is prohibited. Since September 2013, FGM has been punishable with imprisonment. Parents are also not allowed to leave the country to have their daughter circumcised abroad. This is also punishable under German law. Girls and young women can apply for asylum if they are in danger of being cut.
Many girls die during genital mutilation or from its consequences. There are also many dangerous after-effects of mutilation.
If you have been affected or threatened by genital mutilation, contact the help hotline at  08000116016. The help hotline staff are there for you day and night and in different languages. 
In Germany, it is possible to get clitoral reconstruction surgery. This operation can be performed by plastic surgeons. Ask a gynaecologist (women’s doctor) for advice.
You can find more information in the official protection letter of the Federal Government in several languages.
Contact details 
In Göppingen there is a central contact point for women with FGM.
 News - FGM/C Central Contact Point Baden-Württemberg (fgmc-bw.de)

title: Domestic violence
excerpt:
Domestic violence includes all forms of physical, sexual and/or psychological violence between persons in a mostly domestic community.
It does not matter whether the persons live together in a marriage, a registered partnership or just because, which sexual orientation is present or whether it is a community of several generations. The scene of the crime can also be outside the home, for example on the street, in the shop and at the workplace, but often the home itself is the scene of the crime.
No one has to endure when she or he

is humiliated, insulted, beaten or threatened,
is prevented from leaving the house,
from meeting family, relatives, girlfriends or friends,
is forced to have sex,
Separation or wishes for separation are not accepted,
is persecuted, harassed or terrorised.


Victim counselling Rems-Murr district
The counselling service is confidential, free of charge and personalised to you. The victim counselling counsels persons of all genders and ages.
 info@opferberatung-rems-murr.de 08000116016
 opferberatung-rems-murr.de

Helpline for women experiencing violence
Women affected by violence can find support at the help line. At the request of a caller, the counsellors will call in an interpreter in the required language within one minute.
Free, anonymous and confidential counselling is available in 18 foreign languages. 
You can receive advice by phone, chat or email.
 08000116016 
 Help hotline "Violence against women

Women and child protection centre
The Women's and Children's Shelter offers protection for women affected by domestic violence and their children.
 071919308655 frauenhaus@drk-rems-murr.de
 Further information and contact details can be found here.

title: Information about Coronavirus
excerpt:
The federal government has issued new rules as of 01 October 2022. There are some general rules. In addition, the federal states have the possibility to impose additional rules. You may do this if an overload of the health system or critical infrastructure could occur. Please inform yourself about possible additional rules in your federal state. In general, the following recommendations and rules apply:
Rules for public life

Keep at least 1.5 to 2 metres away from other people in public.
Wearing a medical mask in public is generally recommended.
The number of contacts should be kept as constant and low as possible.

Clinics, old people's homes and care servicesMasks are compulsory for access to hospitals and full and partial inpatient care facilities. They must therefore wear an FFP2 mask, as the residents and patients in these facilities are particularly at risk. Employees in outpatient care services must wear a mask during their work.
Medical practicesPatients and visitors may only enter doctors' surgeries, dentists' surgeries, dialysis facilities and other health care facilities wearing FFP2 masks.
Quarantine rulesIn quarantine, a distinction is made between isolation for infected personsand quarantine for contact persons.
As a contact person, you no longer have to be quarantined, regardless of your vaccination status, since 01 May 2022.
There is no longer an obligation to isolate infected persons. Depending on the federal state, there are different measures for infected persons. Please find out what applies in your federal state.
Entry requirements
You can find more information on this on the page of the Federal Ministry of Health.
How do I protect myself and others from the Corona virus?

Washing hands regularly and for a sufficient length of time (at least 20 seconds under running water with soap)
proper coughing and sneezing into a handkerchief or the crook of the arm
Keep your distance from people with coughs, colds or fever
Do not shake hands
Keep your hands away from your face

How do I act when I have symptoms?Should citizens experience symptoms of illness such as cough, fever or shortness of breath, they should:

call 116117 (telephone number of the medical on-call service)
contact the local health department by telephone. You can find the contact details here: https://www.rki.de/mein-gesundheitsamt
contact your GP by telephone

The doctor will talk to you. If corona virus is suspected, you will be further observed and treated.
More information, also in other languages, is available at:
 www.rki.de www.bundesregierung.de www.bundesgesundheitsministerium.de www.infektionsschutz.de www.who.int www.integrationsbeauftragte.de/corona-virus
content:
The federal government has issued new rules as of 01 October 2022. There are some general rules. In addition, the federal states have the possibility to impose additional rules. You may do this if an overload of the health system or critical infrastructure could occur. Please inform yourself about possible additional rules in your federal state. In general, the following recommendations and rules apply:

Rules for public life

  • Keep at least 1.5 to 2 metres away from other people in public.
  • Wearing a medical mask in public is generally recommended.
  • The number of contacts should be kept as constant and low as possible.

Clinics, old people's homes and care services
Masks are compulsory for access to hospitals and full and partial inpatient care facilities. They must therefore wear an FFP2 mask, as the residents and patients in these facilities are particularly at risk. Employees in outpatient care services must wear a mask during their work.

Medical practices
Patients and visitors may only enter doctors' surgeries, dentists' surgeries, dialysis facilities and other health care facilities wearing FFP2 masks.

Quarantine rules
In quarantine, a distinction is made between isolation for infected personsand quarantine for contact persons.

As a contact person, you no longer have to be quarantined, regardless of your vaccination status, since 01 May 2022.

There is no longer an obligation to isolate infected persons. Depending on the federal state, there are different measures for infected persons. Please find out what applies in your federal state.

Entry requirements

You can find more information on this on the page of the Federal Ministry of Health.

How do I protect myself and others from the Corona virus?

  • Washing hands regularly and for a sufficient length of time (at least 20 seconds under running water with soap)
  • proper coughing and sneezing into a handkerchief or the crook of the arm
  • Keep your distance from people with coughs, colds or fever
  • Do not shake hands
  • Keep your hands away from your face

How do I act when I have symptoms?
Should citizens experience symptoms of illness such as cough, fever or shortness of breath, they should:

  • call 116117 (telephone number of the medical on-call service)
  • contact the local health department by telephone. You can find the contact details here: https://www.rki.de/mein-gesundheitsamt
  • contact your GP by telephone

The doctor will talk to you. If corona virus is suspected, you will be further observed and treated.

More information, also in other languages, is available at:

www.rki.de
www.bundesregierung.de
www.bundesgesundheitsministerium.de
www.infektionsschutz.de
www.who.int
www.integrationsbeauftragte.de/corona-virus

title: Important information about pregnancy
excerpt:
First appointment with the gynaecologist
Pregnant women in Germany are under special protection and are entitled to counselling, medical care and support with new purchases for the child. If you are pregnant, you must first visit your gynaecologist. Have the check-ups carried out there. You will then receive a maternity pass. The maternity record is a document containing important information about your pregnancy, your health and that of your child. Always take your maternity pass with you in case of emergencies.
Maternity protection for working pregnant women
Working pregnant women have special protection - known as maternity protection. Maternity protection begins 6 weeks before the birth and ends 8 weeks afterwards. This protection is regulated by law in Germany. During this time, pregnant women are generally not allowed to work. Your job remains the same and you can return to work at the end of your maternity leave. In addition, pregnant women are not allowed to work more than 8.5 hours a day and are not allowed to carry out heavy physical labour. 
Midwife
Midwives support women and their families from the beginning of pregnancy to the end of the breastfeeding period. Midwives provide counselling during pregnancy, can help with the birth, introduce breastfeeding after the birth and also take care of the woman's physical and psychological recovery. Any woman can call on the help of a midwife. Most services are covered by health insurance.
 Website of the Midwives' Association in German and English
 Here you can find a midwife in the Rems-Murr district
Pregnancy counselling
Women and men can obtain free and anonymous advice on all questions, issues and changes relating to pregnancy and family planning. Regardless of whether they need medical or legal information, for example. The counselling service is also available for mothers and young families after the birth of a child. Women and men with an unfulfilled desire to have children can also seek counselling.
Counselling centres Rems-Murr-Kreis:
 Rem-Murr district office 071515011611 schwanger@rems-murr-kreis.de
 pro familia Waiblingen 07151982248940 waiblingen@profamilia.de
Financial support
If you have little or no income, you can apply for unemployment benefit II or assistance under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act (AsylbLG). After the twelfth week of pregnancy, the  job centre or social welfare office will then pay expectant mothers additional needs and initial equipment for pregnancy and baby.
Child benefit
As a rule, all children in Germany are entitled to child benefit from birth until they reach the age of 18. In individual cases, the entitlement may last longer.
Parental allowance
Many parents want to look after their child after the birth. To do this, they do not work for a certain period of time. Or they only work part-time. Parental allowance is paid during this time.

First appointment with the gynaecologist

Pregnant women in Germany are under special protection and are entitled to counselling, medical care and support with new purchases for the child. The maternity record is a document containing important information about your pregnancy, your health and that of your child. Always take your maternity pass with you in case of emergencies.

This protection is regulated by law in Germany. During this time, pregnant women are generally not allowed to work. Your job remains the same and you can return to work at the end of your maternity leave. In addition, pregnant women are not allowed to work more than 8.5 hours a day and are not allowed to carry out heavy physical labour.

Midwives provide counselling during pregnancy, can help with the birth, introduce breastfeeding after the birth and also take care of the woman's physical and psychological recovery. Any woman can call on the help of a midwife. Most services are covered by health insurance.

Website of the Midwives' Association in German and English


Here you can find a midwife in the Rems-Murr district

Regardless of whether they need medical or legal information, for example. The counselling service is also available for mothers and young families after the birth of a child. Child benefit

title: After giving birth
excerpt:
Registration registry office
Newborn children must be registered with the  “Standesamt” (Registry Office) and, if necessary, your accommodation management team. The maternity clinic reports the birth to the Registry Office. There you will receive the birth certificate for your child together with your ID card, the birth certificate from the clinic and, if available, your marriage certificate.
Please submit only original documents. For documents in a foreign language, an officially certified German translation is required.
If you live in shared accommodation, please provide a copy of the birth certificate to your accommodation facility management so that your child can be registered.
Find a paediatrician
When the baby is born, it is advisable to make an appointment immediately with a paediatrician for a U3 examination.  The U3 examination is one of 12 preventive examinations for children. It is carried out between the 3rd and 8th grade. Week of life. These examinations are very important and must be carried out.
 It is advisable to make an appointment as soon as possible, as long waiting times are to be expected when appointments are made.
 Here you can find a brochure on the subject of U-examination in different languages.

Financial support
Those who have no or only a low income can apply for unemployment benefit II or assistance under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act (AsylbLG). After the twelfth week of pregnancy, theJob Centre or the Social Welfare Office then pay mothers-to-be additional needs and the initial equipment for pregnancy and baby.
Claim child benefitAll children in Germany are entitled to a child benefit from birth until the age of 18. (or even later, in exceptional cases). Your child must live in your household and be cared for by yourself. 
You can get more information here.
content:
Registration registry office

Newborn children must be registered with the  “Standesamt” (Registry Office) and, if necessary, your accommodation management team. The maternity clinic reports the birth to the Registry Office. There you will receive the birth certificate for your child together with your ID card, the birth certificate from the clinic and, if available, your marriage certificate.

Please submit only original documents. For documents in a foreign language, an officially certified German translation is required.

If you live in shared accommodation, please provide a copy of the birth certificate to your accommodation facility management so that your child can be registered.

Find a paediatrician

When the baby is born, it is advisable to make an appointment immediately with a paediatrician for a U3 examination. The U3 examination is one of 12 preventive examinations for children. It is carried out between the 3rd and 8th grade. Week of life. These examinations are very important and must be carried out.

It is advisable to make an appointment as soon as possible, as long waiting times are to be expected when appointments are made.

Here you can find a brochure on the subject of U-examination in different languages.

After the twelfth week of pregnancy, theJob Centre or the Social Welfare Office then pay mothers-to-be additional needs and the initial equipment for pregnancy and baby.

Claim child benefit
All children in Germany are entitled to a child benefit from birth until the age of 18. (or even later, in exceptional cases). Your child must live in your household and be cared for by yourself.

You can get more information here.

title: Sexual counselling and contraception
excerpt:
Family planning
Everyone decides for themselves how and with whom they want to have sex. In the same way, you decide for yourself whether, when and how many children you want to have. You can also say that you have the right to family planning and sexual self-determination.
You can find multilingual information on the subject of sexuality at www.zanzu.de

Sexual counselling
At a sexual counselling session, you can talk about your sexuality in a protected environment. Questions about your body, sexual orientation, but also experiences of sexual violence can be discussed.
You can find more information here: www.zanzu.de
Counselling centre
 Pro Familia Waiblingen
 07151982248940 waiblingen@profamilia.de

Contraception
There are various methods if you don't want to get pregnant or want to prevent infection with sexually transmitted diseases. For example, barrier methods such as the condom, or methods with hormones such as the pill.
You can find multilingual information on the subject of contraception at
 www.zanzu.de  www.profamilia.de
 A condom protects against sexually transmitted diseases such as HIV.
 You can find out about contraceptive methods from a gynaecologist.
Emergency contraception:If you have sexual intercourse without contraception, there is a possibility that you will become pregnant, even if you do not want to. Mistakes can also happen when using contraception. Then you will become pregnant despite using contraception. In these cases, you can take the "morning after pill". You must take it as soon as possible, preferably in the first twelve hours after sexual intercourse. You can buy the morning-after pill from a pharmacy without a prescription. You can get advice on this at a pharmacy or from a doctor.
content:
Family planning

Everyone decides for themselves how and with whom they want to have sex. In the same way, you decide for yourself whether, when and how many children you want to have. You can also say that you have the right to family planning and sexual self-determination.

You can find multilingual information on the subject of sexuality at
www.zanzu.de

Sexual counselling

At a sexual counselling session, you can talk about your sexuality in a protected environment. Questions about your body, sexual orientation, but also experiences of sexual violence can be discussed.

You can find more information here: www.zanzu.de

Counselling centre

Pro Familia Waiblingen

07151982248940
waiblingen@profamilia.de

Contraception

There are various methods if you don't want to get pregnant or want to prevent infection with sexually transmitted diseases. For example, barrier methods such as the condom, or methods with hormones such as the pill.

You can find multilingual information on the subject of contraception at

www.zanzu.de
www.profamilia.de

A condom protects against sexually transmitted diseases such as HIV.

You can find out about contraceptive methods from a gynaecologist.

Emergency contraception:
If you have sexual intercourse without contraception, there is a possibility that you will become pregnant, even if you do not want to. Mistakes can also happen when using contraception. Then you will become pregnant despite using contraception.
In these cases, you can take the "morning after pill". You must take it as soon as possible, preferably in the first twelve hours after sexual intercourse. You can buy the morning-after pill from a pharmacy without a prescription. You can get advice on this at a pharmacy or from a doctor.

title: Unintended pregnancy
excerpt:
You can use contraceptive methods to avoid an unwanted pregnancy.If you are not planning to become pregnant, it is particularly important that you seek help and advice. You should find out about different options.
You can find multilingual information here.
Termination of pregnancy
You can terminate the pregnancy with an abortion.Termination of pregnancy is possible up to the twelfth week of pregnancy. Before that, you must go to a pregnancy conflict counselling centre and have a consultation.
Pregnancy conflict counselling:
 pro familia Waiblingen 07151982248940 waiblingen@profamilia.de
 Rems-Murr district office  071515011611 or 071515011622 schwanger@rems-murr-kreis.de
 The help hotline "Pregnant women in need - anonymous and safe" at  0800 40 40 020 is available free of charge 24 hours a day. Counselling is available in many languages with the help of an interpreter.You can also get information about a pregnancy counselling centre near you. They will provide you with anonymous and free counselling and support you in all further steps.
There is a brochure in several languages on the subject of abortion.
Adoption
You can continue the pregnancy and give the baby up for adoption.
In Germany, women can have their baby in hospital without having to give their name. After the birth, the mother leaves the hospital. The baby is given up for adoption after a certain period of time. You can find helpful information under "Confidential counselling and birth".
Baby hatch
It is also possible to hand over the child to the baby hatch. The baby hatch offers help for mothers and their newborn babies who find themselves in extremely difficult and seemingly hopeless situations.
There is a baby hatch in Stuttgart.

title: Child benefit and parental allowance
excerpt:
Child benefit
All children in Germany are entitled to child benefit from birth until they reach the age of 18. In individual cases, this can also be up to the age of 25. Your child must live in your household and be cared for by you.
Child benefit is only paid to one person at a time, usually one parent. If you have several children, the individual amounts are paid out as one sum. Often, you will receive at least € 250 per month for each child.
If you have several children, the number of children determines the amount of child benefit. From the third child onwards, you are entitled to more child benefit.
How do I get child benefit?
You must submit an application to the Family Benefits Office (Familienkasse) of the Federal Employment Agency (Bundesagentur für Arbeit). Please also contact your benefit provider (job centre or district office) for more information.
 The application and further information on child benefit
Note for asylum seekers: You cannot receive child benefit during the asylum procedure. This is only possible after you have received a positive decision from the BAMF.
Responsible for the Rems-Murr district: Familienkasse Baden-Württemberg-Ost (family benefits office).
Parental allowance
Many parents want to take care of their child after the birth. To do so, you do not work for a certain period of time.Or you only work part-time. 
If you have applied for parental allowance, you can get at least 300 € every month. But it can also be more. You usually get parental allowance for 12 months. But it can also be longer.
You get parental allowance if you have a residence and stay in Germany. You need a residence permit. You must live together with your child.
 The application and further information on parental allowanceApply for parental allowance digitally
content:
Child benefit

All children in Germany are entitled to child benefit from birth until they reach the age of 18. In individual cases, this can also be up to the age of 25. Your child must live in your household and be cared for by you.

Child benefit is only paid to one person at a time, usually one parent. If you have several children, the individual amounts are paid out as one sum. Often, you will receive at least € 250 per month for each child.

If you have several children, the number of children determines the amount of child benefit. From the third child onwards, you are entitled to more child benefit.

How do I get child benefit?

You must submit an application to the Family Benefits Office (Familienkasse) of the Federal Employment Agency (Bundesagentur für Arbeit). Please also contact your benefit provider (job centre or district office) for more information.

The application and further information on child benefit

Note for asylum seekers: You cannot receive child benefit during the asylum procedure. This is only possible after you have received a positive decision from the BAMF.

Responsible for the Rems-Murr district: Familienkasse Baden-Württemberg-Ost (family benefits office).

Parental allowance

Many parents want to take care of their child after the birth. To do so, you do not work for a certain period of time.
Or you only work part-time.

If you have applied for parental allowance, you can get at least 300 € every month. But it can also be more. You usually get parental allowance for 12 months. But it can also be longer.

You get parental allowance if you have a residence and stay in Germany. You need a residence permit. You must live together with your child.

The application and further information on parental allowance

title: Advance Maintenance Payments
excerpt:
You live alone with your child and the other parent (mother or father) pays irregularly or no maintenance (money) for your child?
In this case, you may be able to receive advance maintenance payments (financial support) for your child. However, the other parent (mother or father) may haveto pay the money back.
You must apply for the advance maintenance payments yourself. You make the application at the Unterhaltsvorschusskasse at the Landratsamt.
Here you will find further information on the subject of advance maintenance payments and the application form.

title: Further financial support in the district
excerpt:
FUNKE Children's Foundation
The FUNKE Children's Foundation provides financial support for children in the following areas:

Sport: Membership fees for sports clubs, sports equipment, fees for sports courses, children's gymnastics, swimming courses, ...
Education: School equipment, tutoring, ...
Culture: Music lessons, musical instruments, art courses, theatre courses, ...
Free time: Holiday camps, participation in excursions, ...

 FUNKE Children's Foundation     Talstraße 12      71332 Waiblingen
 07151172434 info@kinderstiftung-funke.de www.kinderstiftung-funke.de

State family voucher booklet
With the State Family Pass and the accompanying voucher card, families who have their permanent residence in Baden-Württemberg can visit the state-owned castles, gardens and museums free of charge or at a reduced entrance fee. 
The following persons can receive a National Family Pass:

Families with at least three children entitled to child benefit
Single parent with child
Families with a severely disabled child
Families who are entitled to child benefit, housing benefit or Hartz IV benefits
Families receiving benefits under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act (Asylbewerberleistungsgesetz) 

The State Family Pass and the corresponding voucher card can be obtained on application at your town hall. There you can also get more information about possible municipal family passes and other reductions.
You can find more information in different languages here.

title: Pension
content:
For many people, the question arises: What happens if I can no longer work in my old age?
For this purpose, Germany has the social security system of the German pension insurance (DRV). The website of the German pension insurance offers a lot of information and can answer some questions about pensions

Deutsche Rentenversicherung

In principle, the pension is paid for by contributions from compulsory insurance jobs. As a rule, halfof the contribution is paid by the employer and half by the employee. 

If you are now in a position to claim a pension, you must apply for it. The pension is not paid automatically. You apply for this at least 3 months before you plan to retire. This makes the transition from employment to retirement easier.

You can find the nearest advice centre on pension insurance here. There you can get more detailed information about your model of pension and other benefit. 

However, the pension insurance does not only pay a pension, but also provides other benefits. This includes, for example, rehabilitation measures in order to be able to work again. It is important that the later pension benefit does not decrease as a result. It may even increase if such a measure keeps you fit for work for longer.

title: Open meetings and cafes

An open meeting place or an open café is a place where people meet. It doesn't matter if they have an appointment or just spontaneously come by. This offers the opportunity to get in touch with a wide variety of people and exchange ideas.

Ask at the town hall of your place of residence for an open meeting place or café.

title: Clubs in the Rems-Murr district
excerpt:
Clubs are of great social importance in Germany. They offer people the opportunity to realise common goals and improve their language skills. These goals can be of different kinds: sporting activity, leisure activities, commitment to the needy and disadvantaged, protecting nature or socialising with like-minded people.
There are many sports clubs in the Rem-Murr district for a wide variety of sports. But there are also music clubs and other hobby clubs.
Normally you have to pay an annual membership fee to be a member. However, you can obtain more detailed information about this directly from the club.
 If you are on a low income, subsidies for membership fees in clubs for children and young people can be granted as part of the education and participation package.
Find out which clubs are available in your local authority.
