title: Migrant organisations
excerpt:
Migrant organisations are organisations that were founded by migrants themselves and also make up the majority of members. There are different goals and orientations that these organisations pursue.
Example:

Cultural associations
Religious associations
Political associations

There are also clubs composed only of women, men, parents, seniors or youth.
You can find further information on the BAMFwebsite.
If you need more information about specific migrant organisations, contact the municipality where you live.

title: Cultural institutions
excerpt:
There are institutions in your municipality that play an important role in cultural education: 

Museums
Libraries
Art schools and music schools
 Theatres


Museums
There are many museums in the Rems-Murr district and in the Stuttgart region. These offer citizens the opportunity for further cultural education. You usually have to pay for admission. Here you can find information on possible reductions.
Here you will find an overview of the museums in the district.

Libraries
In libraries and librarians you can borrowbooks, magazines, CDs, DVDs and sometimes objects. You can then keep the books and media for a few weeks (loan period). Most of it is in German. But sometimes there are also books in other languages. If you want to borrow something, you need an ID card. You can get this card in the library. Most of the time you have to pay something for it. If you do not return the books and media on time, you will have to pay additional fees (money).
Libraries and libraries can be found in  in many communities in the Rem-Murr district.
Ask at the “Rathaus” (town hall) in your place of residence if there is a library.

Art schools and music schools
If you or your child want to learn to play an instrument or sing, you can go to a music school. There is a teacher there who will teach you. If you want to be creative, you can also attend a painting course at the art school.
Art schools and music schools cost money. Part of the costs can possibly be paid via the education and participation package. 
There are art schools and music schools in many municipalities in the district. Find out more at the town hall in your municipality.

 Theatres
There are various theatres in some municipalities in the Rems-Murr district. There is theatre for adults, but also for children.
Here you will find an overview.
You can also get informationdirectly from your municipality.

title: Bank account (current account)
excerpt:
Why do I need a current account?
A current account is an account for people who want to make payments via the bank . Your money is always available in your current account.
With a current account you can:

Make transfers
Receive cashless payments (payments from public offices / authorities / social benefits are often made cashless, i.e. transferred to a personal current account)
Set up standing orders
Participate in direct debits
Cashing cheques, making cashless payments with the EC / Maestro card
Withdraw cash at bank counters or ATMs
Print out your account statements
Opening an account

 Different banks offer current accounts on different terms. Find out exactly how much a current account costs each month and what services the bank offers in return.
How do I open an account?
Decide which bank you would like to have an account with.
Make an appointment to open an account.
Bring the following documents with you to the appointment:

Identification document (proof of arrival, residence permit, authorisation to stay, tolerated stay permit, identity card)
If no current address is noted on the identification document: please bring a registration certificate or a comparable document with you
Important: If you do not speak German or English, please bring an interpreter with you.

Further multilingual information on this topic can be found here.

Important information:
After opening the account, you will receive an EC card with a four-digit PIN code. Sign the back of the EC card. Memorise the PIN code. You will need the PIN code for cashless payments and for withdrawing money from ATMs.Be sure to keep your card and PIN code separate!If you want to withdraw cash: It is best to use the ATMs of the bank where you have your account. Then the withdrawal costs nothing. If the PIN code is entered incorrectly three times at the ATM, the debit card will be withdrawn and blocked. In this case, you must ask your bank.If your EC card is lost or stolen, have it blocked immediately. State your sort code and account number. Then ask your bank for a new EC card.
 116116
Monday to Friday from 0 - 24 hrs
content:
Why do I need a current account?

A current account is an account for people who want to make payments via the bank . Your money is always available in your current account.

With a current account you can:

  • Make transfers
  • Receive cashless payments (payments from public offices / authorities / social benefits are often made cashless, i.e. transferred to a personal current account)
  • Set up standing orders
  • Participate in direct debits
  • Cashing cheques, making cashless payments with the EC / Maestro card
  • Withdraw cash at bank counters or ATMs
  • Print out your account statements
  • Opening an account

Different banks offer current accounts on different terms. Find out exactly how much a current account costs each month and what services the bank offers in return.

How do I open an account?

Decide which bank you would like to have an account with.

Make an appointment to open an account.

Bring the following documents with you to the appointment:

  • Identification document (proof of arrival, residence permit, authorisation to stay, tolerated stay permit, identity card)
  • If no current address is noted on the identification document: please bring a registration certificate or a comparable document with you
  • Important: If you do not speak German or English, please bring an interpreter with you.

Further multilingual information on this topic can be found here.

Important information:

After opening the account, you will receive an EC card with a four-digit PIN code. Sign the back of the EC card. Memorise the PIN code. You will need the PIN code for cashless payments and for withdrawing money from ATMs.
Be sure to keep your card and PIN code separate!
If you want to withdraw cash: It is best to use the ATMs of the bank where you have your account. Then the withdrawal costs nothing. If the PIN code is entered incorrectly three times at the ATM, the debit card will be withdrawn and blocked. In this case, you must ask your bank.
If your EC card is lost or stolen, have it blocked immediately. State your sort code and account number. Then ask your bank for a new EC card.

116116

Monday to Friday from 0 - 24 hrs

title: Broadcasting fees (GEZ)
excerpt:
What are broadcasting fees ()?
Germany has independent radio, television and online services from ARD, ZDF and Deutschlandradio. They report free from economic and political influences. For this, all people pay money together. This is called “broadcasting fees”.
According to the law: A broadcasting fee must be paid for every home in Germany. However, only one person per flat has to pay the broadcasting fee. 
You can find more information here in different languages.
Do I have to pay as well?
Some people can be exempted from this payment. For example, if you receive benefits under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act or other social benefits.  An application must be submitted for exemption from the broadcasting fee.You can find the application for an exemption here.
General information and videos on the subject of broadcasting fees can be found here in several languages.

You can find the application for an exemption here.

General information and videos on the subject of broadcasting fees can be found here in several languages.

Social housing
In many cities and municipalities, there is also social housing. These are subsidised by the state and are only rented topeople with a certificate of eligibility for housing . If you are looking to get social housing, you must apply for a “Wohnberechtigungsschein” (certificate of eligibility for housing) from your municipality. For more information, please contact your town hall.

title: I have found an apartment
excerpt:
Rental contract
The amount of rent is agreed in the rental contract. When tenants sign a rental contract, they agree to pay that amount of rent.
The rent is made up of cold rent (basic amount), ancillary costs (refuse collection, operating costs) and heating costs. 
The date that rent is due is agreed upon in the lease contract. If the rent is increasingly not paid on time, this can lead to termination of the lease contract.
You need to read the lease carefully. If you do not understand everything, ask somebody who can help you.
 The rental contract is very important. Once it is signed, it cannot be cancelled so quickly! 
The contract must include the following points:

Name and address of the landlord
Address of the rental object
Living space in m²
Number of rooms
Amount of the net base rent
Agreed amount of operational costs
Amount of heating costs
Total rent
Amount of damage deposit

If you agree with what the lease says, then sign it.
For more information in several languages, click here.
Deposit
The deposit is a security for the landlord/landlady. The amount for the damage deposit is a maximum of 3 base rents. When you move out of the property, you will get the money back, provided that you have not caused any damage.
Possible cost absorption
If you receive money from the Jobcentre or the Landratsamt , you must observe the following:
Important: You may not signthe tenancy agreement yet, but must first have it approved.
First of all, you need to get an estimate from your future landlord.
This should include:

The amount of the rent
The amount of any additional costs (heating, water, electricity)
The amount of the deposit
Possible graduated rent (automatic increase of the rent)

You must go to the Job Centre / Landratsamt with the cost estimate. They check the cost estimate.If everything is in order, they'll approve it.If you have a residence requirement, you must submit an application to the Aliens' Registration Office (Ausländerbehörde) .
Initial equipment
If you receive benefits from the Job Centre, you have the possibility to apply for initial equipment for furniture and furnishings. You will be paid a lump sum. 
 It is important that the application is made before the furniture is purchased
Caution: It may take a while before the money is paid out! In addition, the Job Centre has the right to inspect the flat in order to check the amount of the initial equipment. 
Info for refugees: When moving out of accommodation, you are not allowed to take the furniture of the accommodation with you. That is why you need new furniture. You can apply to the Job Centre for initial outfitting.
Housing benefit
If you and the people living with you in the household earn little money, you are entitled to housing benefit under certain conditions. If you get money from the state for yourself and your family, you will not usually need to apply for housing benefit.
 Information on housing benefit in the Rems-Murr district

Rental contract

The amount of rent is agreed in the rental contract. When tenants sign a rental contract, they agree to pay that amount of rent.

The rent is made up of cold rent (basic amount), ancillary costs (refuse collection, operating costs) and heating costs.

The date that rent is due is agreed upon in the lease contract. If the rent is increasingly not paid on time, this can lead to termination of the lease contract.

You need to read the lease carefully. If you do not understand everything, ask somebody who can help you.

The rental contract is very important. Once it is signed, it cannot be cancelled so quickly! 

The contract must include the following points:

  • Name and address of the landlord
  • Address of the rental object
  • Living space in m²
  • Number of rooms
  • Amount of the net base rent
  • Agreed amount of operational costs
  • Amount of heating costs
  • Total rent
  • Amount of damage deposit

If you agree with what the lease says, then sign it.

For more information in several languages, click here.

Deposit

The deposit is a security for the landlord/landlady. The amount for the damage deposit is a maximum of 3 base rents. When you move out of the property, you will get the money back, provided that you have not caused any damage.

Possible cost absorption

If you receive money from the Jobcentre or the Landratsamt , you must observe the following:

Important: You may not signthe tenancy agreement yet, but must first have it approved.

First of all, you need to get an estimate from your future landlord.

This should include:

  • The amount of the rent
  • The amount of any additional costs (heating, water, electricity)
  • The amount of the deposit
  • Possible graduated rent (automatic increase of the rent)

You must go to the Job Centre / Landratsamt with the cost estimate. They check the cost estimate.
If everything is in order, they'll approve it.
If you have a residence requirement, you must submit an application to the Aliens' Registration Office (Ausländerbehörde) .

Initial equipment

If you receive benefits from the Job Centre, you have the possibility to apply for initial equipment for furniture and furnishings. You will be paid a lump sum. 

It is important that the application is made before the furniture is purchased

Caution: It may take a while before the money is paid out! In addition, the Job Centre has the right to inspect the flat in order to check the amount of the initial equipment. 

Info for refugees: When moving out of accommodation, you are not allowed to take the furniture of the accommodation with you. That is why you need new furniture. You can apply to the Job Centre for initial outfitting.

Housing benefit

If you and the people living with you in the household earn little money, you are entitled to housing benefit under certain conditions. If you get money from the state for yourself and your family, you will not usually need to apply for housing benefit.

Information on housing benefit in the Rems-Murr district

title: Moving Home
content:
As soon as you have moved into your new home, you must register with your new municipal administration within two weeks. You will need a landlord's certificatefrom your landlord for this. If you miss the two-week deadline, a penalty may be imposed.

Ask at the town hall for the forms or look on the homepage of the town hall.

Inform all important offices of your new address (e.g. bank, district office/job centre, insurance company, employer, immigration office). Please make sure your name is on the letterbox.

title: Bicycle
excerpt:
What do you have to consider when riding a bike?
You can easily explore the Rems-Murr district by bike.You can get anywhere at any time, quickly and at low cost.There are special cycle pathsin Germany and also in the Rems-Murr district. Cyclists must also obey the traffic rules . You can find an overview of the most important traffic rules in Germany in different languages on the following page. When buying a bicycle, make sure that it is roadworthy .
Some important traffic rules for cyclists:

Always ride on the right side of the road.
Do not ride next to each other, but one behind the other.
If there is a cycle path, you must use it.
Only children under 11 years of age are allowed to use the footpaths by bicycle.

Bike repair
Bicycle shops can repair your bike. You'll have to pay for that. In some municipalities there are also bicycle repair shops run by volunteers.  That is usually cheaper. You can also get help with repairs here.Find out what services and support options are available locally. 
Here you will find extensive information in many languages.

Some important traffic rules for cyclists:

  • Always ride on the right side of the road.
  • Do not ride next to each other, but one behind the other.
  • If there is a cycle path, you must use it.
  • Only children under 11 years of age are allowed to use the footpaths by bicycle.

Bike repair

Bicycle shops can repair your bike. You'll have to pay for that. In some municipalities there are also bicycle repair shops run by volunteers. That is usually cheaper. You can also get help with repairs here.
Find out what services and support options are available locally.

Here you will find extensive information in many languages.

title: Bus and train
excerpt:
To get to your destination in the Rems-Murr district, public transport is available. That's bus and train. 
Ticket
Check out exactly which ticket you need and which ticket is the cheapest for you. This is because there is a large number of different tickets.
There are, for example:

Single tickets
Day tickets
Weekly or monthly tickets

There are also, for example, tickets:

for kids
for pupils
for students
for families and groups

 Since May 2023, there is also the Deutschlandticket for €49 per month. You can find the latest news on the Deutschlandticket here.
Apps and websites for public transport

Regional: VVS website + VVS app
Baden-Württemberg: bwegt website + bwegt app
German Railways: DB website + DB Navigator app

Driving without a ticket will be punished! A valid ticket is required for every trip. Otherwise you will pay a heavy fine.

title: Cars
excerpt:
Driving licence
If you drive a car in Germany, you must have a valid driving licence and always carry it with you.
In Germany, you can drive a car from the age of 18 and with a valid driving licence.There is also the option of taking the driving licence at the age of 17.
You want to get your driving licence?
If you want to get your driving licence, choose a driving school.  The driving school will explain which documents you need and how to proceed. Getting a driving licence costs money. Please enquire in advance about the amount of these costs.
In order to get a German driving licence, you must pass the theoretical and the practical exam.The theoretical examination can be taken in many languages other than German. Talk to your driving instructor about this.
You must also attend a first aid course. There you will learn how to provide help in an emergency situation, for example in case of accidents, burns and poisoning.
Here you can find more information and contact details on how to apply for a driving licence at the district office.
You already have a foreign driving licence?
You have a foreign driving licence and live in Germany?
In this case, your foreign driving licence is still valid for 6 months after you moved to Germany.After these 6 months, you must transferyour driving licence to a German driving licence. You will also have to take a theoretical and practical exam.
 Persons from EU/EEA states with a valid driving licence do not need to transfer their foreign driving licence.
Here you can get further information as well as applications for the transfer of your driving licence.
Note: To ensure that road traffic is safe for you and others, there are many rules. You must observe these when driving a car. These rules are laid down in the Straßenverkehrs-Ordnung (StVO). If you break these rules, you will be fined.Penalties can be: Fines, a driving ban or points on your licence.
Here you will find further information in several languages.

Register a car
You would like to buy a motor vehicle (for example car, truck, motorbike, scooter) and drive it? Then you must register (register) this motor vehicle. To do this, you must go to the “Zulassungsstelle” (Registration Office).
Please make an appointment online inadvance.
Waiblingen, Schorndorf and Backnang
Here you will find all important information on admission and the contact details of the respective locations.

title: Volunteering in the refugee and migration sector
excerpt:
In almost every town and municipality in the Rems-Murr district, there are groups that are committed to helping migrants and refugees. The volunteers help the migrants to orientate themselves in their environment. They help with questions about daily life, for example. For example, if a letter is not understood in German. Many volunteer groups also offer support with learning German.
Would you like to volunteer in the refugee sector? Then you can contact the district's volunteer coordination centre:
Harald LuttmannVolunteer support
 071515011670 h.luttmann@rems-murr-kreis.de
Sandra KrebPromotion of volunteering
 071515011417 s.kreb@rems-murr-kreis.de
Further information can be found here.
If you would like to volunteer in a particular municipality, you can contact the respective town hall.

title: Volunteer
excerpt:
Volunteering means that people work for an issue voluntarily and without money in addition to their work. 
You can volunteer in these areas:

Refugee assistance
Nature conservation
voluntary fire brigade 
Activities in the religious field
Music clubs and sports clubs

Often these people are organised in associations.  Volunteering brings together people with similar interests. Volunteering is therefore important for everyone. You can become a volunteer, too, and get to know people in your area. If you are interested in volunteering, you can contact the municipality where you live.
content:
Volunteering means that people work for an issue voluntarily and without money in addition to their work. 

You can volunteer in these areas:

  • Refugee assistance
  • Nature conservation
  • voluntary fire brigade 
  • Activities in the religious field
  • Music clubs and sports clubs

Often these people are organised in associations. Volunteering brings together people with similar interests. Volunteering is therefore important for everyone. You can become a volunteer, too, and get to know people in your area. If you are interested in volunteering, you can contact the municipality where you live.

title: Shopping Facilities
excerpt:
In Germany, shops are generally open from Monday to Saturday. They are usually closed on Sundays and public holidays. The opening hours of the shops may vary. You can find out about this on the Internet or at the entrance to the respective shops.
 Restaurants, cafés and leisure facilities (for example swimming pools, museums, cinemas) are also open on Sundays and public holidays.
Here you can shop:

Discount shopsIn discount shops you can mainly buy cheaper food. The range of goods is relatively limited and is presented in a simple way. There are discount shops in almost every town.
SupermarketsIn supermarkets you can mainly buy somewhat more expensive food. Here you will also find many branded products. Greater importance is attached to the presentation of the goods than is the case with discount shops.
Weekly marketsAt the weekly markets you can buy primarily regional food (e.g. fruit, vegetables, eggs, bread). The weekly markets are only held on certain days of the week and usually in the morning. But there is not a weekly market in every town.
Specialist shopsSpecialist shops are shops where you can buy mainly goods of a certain category. These are, for example, bakeries, butchers, sports shops, shoe shops.
Retail shops with foreign productsThere are shops, especially in larger cities, where you can buy foreign products. There are, for example, Turkish, Russian or Asian food shops.
DrugstoresDrugstores are specialist shops with an extensive assortment. Here you can buy mainly hygiene products (e.g. shampoo, cleaning agents) or cleaning products (e.g. washing powder, washing-up liquid).
content:
In Germany, shops are generally open from Monday to Saturday. They are usually closed on Sundays and public holidays. The opening hours of the shops may vary. You can find out about this on the Internet or at the entrance to the respective shops.

Restaurants, cafés and leisure facilities (for example swimming pools, museums, cinemas) are also open on Sundays and public holidays.

Here you can shop:

  • Discount shops
    In discount shops you can mainly buy cheaper food. The range of goods is relatively limited and is presented in a simple way. There are discount shops in almost every town.
  • Supermarkets
    In supermarkets you can mainly buy somewhat more expensive food. Here you will also find many branded products. Greater importance is attached to the presentation of the goods than is the case with discount shops.
  • Weekly markets
    At the weekly markets you can buy primarily regional food (e.g. fruit, vegetables, eggs, bread). The weekly markets are only held on certain days of the week and usually in the morning. But there is not a weekly market in every town.
  • Specialist shops
    Specialist shops are shops where you can buy mainly goods of a certain category. These are, for example, bakeries, butchers, sports shops, shoe shops.
  • Retail shops with foreign products
    There are shops, especially in larger cities, where you can buy foreign products. There are, for example, Turkish, Russian or Asian food shops.
  • Drugstores
    Drugstores are specialist shops with an extensive assortment. Here you can buy mainly hygiene products (e.g. shampoo, cleaning agents) or cleaning products (e.g. washing powder, washing-up liquid).

title: What is the “Tafel” and who can visit there?
excerpt:
The Tafel helps people who don't have much money. They offer cheap food and hygiene products that are no longer sold in the shops. These include:

Foods with an imminent expiry date
Baked goods from the previous day
Damaged or dented packaging
Fruit and vegetables with small blemishes.

You can get food and toiletries from here if you do not work or do not earn enough money. You willneed an ID card for this. It is issued by the “Tafel” stores. Go there with your proof that they are needy.  For example, with your official notice issued via the “AsylblG” or “Sozialhilfe” (these are the letters that state how much money you will receive for one month).
In the Rems-Murr district there are Tafel shops in the following towns: Waiblingen, Fellbach, Backnang, Winnenden, Weinstadt, Welzheim, Murrhardt Here you will find the respective addresses and contact details.
content:
The Tafel helps people who don't have much money. They offer cheap food and hygiene products that are no longer sold in the shops. These include:

  • Foods with an imminent expiry date
  • Baked goods from the previous day
  • Damaged or dented packaging
  • Fruit and vegetables with small blemishes.

You can get food and toiletries from here if you do not work or do not earn enough money. You willneed an ID card for this. It is issued by the “Tafel” stores. Go there with your proof that they are needy. For example, with your official notice issued via the “AsylblG” or “Sozialhilfe” (these are the letters that state how much money you will receive for one month).

In the Rems-Murr district there are Tafel shops in the following towns:
Waiblingen, Fellbach, Backnang, Winnenden, Weinstadt, Welzheim, Murrhardt
Here you will find the respective addresses and contact details.

title: Where can I buy and sell used goods?
excerpt:
Second-hand shop
In second-hand shops you can buy second-hand clothes, furniture, books, electrical goods and so on very cheaply .In some municipalities, there are also social department stores where you can buy inexpensive everyday items.For some shops you need an entitlement certificate. Therefore, please bring your identity papers, proof of income from social welfare, pension or other sources with you on your first visit. Find out where there are such shops in the town where you live. 
Clothing store
Buy used clothing in the Rems-Murr district at low prices:
 Backnang, Schordorf, Winnenden
 German Red Cross Clothing Closets 

Flea market 
At flea markets you can buy used goods. This can be clothes, jewellery, tableware and much more. Often there are themed flea markets. For example, only children's things are sold at a children's flea market . You can also sell goods at the flea market. You have to pay stand fees for this. Check with the office that organises the flea market.
You can find out when and where the next flea market will be here.

Other ways to buy or sell used items

The information boards in shops
the classifieds section in the daily newspapers and weeklies
Social media
Apps for second hand goods
other websites for used goods

Some things are even given away.

title: Contracts
excerpt:
In Germany, there are contracts for many things.
For example:

Renting an apartment (rental contract)
New job (employment contract)
New mobile phone (mobile phone contract)
Registering at the gym (membership contract)

If the contract is signed by two parties, it is legally binding. Everything concluded in the contract must be complied with by the buyer and also by the trader.
For example, if you have a contract with the gym for 2 years, then you will also have to pay the fees for 2 years. Therefore, you should consider whether you can pay for everything for this period.
Often, contracts also contain "small print". This is usually written in small letters at the bottom of the contract. It is essential that you always read this and agree to it before signing.Donot allow yourself to be pressured into signing a contract. You always have the right to read and check everything. Ask if you can take the contract home with you if necessary. Then you can read the contract in peace or have it translated.
You may also seek legal counsel or advice in the event of disagreement with the other party.
Termination
You must give written notice (usually 3 months before the end of the contract). If you do not observe the notice period, the contract is often automatically renewed.

Mobile phone contract
There are two different mobile phone contracts in Germany.

Prepaid contract The prepaid contract does not have a fixed contract term, but you have to top up your phone’s credit (money).
Term contract The fixed-term contact has a minimum contract period. Ask how long the contract lasts and check whether you can pay it for that long. This contract is automatically renewed if you do not cancel. If you do not want the contract to be automatically renewed, you must cancel in writing. Pay attention to the notice period.

For example, if you have a contract with the gym for 2 years, then you will also have to pay the fees for 2 years. Therefore, you should consider whether you can pay for everything for this period.

Often, contracts also contain "small print". This is usually written in small letters at the bottom of the contract. It is essential that you always read this and agree to it before signing.
Donot allow yourself to be pressured into signing a contract. You always have the right to read and check everything. Ask if you can take the contract home with you if necessary. Then you can read the contract in peace or have it translated.

You may also seek legal counsel or advice in the event of disagreement with the other party.

Termination

You must give written notice (usually 3 months before the end of the contract). If you do not observe the notice period, the contract is often automatically renewed.

There are two different mobile phone contracts in Germany.

  • Prepaid contract 
    The prepaid contract does not have a fixed contract term, but you have to top up your phone’s credit (money).

title: Insurances
excerpt:
Important insurances 
In addition to the five statutory social insurances (health insurance, long-term care insurance, pension insurance, accident insurance and unemployment insurance), there are other insurances. These are voluntary, even if the word "compulsory" sometimes appears in their name, as in the case of "liability insurance". Most of them insure you against financial risks. Depending on your life situation, some of them may be useful.
The best-known supplementary insurances are

Liability insurance
household contents insurance
KVZ insurance
Mobile phone insurance

Further information in various languages on the subject of insurance can be found here.
content:
Important insurances

In addition to the five statutory social insurances (health insurance, long-term care insurance, pension insurance, accident insurance and unemployment insurance), there are other insurances. These are voluntary, even if the word "compulsory" sometimes appears in their name, as in the case of "liability insurance". Most of them insure you against financial risks. Depending on your life situation, some of them may be useful.

The best-known supplementary insurances are

  • Liability insurance
  • household contents insurance
  • KVZ insurance
  • Mobile phone insurance

Further information in various languages on the subject of insurance can be found here.

title: Save electricity and energy
content:
Normally the new tenants are automatically registered by the landlord with the electricity supplier. You can choose the electricity provider yourself. After a notice period of approximately 2 weeks, you can change your electricity provider. 

The best way to find an overview of providers and price comparisons is via the independent energy consumer portal.

www.energieverbraucherportal.de

Saving energy = saving money

Make sure you ventilate regularly (open the window fully for 5 minutes at least 3 times a day) and heat properly. In this way, you prevent mould from developing and save energy and thus money.

Detailed information and helpful tips are available from the consumer advice centre in various languages.

Saving energy  

Power-saving check

People on low incomes or social benefits learn how to save energy in their homes during the electricity savings check. In this way, they save money in the long term and protect the climate. The consultations are free of charge.

The electricity savings checks can be carried out as a consultation and in the home and consist of two appointments. Households are given tips on energy-saving behaviour and receive a free starter pack containing energy-saving light bulbs, sockets with off-switches, energy-saving showers and more.

Contact

Mr Bühlweiler
07151172422
buehlweiler@caritas-ludwigsburg-waiblingen-enz.de
Power-saving check

title: Waste separation
excerpt:
Waste must be disposed of in the designated bin. There are different bins for plastic, paper and cardboard, for food leftovers (organic waste) and for other waste. Please adhere to waste separation, as much of the waste is reused and it is an important part of environmental protection. 
What goes in which waste bin? When are the waste bins emptied? Where is there a recycling point? Information can be found here:
Waste Management Rems-Murr District
 Waste Management Rems-Murr
The Rems-Murr-Kreis waste management authority now also has an app for mobile phones. Here you can find important information and see on which days your bins are emptied: Waste app
Foreign language information on waste separation, waste disposal and waste prevention can be found here.

title: Water (drinking water)
excerpt:
In Germany, water can be drunk directly from the tap.  The quality of the drinking water is strictly controlled.
 It is generally recommended to use only cold water for drinking and preparing food and drinks.
 If the water is in the pipe for a long time (more than 4 hours), it is recommended to let it run until it comes out cooler.
content:
In Germany, water can be drunk directly from the tap. The quality of the drinking water is strictly controlled.

It is generally recommended to use only cold water for drinking and preparing food and drinks.

If the water is in the pipe for a long time (more than 4 hours), it is recommended to let it run until it comes out cooler.

title: Internet and Wi-Fi
excerpt:
Public and free wifi
Free Wi-Fi is available in several places in public areas (hotspots), for example in city centres, libraries, restaurants or media houses. There you can surf the internet with your own device.
Private WLAN and Internet
For a private Wi-Fi via your mobile phone or computer, you need an internet contract.
Note: Be careful with internet contracts. Bear in mind that a contract is often concluded for at least 2 years. Before signing a contract, ask your accommodation management or landlord whether WLAN is technically possible at all.

Note: Be careful with internet contracts. Bear in mind that a contract is often concluded for at least 2 years. Before signing a contract, ask your accommodation management or landlord whether WLAN is technically possible at all.
